pros: The people that make up this organization are amazing, smart, and excellent to work with.  Someone is always willing to help out and we all realize the goal of the job is to protect the warfighter.  At the lower levels, new ideas are always welcome.
cons: A LARGE amount of bureaucracy.  Upper management is completely detached and gets very little input from the ground floor, so much so that it has a very large impact on business in the long run.  Favoritism and nepotism are near epidemic levels which prevent's the company from making actual progress.

review_title: When is the Change Coming
pros: Great company to work for as far as flexibility and work life balance
cons:
Upper Management, especially at the Director level is no-help what-so-ever.
They need to guide their management and allow them the opportunity to grow employees.  Employees are dissatisfied with all the red tapes and lack of advancement.  In 2016, it is time to stop the good old boy/girl network and broaden the horizon, especially when it comes to diversity in hiring people of color (especially black males into management).

review_title: Client Opportunities are Interesting//Annual Review Process is Horrible
pros:
Company has many Contracts, which enables employees to join new Programs to enhance job skills and reduce boredom of being on the same Project for many years.

Truly some very smart people dedicated to the their government customer's mission.  You can serve on a Program that clearly has positive implications to our country's national defense.
cons: Annual review process is so awkward and employees are required to finalize their annual review at least two months before the year ends.  Also, way too much emphasis on Innovation from a Company standpoint--e.g. how many people did you refer or how much did you grow the business--rather than how employees have developed and implemented innovative solutions for their government customers.

review_title: Client Opportunities are Interesting//Annual Review Process is Horrible
pros:
Company has many Contracts, which enables employees to join new Programs to enhance job skills and reduce boredom of being on the same Project for many years.

Truly some very smart people dedicated to the their government customer's mission.  You can serve on a Program that clearly has positive implications to our country's national defense.
cons: Annual review process is so awkward and employees are required to finalize their annual review at least two months before the year ends.  Also, way too much emphasis on Innovation from a Company standpoint--e.g. how many people did you refer or how much did you grow the business--rather than how employees have developed and implemented innovative solutions for their government customers.

review_title: Overview of life at NGC and in Aerospace
job_title: Software Engineer II in Carson, CA
pros: It is a safe and secure environment to work. With a security clearance it is almost impossible to be laid off. Compensation is around market and the benefits are great. You will get in at 8 and leave at 4:42... (seriously, you have 42 minute lunches in parts of NGC)
cons: The skills learned there tend to be niche within the aerospace industry. So you tend to get pigeonholed into aerospace because the skills are non-transferable. Also pay increases are not really performance based. You will get between 3-5% a year even if you get a spectacular review. You have to threaten to leave or transfer within the company to get a significant bump in pay.

review_title: Northrop is a good company with very ethical leadership, but limited opportunities for promotability.
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in McLean, VA
pros: Ethical leadership, good CEO, and many interesting contracts. Generally the pay is competitive for the industry, and there is general flexibility in work (provided not working at a government site). Generally the fiscal environment in defense is causing the company to execute long term strategies better than in the past.
cons: Defense budget tightening is causing the company to shrink which has resulted in fewer positions, lost contracts, and asking people to do more for the same compensation. Overall, the biggest issue with the company is the HR though. They are an opaque organization, soloed away from the actual contracts doing the work, and do not seem to help people advance in the company. They seem disconnected from the rest of the company, aloof on what we actually do, and are not helpful.

review_title: Some insights into getting the job and whats required
job_title: Systems Engineering and Test Integration IV in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros: Good pay,  The best in Technology
cons:
The security clearance process is a total pain in the a**,  takes up to 2 years to get a TS clearance.  If your interim clearance gets denied watch out...  your offer can be pulled anytime. They wont hold your job for 2 years and wont tell you this up front - leaving you up in the air, so don't  quit your current job unless you get interim clearance otherwise the door will slam in your face with one foot in the door...

This company lives and dies by the contracts,  they over hire in many cases and expect a certain percentage to fail their clearance contingency so don't get your hopes up until you get the formal approval to walk in the door....

review_title: Challenging and Stable
job_title: RF/Microwave Engineer in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: A lot of very big, long-term contracts have recently been won, so there's a ton of work and stability working here. The work environment is not competitive and many of the employees are very willing to take the time to teach and mentor their junior coworkers. There's a lot of stability and a lot of PTO and flexibility in work schedule (depending on your manager). There are plenty of benefits (401K, health insurance, etc.) that also make it a great place to work.
cons: It can get slow sometimes and may not be the best for someone who wants a fast-paced work environment. Certain programs are extremely fast-paced, but those programs are not representative of the majority of the work in the company. And if you're looking for fun perks that have become a norm in big tech companies and startups (nitro coffee, kombucha bars, beer on tap, etc.), you will be disappointed. Most people invest in a coffee machine with their coworkers and use that for their daily caffeination.

review_title: Paternal company, lacking aligned leadership
pros: Everyone is very nice, and they work very hard.  It has competitive benefits, including salary.  It is loaded with resources and assets to help you professionally and personally.  Great location, near McLean metro stop.
cons: Lacks strategic leadership into the organization, so you feel somewhat like you are spinning your wheels.  So risk adverse, you can't do anything without a lawyer in the room.  Moves too slow due to democratic decision making.  In a different time, these things could be overcome, but in today's world of fast pace and try/fail mentality, it will be tough for them to compete in the IT space.

review_title: Good place to work if you are willing to actively own your career and make known your skills and desires.
pros:
Large Organization with lots of opportunities across many disciplines.... if you are willing to pursue them on your own and you don't rely on just your manager to identify opportunities

Many engineers that are very dedicated to the craft and are the heart and soul of the organization

Some of the functional managers care very much for the welfare of the employees and for the business - be sure to look out for them and try to work for them or at least with them...
cons:
Large Organization... very political - step carefully

Some very opinionated senior staff that yields much influence,some are willing to open up to new ideas, many are not

review_title: Great Company - Depending on Organization
pros: Good benefits, good salary, bonuses for performance, 9/80 work schedule, lots of internal development, corporate truly seems to care about the employees, interesting work
cons: Many manager manage "up" meaning they couldn't care less about their organization; lots of egos - the "West Point-ers" especially act as if they know absolutely everything about everything; the work is usually more challenging due to schedule than due to complexity; In the defense industry, you'll find that your current assignment magically vanishes due to a change in government spending, but don't worry - you'll likely be doing the exact same thing on the next project, starting from scratch, until that assignment vanishes.

review_title: Northrop Grumman provided valuable opportunities for personal growth in defense systems integration and development.
pros:
- Gives large variety of jobs in technology, systems integration and technical services to improve the value of business unit programs and client services
- In a large corporation, it is possible to advance to new challenges while maintaining/increasing your benefits within the company
- With CMMI Level 3 ratings in most areas of the company, processes are well defined and training is readily available to facilitate job completion and employee growth
- Northrop Grumman's past performance is outstanding in many business areas which enables contract growth
cons:
- As a large corporation, Northrop Grumman has much bureaucracy, detailed policies and corporate goals which sometimes inhibit entrepreneurial approaches to problems and business development
- Senior management often profess lofty goals like facilitating engaged employees but many times do not back up their managers or employees with any resources to address improvements that employees suggest because of restrictions on available overhead funding

review_title: Uninspirational but decent place to work
job_title: Electrical Engineer III in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros: Decent salaries and benefits, smart people to work with, some flexibility.  nice work out facility and cafeteria.  Great people here that tend to stay for years.  It's definitely not the worst place you could work.  They made it worth my while to come and work here.
cons: Bureaucratic, you feel like an employee rather than a partner in the success of the company (no bonus), focused on the hours you work rather than whether you get your work done.  For a salary job, I'd rather manage my own time, but working in defense, every hour has to be accounted for.  So it isn't not really a salary job.  Slow with promotions and raises, and be careful that you don't get maxed out for your job grade.  Rolling Meadows is an old dated facility.  For high performing ambitious individuals, I don't think NG is the place for you.  You'll get tired of running into walls and limitations.

review_title: Northrop Grumman IS - A great place to work for the driven professional
job_title: Systems Engineer in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: Northrop has an amazing amount of resources available that you won't find in smaller businesses.  Northrop has the knowledge and expertise to compete with any other company in aerospace, and they have the facilities and hardware to get work completed.  The work that Northrop does is very interesting, and seems important to the nation.  When it comes down to it, some of the best minds in the nation are at work at Northrop, and there's as much to learn as there is to do.
cons: Northrop is a huge company, and if you're not a self-starter, you can get lost in the company, or think that you're doing a lot better than management thinks you are.  There are politics involved, and one must be good at playing the game just as one must be good at doing the actual work.

review_title: OK Place to Work
pros: Most of this depends on the department/program you're on... My experience was: job security is good. Pay/benefits good. Fun and exciting products to work on. If you have a whole lot of patience and you're a hard and smart worker that is able to live above, or at least in harmony with, the red tape, you could go far here.
cons: Lots of red tape. Little to no interest in "truly" improving processes. Not much interest in getting work done right the first time. Plenty of people not adding value to much of anything that are promoted to get them out of the way.

review_title: exempt vs non exempt employees
pros: salary for most employees is great, which in turn employee longevity is almost certain.  People are friendly and can be helpful to help a person transition into new work environments.
cons: Recognition to employees other than exempt is not visible.  Due to the longevity of a lot of employees, it is very difficult for a non exempt employee from other companies to bring their experience, work abilities, work place knowledge from other companies into the Northrop Grumman work place.  With all the layoffs and RIFS people (exempt) are not disseminating their workloads as they should and are overloaded with work.

review_title: Make your own career here-it's who you know, for better or worse
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Woodland Hills, CA
pros: Mobility within company, great people, amazing products and technology. 9/80 schedule, educational reimbursement, health plans, on-site cafeteria, credit union, doc/nurse, health coordinator, employee resource groups (ERG).
cons: Politics, politics, politics, the "good old boys club" runs rampant, ignorant uneducated management (mismanagement), poor (none) design-for-manifacturability, HR is corporate and on the side of the company not an advocate for employee, NEPOTISM from the TOP down (hiring and promoting incompetent, unqualified people based on bloodlines, personal relationships, shared foreign nationality -hint hint Middle East), harassment and different treatment of women, rewards and awards programs"revamped" designed to minimize opportunities for employees and reduced $ amount of awards, employee reviews based on politics and  quotas (allegedly) from corporate (think of that one horrible teacher in college who only gave two A's max no matter the merit), regular layoffs, layoffs based on management politics.

review_title: Northrop Grumman has been a great place to start my career and develop the skills I need to succeed at whatever I do.
pros: It's a really big company, so there's a good chance that whatever kind of engineering you do, there's somebody working in the same area. Most of the people I've worked with within the company have been exceptional in terms of their knowledge, enthusiasm, and commitment to creating really great things.
cons: It's a really big company, so there's a lot of bureaucracy and sometimes even little things can take frustratingly long to get done. Also, because there are so many different locations, the culture varies greatly from one campus to the next, and your experience working with one campus will likely be greatly different from another.

review_title: Instructional Designers beware
pros: Good entry level learning experience, if you are hired with other people it can be beneficial, benefits are good.
cons:
There was undercutting and there was an effort to bring you down if you threaten any positions (with ability).
They started setting my hours after an amount of time because I missed a meeting no one told me about (terrible communication).
Poor responsibility and inability to follow up on projects to find out if they did good on their projects (unaccountable leadership).
High turnover due to terrible contracts and your hours can become "guess work" if there isn't a new project to work on.
They start you off as Part-Time on call and if you prove your worth, they move you to full time (time management lacking). 
Gossip in the workplace causes those who have not been there to be "the fall guy".
I do NOT recommend Northrop Grumman for Instructional Designers/Trainers.

review_title: Hear No Evil, See No Evil, Speak No Evil
job_title: Senior Cyber Security Engineer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Pay was good, health benefits where good.
cons:
Management does not listen to employees.  I brought ethics violations and federal contracting violations by a sub-contractor manager to the attention of Northrop Grumman management and I was given the excuse "He's the manager" by my Northrop Grumman management.  Those excuses cost Northrop yet another employee because I cleaned out my desk and walked off the job because I was not going to deal with the corrupt sub-contractor manager who was introducing risk into the government contract without government permission and making it impossible to do what I was hired to do.

Northrop black lists employees who leave under duress or other than desirable circumstances and give negative feedback to potential employers when doing an employment background check.  This was verified by an associate who called NG and posed as an employer seeking to hire me.

review_title: My honest opinion about my experience so far.
pros: Company focuses a lot on professional development and retaining employees in the company. Some managers do a really good job at listening to the employees.
cons: There are some great things about the company and I feel like I could REALLY love it if a few things changed, but the cons unfortunately outweigh the pros. There have been WAY too many unfulfilled promises. It's almost to the point where I hear something from management and doubt it'll ever come true. NG made all kinds of promises to me "if I join the company" and not one of them have come true which has made me feel VERY taken advantage of. It's been very upsetting to me and my family. Many managers (and employees in general) tend to micromanage HEAVILY.  Biggest thing - company doesn't live the values that they claim to live (at least at my location).

review_title: Not a place you want to work if you expect advancement or professional growth.
job_title: Software Development Analyst III in Helena, MT
pros:
-Knowledgeable, friendly co-workers that are open for questions and technical support.
-Awesome medical benefits.
-Flexible hours and no pressure requesting vacation time.
-Management makes it easy for employees to schedule meetings with them if you ever need to talk.
-Management is  very prompt on answering or researching your questions.
cons:
-As one reviewer said for the Helena site, too many signatures needed by managers on the company and client sides to get tasks rolling quickly.
-Recognition is next to invisible.
-Management on all levels is less than adequate when it comes to the business side of things (read, disconnect between management and clients). Also very top heavy with managers.
-Training before you start a new project is non-existent.
-Promotions and advancement seem unattainable. Managerial decisions of who gets a raise or is promoted is decided before employees even get to their year end, performance management meetings.

review_title: A solid stable job for new business undergrads - NGAS.
job_title: Cost Estimating Analyst IV in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: Work/balance is good - depending on the program and functional area.  Projects are cutting edge and interesting scientifically.  Lot opportunity to move around after you have a couple of years under your belt.  A lot of old timers are leaving or have left.   This will open up a lot of doors for new hires and recent college grads.  They have a generous grad school subsidy (business and science).
cons: Overachievers are not necessarily rewarded more against their peers (unless you count more work!).  Raises are barely in line with inflation.  Nepotism and politics can still reign over competency.  Bureaucracy can be beyond frustrating.  HR still approaches promotion based on years of experience first not necessarily ability or talent.

review_title: A solid stable job for new business undergrads - NGAS.
job_title: Cost Estimating Analyst IV in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: Work/balance is good - depending on the program and functional area.  Projects are cutting edge and interesting scientifically.  Lot opportunity to move around after you have a couple of years under your belt.  A lot of old timers are leaving or have left.   This will open up a lot of doors for new hires and recent college grads.  They have a generous grad school subsidy (business and science).
cons: Overachievers are not necessarily rewarded more against their peers (unless you count more work!).  Raises are barely in line with inflation.  Nepotism and politics can still reign over competency.  Bureaucracy can be beyond frustrating.  HR still approaches promotion based on years of experience first not necessarily ability or talent.

review_title: Great company but an increasinly negative place to work
pros: Great company legacy, exciting aircraft and space programs.  Good salary and benefits.   Good work/life balance for the most part, every other Friday off.
cons: The culture has changed dramatically over the last five years; management is more cutthroat and pays lip service toward goals such as employee engagement and diversity.  Has become a very political environment, sadly, with people undercutting each other to advance rather than helping each other to advance their careers.  Total loss of the reward of feeling like you're part of a team. I couldn't stand the ugly environment anymore after 14 years. (referring specifically to Space Park).  Opportunities for career advancement are based purely on politics versus the applicant's abilities.

review_title: There's a reason you won't see Northrop on the lists of "best places to work"
job_title: Software Engineer IV in San Diego, CA
pros: Northrop Grumman designs and integrates some of the most awesome systems in the world for Defense.
cons: Northrop has shifted its priorities to shareholders and customers above its own people. This may be the "right" decision to make for the company, but it doesn't make it a good place to work.

review_title: Planning analyst
pros: Has health benefits and 401K like other big companies; has year-end shutdown, 9/80 work schedule in certain groups,
cons: Very demoralizing environment for employees; performance ratings are based on quotas, no career growth; favoritism is how staff get promoted; free-loaders get promoted and kudos while the one actually do their work get slammed with bad reviews and get stuck cleaning up the mess; many managers should not be managers, lack leadership skills and play favors to their friends and friends' kids

review_title: Cumbersome and Dishonest
job_title: Senior Middleware Tools Specialist in Linthicum, MD
pros: None, I was only given a start date
cons: The left hand doesn't know what the right is doing.   I was given a start date, submitted sensitive documents and urine sample for drug test  and back ground check which took at least a month.  I was was given starting pay and supervisor to report to and at the 12th hour they said I wasn't qualified because I didn't have 2 years full time off electronic school.   I a ttended a year full time at RETS Technologies and 5 year apprenticeship and 15 years  with Local 486, with more than adequate electronic experience working in supermarkets and process refrigeration.  The whole process took several months.  I turned down several positions because I accepted position.  This company has no empathy or common sense, so don't do it.  The pay for what they want is also inadequate.  They wanted a top notch HVAC Refrigeration mechanic.  I have a unrestricted Masters license.   I wonder about our defence industry now seeing the inadequate hiring process for good people.

review_title: Great people, but suffers from being an enormous company
pros: I can only speak for a small part (~10,000 employees) of NG.  In my experience, I worked with really great personalities on my day-to-day tasks.  This goes really far, Northrop has some terrific people.  I also feel that the workplace flexibility was terrific, specifically in the areas of flexing your time and having a good vacation accrual rate.
cons: It is a big company afraid of innovative investments.  Much of the work currently being done is a re-spin of existing programs.  You are subject to the highly uncertain congressional funding environment for the big ticket programs, which during periods of pain can mean protracted layoffs and lack of career mobility.  This is more an industry problem, rather than NG specific.

review_title: Company Leadserhip has lost its focus on the "people" side of the business
job_title: Senior Proposal Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Plenty of work to do, challenging assignments, 9/80 work schedule
cons: Leadership (CEO, Sector Presidents, HR) has forgotten that the success of the company comes through it's best people.

review_title: OK place to start a career, but look elsewhere unless you're willing to join the old boys network
pros: PDP - the professional development program is a good way to gain exposure to different parts of the company and not a bad place to start a career. Northrop is an industry leader.
cons: To move up or get into management, you pretty much have to belong to the old boys network and play golf with the movers and shakers. The work is not very challenging, at least for entry level engineers, but this depends on which group you end up. Out of 5 rotations throughout Electronic Systems as a PDP, I had consistently challenging work in maybe 1 rotation. The rest of the time, I either had not enough work, or pretty much did grunt work.

review_title: A company that only seems to reward incompetence.
job_title: Member of Technical Staff II in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: Some people like the location but it is up to the individual if they like Los Angeles.  The ability to and the support from management to allow for remote work access is a plus.
cons: The number of incompetent employees is astounding.  Countless low level employees are unable to do their jobs.  Program management is unable to recognize the lack of completed, quality work from these people.  Functional management is unable to assign quality people to the positions needing them.  How so many people can be oblivious to such a large problem is insulting to those who perform well and are expected to make up for wide spread incompetence from upper management to lowly worker.  People who actually perform well are not given the recognition they deserve.  People who fail to perform are not punished in any form.  Top performers are stuck on the same career path at the same compensation levels as people who should have never received a degree.

review_title: Good place to work if coming up  the ranks but way to many politics
job_title: Information Security Engineer in Arlington, VA
pros: Benefits are fairly competitive. A lot of opportunities if your a go-getter.  Better to start out early in your carrier.
cons: Lack of communication between business units. They throw people into management positions who are not qualified to be managers.  Still very much a lot of politics within NG than there should be.  Forget training unless your giving your own time during the day then having to make up your personal time...bad structure.

review_title: Be wary!
job_title: Systems Engineer in Newport News, VA
pros: I worked at the Newport News sector...most managers were very flexible when it comes to time off or coming in early/later.  That's what keeps a lot of folks there.  Most of the folks there are very friendly and helpful if you have any questions.
cons: Good ol' boy/girl network.  Only the ones that management likes has a chance of getting promoted, and then it is done in secret.  Very poor merit increases.  No bonus for non-management.  Even though they claim they let you go in any direction you want to go in, they are very quick to pigeonhole you into one thing.  A lot of the older folks are eligible for retirement and there will be a huge brain drain in the next few years.  On the other end, they can't keep the younger folks around b/c either they don't want to deal with the old technology or they know they will not be promoted.  Very hard to get training.

review_title: Some good things, more bad though.
pros: The company builds cool things.  Job security. Good benefits.
cons: Low pay, Lack of training and development, sometimes unprofessional atmosphere.  There is basically no training program for college hires.  I was basically given a cube and a computer and went to work.  I am still unsure exactly what it is I do.  The company needs to create a defined training program for college hires.  Class room work, group activities etc.  This will allow the new employees to not only learn required skills but also get acquainted with the company and meet other new hires. The company promised a lot during the interview process and simply did not deliver.  Also watch out for the relocation repayment agreements they will trap you.

review_title: A review by a younger employee at NG.
pros: Some of the great reasons to work here really are vast number of jobs you can take. You can easily swap from position to position within the company and never get bored. The rotation programs and leadership training programs for recent grads are both stellar opportunities to network.
cons: Due to being a defense contractor, there are some restrictions. The company tends to be rather inflexible in how you spend your hours as there is much that can be done to improve the collaborative feel to the workplace, however, that can't be done because there isn't a charge number to hit. Also, the company seems very convinced that years served is a good indicator of who should be promoted rather than accomplishments, making it hard for younger employees to move as quickly

review_title: I had excellent opportunities to work on emerging programs.
pros: Certain pockets of the company have many former military members.  Since the Department of Defense is our primary customer, this provides great insight into the 'right' solutions.  Integrity is stressed repeatedly and is an overriding ethic.  I am a man, but is seemed women were treated very fairly and given a fair chance to advance to all levels of the hierarchy.
cons: Budget approval processes are stilted and burdensome, and authority is held a too high a level in the company.  An Air Force buck seargeant has more authority for committing resources than a Director at Northrop.  Because of this many perfect business opportunities are squandered because of a lack of agility.  For a similar reason, Internal Research and Development is ill-matched to emerging opportunities.

review_title: A job for a lifetime if you can handle corporate politics
job_title: Aerospace Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Due to their size, Northrop Grumman has plenty of opportunities to make a lifetime career out of working with them.  They pay competitive rates and have locations in just about every area of the country.
cons: There are massive amounts of politics, internal struggles and even competition between divisions.  Often times there will be many different groups competing for the same work and you wind up in a war of egos.  Due to the structure of most major defense contracts, Northrop is forced to follow the model of putting "cheeks in seats" and just hiring warm bodies to fill positions rather than spending time to prune and recruit top talent.  While this makes for a diverse team, salaries are NOT based on performance and you WILL wind up doing 10x more work than someone who makes a significant amount more than you.

review_title: Training Product 2 in Sierra Vista, AZ; Technical Services
job_title: Trainin Product II in Sierra Vista, AZ
pros: The best things about working here were the benefits. The health, dental, vision, life, and 401k were some of the best I have had. When a contract dried up the management did there best to keep you employed.
cons: Management. There were entirely too many managers for each section. There were entirely too many managers/supervisors/leads in any one program. Tenured employees. These employees would be a detriment to the organization but would be allowed to stay in their current position, or be able to move laterally without being terminated. We were constantly understaffed and were recommended "required" to work long days and even weekends. They would pay overtime if the contract allowed it. Management theory on problems were that of knee jerk reaction. Good old boy system in place.

review_title: Mechanical Engineer
pros: Large Company, lots of different opportunities, flexible work hours
cons: Tuition Assistance is being capped @10k per year beginning in 2020, IF YOU PLAN TO ATTEND PART TIME GRADUATE SCHOOL, DO NOT WORK HERE.  Employees were told this 1.5 months before 2020. So if you want to get any sort of masters degree while working, be prepared that it will take 4-5 years to complete. I understand  tuition assistance is a benefit. With that established, other companies (Boeing Raytheon etc.) Offer much better tuition assistance options. Many younger employees (myself included) are very frustrated with Northrops tactics and advise younger employees to choose somewhere else if you ever think of attending graduate school.

review_title: Rewarding Career Despite Management Shortcomings.
pros:
Overall quaity of personnel.
Until recently there was a definite team spirit that prevailed in the work place.
Chance to work with the latest technology.
Company really respects employess unlike some other well-known defense contractors.
Highest level of  Integrity in all aspects of business conduct.
cons:
They (Corporate management ) keeps chasing whatever the the " Hot Business School Topic" du Jour" is.  

Walked away from being Navys main shipbuilder because of lack of "synergy" with other prodcuct lines. We build naval aircraft, electronics systems, sensors and command & control systems. No synergy??!! 
They should be positioning the company more agressively vis a vis Lockheed and Boeing.

They talk about "green this and green that"  touting paper recycling while management still balks at widespread  telecommuting or setting up distributed work locations.

review_title: The blind leading the blind.. without brail.
pros: Benefits package (flexible spending plans). Casual work environment. People are generally pretty friendly toward each other. The longterm employees cover for each other, try to find a position for each other when there is not enough work in one particular area, care about each other.
cons: Very little support from management. People are promoted whether or not qualified for a position and not provided with the support they need to be successful in their new position. It is very difficult to get manager approval for training in new technologies as well, even if no one in the group has experience using the technology. Management is not very flexible or understanding regarding the need for work and life balance. There is a lack of structured communication within the development team, with hallway conversations often setting the new direction without being communicated to the rest of the team until much later. Disfunctional.

review_title: I had high, but unmet expectations.
pros: Among aerospace and defense sector contractors, it has a dynamic and imaginative executive bench who are very strategic in thinking.  It attracts imaginative talent to work on leading edge projects.  It contributes to the well being of active duty military personnel and their families, hires veterans, has an active K-12 program in STEM education, and has created work sites in rural locations of high unemployment.
cons: Mid management ranks are in need to improvement.  Their leadership skills are weak and uninspiring at best..  Many mid-level managers have a style that is stuck mid-century,  Information is often stopped at this level and parsed out sparingly as if employees are outsiders.

review_title: I had high, but unmet expectations.
pros: Among aerospace and defense sector contractors, it has a dynamic and imaginative executive bench who are very strategic in thinking.  It attracts imaginative talent to work on leading edge projects.  It contributes to the well being of active duty military personnel and their families, hires veterans, has an active K-12 program in STEM education, and has created work sites in rural locations of high unemployment.
cons: Mid management ranks are in need to improvement.  Their leadership skills are weak and uninspiring at best..  Many mid-level managers have a style that is stuck mid-century,  Information is often stopped at this level and parsed out sparingly as if employees are outsiders.

review_title: Very interesting work if you can get it
pros:
Work was varied and  interesting. The people working there were very dedicated and aware they were providing products that would be used by the American soldier. The quality of the work saved American soldiers' lives.
One more good thing: since you needed a security clearance to work there, you didn;t need to worry about your job be outsourced offshore.
cons:
The funding levels were always fluctuating which meant that staffing levels on projects was constantly changing.  And having the US government as the sole customer was a real pain.
Having a security clearance was a burden even if you were not working on a classified project. For example, you were required to report any contact with foreign nationals --- quite the burden if you live in an area like So Cal which has a large immigrant population. Also, before you took any vacation overseas you had to fill out paperwork about your trip and itinerary down to your flight and seat assignments. And of course a detailed report when you returned.

review_title: Worst Aerospace company to work for, Management and Human Resources have no Ethics.
pros: The engineers and work force who produce are good people
cons: Management and HR are in bed together. There is Zero employee advocacy and Management alone has ruined what was once a great company to work for run by Engineers, now run by bean counters who only care about their bonuses and pockets while they strip away all benefits from employees. Human Resources is a joke, they work hand in hand with Management and if there is a problem they simply defer it and point it right back at the employee.

review_title: Both a Corporation and Defense Contracting...
job_title: Software Engineer II in Aurora, CO
pros: If you are lucky, you can work on a program that has a cool mission, since a lot of it is classified work. So it's fun stuff. Also, for a brief time, I worked with a really motivated and exciting team. Which means there are some cool people there. However, you are not guaranteed either since you get moved around from program to program depending on the needs.
cons: 1.) Heavy corporate politics, 2.) Uneducated government managers providing detrimental, inefficient oversight, 3.) Schedule, metrics, and bean counting all supersede the software engineers' input. 4.) A top heavy, un-motivated elderly population combined with an unrewarded, both by satisfaction, and by compensation (due to budget cuts), young talent results in daily cynicism from both groups of people.

review_title: Great for Early Career Development but too many proceedures and lack of great leadership makes it difficult to succeed
pros:
Dual Pension and 401k for employees that joined prior to 2010.
Lots of opportunity for driven individuals to make a difference and prove themselves.
Good comrodary at the group level.
cons:
Lack of Leadership that applies to and directs the average worker.
Too many procedures in place that limit ones effectiveness on a day to day basis.
Average raise is 2-4%, a great raise is 4%, so it is very hard to climb faster than others in salary
No raises given for earning a Masters if earned while working at Northrop Grumman

review_title: Fails to see the value in their biggest asset, their employees
pros: May allow flexible work arrangements
cons: This company has changed direction in the last few years. It's no longer a place an employee can see themselves at for the long term. They don't value employee development and retention as they did in the past as evidenced by declining benefits and a lack of effort to retain some of the best and most knowledgeable people the have hired. The senior management has a lack of respect for the professional knowledge that most employees have built years acquiring, and seems determined on micromanaging all aspects of their employees jobs even though management many times lacks the skills to do those jobs themselves. Don't get me wrong here, it's a good place to come into for a short time to build your resume, just don't plan on staying.

review_title: Not great, could be worse
job_title: Systems Engineer IV in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros: NG is very flexible with schedules.  There are core hours, but as long as you cover those you can arrange your schedule to suit your life.  I work early hours to avoid traffic, and I know a lot of younger employees that work late hours so they can go straight to the clubs and bars after work and still have time to sleep before coming in the next day.
cons: The HR department will do everything they can to under pay you when you start and once they do the only way to catch back up is to leave the company.  If you are thinking of hiring in, don't believe them if they say that the pay the first year will be low, but that raises come quickly.  It is simply a lie.

review_title: Overall a good place to work.
job_title: QA and Performance/Robustness Engineer in Fort Collins, CO
pros: Interesting people and a wide variety of opportunities. My colleagues were bright, hard working and they didn't mind taking some time and helping a newbie. Overall the all the environment was a pleasant one.
cons: The management crew that I had to dealt with were seriously "integrity challenged". I've never been misled and lied to as much in my entire career. There were a lot of broken promises made and outright lies told. When the director flew in to see why the employee morale was so low at this site she told us that the upper-level manager was in the process of being "re-trained" after a debacle at her former site where the employees threatened to walk out. . The training didn't take unfortunately. Northrup Grumman itself is a great company but there are places with NG that you do not want to go to.

review_title: What is Northrop?
job_title: Cost & Schedule Analyst I  in San Diego, CA
pros:
One great thing about Northrop is that we have a 9/80 shcedule which allows us to have every other Friday off. Also, we have a shut down at Christmas and we don't have to use our vacation.

We also have some cool Employee Resource Groups such as Connect1NG.
cons: Unfortunatley there are way more cons than there are Pros. What is especially dissapointing about NGC is the management. There are many worthless managers here who have no idea how to treat people, they've gotten to where they are by riding the coat-tails of others. Having said that, I guess it's just like every other company. They tell you one thing and do another. Believe half of what you see and nothing of what you hear.

review_title: Company Culture Update Needed to Ensure a Bright Future
pros: Work-life balance is generally good with most working a 9/80 schedule (every other Friday off).  Many opportunities to move laterally if you want experience in multiple business roles.  Opportunities exist for challenging/complex projects and roles.  Matrix environment presents excellent opportunity for cross-functional learning.
cons: Promotions are very difficult to achieve, both in-place and to management. Workplace diversity is painfully low.  Younger employees are difficult to retain because the company culture hasn't kept up with the times.  Merit increases have been very low for several years (0%-3%, generally).  Reorganizations and executive management changes are almost constant and executives just get recycled to different/newly created management roles.

review_title: Not Recommended
pros:
Definite job security
9/80 work schedule
cons:
Underpaid, despite always receiving excellent performance review
Always did work above my pay grade
Lack of diversity, especially in management
So manager tried to make me work overtime without pay
Major issues with nepotism 
Too many conflicts of interest within hiring, half of the workforce is related or longtime friends. I saw instances where internships were going to undeserving children of management, rather actual talented students!

My advice to minority &/or women: take your talent elsewhere

review_title: Buyer beware
pros: The once a year layoffs (2010-2015ish) have stopped, stable long term employment.
cons: Steady reduction in benefits (pto,  credit hours, health care in years past)  continues with a new, no exceptions cap on tuition reimbursement. Currently enrolled employees had this sprung on them with just 2 months notice. Combined with the policy that if you leave the company, you must pay back 2 years of tuition, this leaves current students who are unable to cover their tuition with the options of finding another company willing to cover those two years as a signing bonus or simply abandoning their degree and riding out those two years at NG.

review_title: It is what you make it.
job_title: Project Management I in Redondo Beach, CA
pros:
We live, work, and play super close to the beach.

The salary let's you live reasonably well, just watch those non-discretionary bills like happy hours, cable/internet, and of course: eating out.

Northrop Grumman has been around for many years, and has acquired numerous companies throughout it's history: One day you're working with a new grad, the next you're with someone who built a Space Shuttle in Palmdale, or a military test pilot from New York!  

There is no shortage of uber-smart people around.
cons:
Huge age gap, which the entire Aerospace/defense industry is trying to address before it becomes dire.

There's still people printing documents, signing them, scanning them, and then sending it thru email - we build satellites for Pete's sake!

The cute girls are few and far between - you can check out the beach/soccer mom's in Manhattan Beach though!

review_title: Good work-life balance, but very slow moving, defense cutbacks limit opportunities
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Good work-life balance. Good benefits. Some projects use interesting technologies you would probably not see elsewhere. You get exposed to some classic aerospace projects. The diversity of technologies on a single project (aerospace, mechanical, electronics, software, etc.) is hard to match. Friendly people. Reasonably good training opportunities. Good place for a long career if projects live on.
cons: Very slow moving, risk adverse, at the mercy of government budget cuts, inefficient, prone to over-engineering of products. Although they try to promote entrepreneurship from the grass roots, in practice it doesn't happen the way it does in non-government industries. On existing projects some technologies are decades old. Technology tools are also very old. Shoestring budgets limit innovation.

review_title: Good Company but hard to move up from Entry Level
job_title: Manufacturing Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Interesting Work, 9/80 Schedule makes for great work life balance, Good salary pay but no bonuses. Lots of career opportunities for mid Career employees.
cons: HR dictates all Raises and Promotions for Entry Level employees and makes them very difficult to come by. Seems like the only way to get promoted out of entry level is leave company and come back in 3-4 years. No bonuses so can be demotivating that hard work isn't compensated for unless you get a promotion as everyone gets the same satisfactory rating and merit increase every year.

review_title: If possible, work somewhere else.
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Aurora, CO
pros: It's better than being unemployed.
cons: They are myopic, old school, non-competitive, and aspire to mediocrity at best.  Management is often ill trained and unskilled at seeing the big picture.  They tend to be penny wise and pound foolish relative to compensation and talent retention.  The work is agonizingly boring, especially if you have even a glint of intellect or ambition, and they treat $500 bonuses as though they have handed you world peace with a side of perpetual health and youth.  It is a pathetic culture best suited to lobotomized trons.

review_title: Northrop Grumman - Good, not Great
pros: I work with a great group of people; our on-site management promotes work-life balance; compensation plan is OK, but it keeps getting whittled down... medical and dental coverage  costs have gone up considerably in the last few years, salary increases are limited and usually occur only as annual bump-ups of about 2%.
cons:
Upper management verbally promotes career advancement opportunities, but I have applied to numerous internal opportunities in an effort to advance, to no avail. I have received "Constantly Exceeds Expectations" ratings every year I have worked for the company; I completed the NG Technical Professional Mentorship Program; I take on challenges outside my job description, at no additional pay/compensation... Career advancement internal to the company is not reality.

New employees no longer qualify for Retirement Account Contributions.

review_title: Good Cop Bad Cop
pros: The people doing the work are friendly & knowledgeable. Many opportunities if you are favored by management. New bomber program hows promise.
cons: One sector is leaderless & lacking in vision and direction. Very controlling & sexist management who favored men over woman to avoid any competition or revealing of inadequate leadership ability.  No competing edge or leading technology. A  high level director actually told  men of a certain age to consider an exit strategy.  Lots of energy on employee engagement but never implement changes, just a check mark to say to "the street" they are diverse & inclusive. Senior leaders are verbally abusive & bait negative conversations about middle management & then publicly they praise them - schizophrenic & unprofessional. Must play mother-may-I  to have discussions with key clients even when you have a better relationship than the senior leaders responsible for relationship management.

review_title: Extremely poor management and job environment at NG in Boulder CO
pros: Boulder Living is really great but...
cons: As a senior engineer with decades of experience in the space industry, I was given minimal tasking well below my experience level and was treated extremely poorly by the management.  There was very little trust given to employees. Performance of many significant tasks went unrecognized; asking not to work on certain projects led to suspicion and professional consequences.  Pointing out your strengths only ensured that you would not have a chance to do related tasks.  So called secure jobs would just vanish at the end of the year. Witnessed mass exodus and a poor business base.  Promises during the interview of quick and easy advancement were completely untrue. Very poor experience overall - I would call that the bottom of the barrel for my career for sure!  You should really consider other options instead of going there unless you are really desperate for work.

review_title: Aerospace status quo and nothing more
job_title: Mechanical Engineer III in San Diego, CA
pros: Flexible working hours and the 9/80 schedule are great! Very little if or no unpaid overtime expected. Paltry funded employee resource groups (better than no resource groups).
cons: No pension, increased heath care costs every year with fewer benefits, no free gyms to use, salaried employees are made to clock in and out like hourly employees (and paid in the same fashion), fewer vacation days every year to meet what they call "industry standards" and no more bonuses or employee appreciation days to save money. No money for training or resources. They create programs to profit off employee's good ideas without providing any incentive to the employee. If you want a promotion/raise they tell you to get a job offer from another company first no matter how good you performance reviews are.

review_title: Aerospace status quo and nothing more
job_title: Mechanical Engineer III in San Diego, CA
pros: Flexible working hours and the 9/80 schedule are great! Very little if or no unpaid overtime expected. Paltry funded employee resource groups (better than no resource groups).
cons: No pension, increased heath care costs every year with fewer benefits, no free gyms to use, salaried employees are made to clock in and out like hourly employees (and paid in the same fashion), fewer vacation days every year to meet what they call "industry standards" and no more bonuses or employee appreciation days to save money. No money for training or resources. They create programs to profit off employee's good ideas without providing any incentive to the employee. If you want a promotion/raise they tell you to get a job offer from another company first no matter how good you performance reviews are.

review_title: Industrial Engineer
job_title: Manufacturing Engineer II in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Like any job you get what you put into it. Many people that I have heard complain dont put the effort in to get to their ultimate career goal. I have had a great manager that has been excellent with me. Ask for stretch assignments and there is a chance you will get that opportunity down the line. 9/80 schedule is awesome.
cons: Get rid of all the dead weight. A good chunk of employees are on cruise control and management is always slow to get rid of the lazy people. They hate laying off employees unless its on a mass layoff basis. Any other company would immediately get rid of  these people immediately if there is no work or they are not performing. In all departments i have seen its only 1 or 2 employees holding the whole department together. Lets get the 4/10 schedule going!

review_title: Low Morale caused by poor management and lack of direction, training
pros: Good balance of experience across all levels, products, company ethics
cons: Management/leadership training is weak at this company at all levels compared to other company management/leadership training. HR and some program/product team managers have the attitude with new/newer employees of it's the Northrop way or the highway. These managers often do not provide direction or training assistance, rewards, interactions, or good performance ratings with the exception of favored long term employees, which has caused a lot of anxiety, low morale and commitment issues with employees of <5 yrs. Newer employees are scared away and if not already gone, may be planning to.

review_title: Program Manager
pros: Infusion of new, young talent has been invigorating to the company.  Most of the employees are motivated to do a good job and most teams have a driven personality to accomplish the stated goals of the team(s).
cons: Upper management has taken to being more concerned about short term shareholder value and the sector/business areas goals are significantly slanted to that.  The new business philosophy has  put a strain on the relationship between the company and their customer(s).  Although the young talent has been invigorating to the business, upper management wants those younger employees to become the managers now and replace the older managers (read more expensive but certainly more experienced) to the detriment of the projects/programs involved.

review_title: '24' meets 'Dilbert'
job_title: Software Engineer II in Aurora, CO
pros: Several locations and programs allows you to choose from a diverse and exciting set of technical areas in which to work, Northrop offers good raises to young, high performing engineers and a good 401k match.
cons:
It all depends on which program you work on.  Some are very slow and bureaucratic and do not have easy internet access - a nightmare for a young engineers who want to stay current.  If you are not careful, you could become obsolete if you stay on a program like this.  

Do not expect many perks.  No profit sharing, stock options, or bonuses unless you are an executive.  No free coffee, drinks, etc.  Northrop doesn't like these 'overhead' costs.

Offices and facilities I have seen are very bland, sterile, and do not encourage creativity and innovation; this is not a place where I could easily work overtime.

review_title: One of the better and calmer places I've worked.
pros:
Management is clear about my assignments and makes sure I have things to do, as opposed to some companies who think it's my job to find work for myself.

The work is what I expected and on target.

Everyone has been very friendly here, no attitudes, no BS.

The cubicle is fairly large and the office is quiet.

I was able to get a faulty keyboard replaced easily.

I can work from home as needed or take time off even with little warning.

Though I'm a consultant, I was invited to the holiday party with my wife.
cons: The guards are very overzealous about seeing badges, to the point that a guard checks my badge while I'm entering the internal cafeteria, and then the same guy stops me on the way out to check it again, like I got fired at the sandwich counter or something.

review_title: Disappointed Engineer
job_title: Senior Network Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Challenging projects with exciting emerging technology in Aerospace to work on. Fairly competitive salaries and a 9/80 work week to give you those much needed 3 day weekends.
cons: Management seems clueless about why the projects are constantly behind schedule and over budget. The suggestions of the engineers working on the projects are sometimes met with a "shoot the messenger" response. Hard to promote unless you know somebody up high in the food chain. Raises are small and you have to be Superman on Steroids to get rated anything higher then "3" or average on you performance review.

review_title: Age Discrimination is BLATANT!
pros: It's difficult to give a positive review to a company that lacks understanding of their employees.  Employees want to make a difference, but there are too many roadblocks for advancement for the baby boomers.
cons: Upper management is driven by productivity to achieve their financial bonuses.  Worker bees are told there's no money for raises.  Benefits are cut across the board.

review_title: Strong, stable company with interesting projects
pros: The business is very stable in economic downturns and is currently growing at an incredible rate. Employees are offered several flexibile work hour plans with additional flexibily in the day to day schedule. There are a host of interesting and technically challenging projects and currently a lot of growth opportunities. A wonderful mentoring program is available for younger engineers, pairing each with a manager or senior engineer in a different department.
cons: Not much, really... but the local facility is quite out of date and there could certainly be better recognition for high quality work beyond just annual awards for a few at each site.

review_title: Shipbuilding is dirty, a little dangerous, and really fascinating.
pros: NGSS is one of the few real manufacturing opportunities left in the US.  Unions did not have the yard completely locked up so there was opportunity for contract labor, which allowed working as a welder or shipfitter without having to commit to a lifelong lockin to the boilermakers union.  They were amenable to some work flexability, e.g. the yard went to 4 ten hour days before I left.
cons: No benefits (unless you paid for them yourself), questionable work safety, very little opportunity for feeback or input at the labor level.

review_title: Tired
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Town, ND
pros: All the Overtime you can want.  Friendly work environment.  Indoor work.
cons: Advertise for a 4-10 work week but when you show up you get forced Overtime.  Plant has been on overtime for ten plus years now.  Also, advertise a sign on bonus of $1000 which is hidden behind so much red tape you can never qualify for it.  Better hope you never have a problem with management because HR will cover for them.

review_title: Hurry up and wait
pros: It's a very large company and there are a lot of perks and benefits that they offer but overall they will cost you some but not as much as if you weren't here.. Co workers are good and the work is nice.
cons: I've just been really beaten down by the raises and promotions part of things.. I've worked really hard and in the last 2 years received 1 raise and because I started at a lower wage than what I should be making it was a small raise.. How am I suppose to support a family in la on these low wages and even at that when I work really hard not be able to achieve a good raise

review_title: Northrop Grumman is a decent company to work for until retirement, but managers need to reward the best.
pros: Decent pay and average benefits. If you're looking for a good, average company, Northrop Grumman is fair. They have several sectors; so, if you wanted to, you could find a job somewhere. You just may have to look for a few months to find the one that matches exactly what you're looking for.
cons: You can be the best worker at a site, but still get treated like the worst. They try to treat everyone the same, I guess because of lawsuits and all of this ethics training, but some workers need to be told they're slacking. They need to reward the hardest workers better in order to keep the best.

review_title: Satisfaction level highly dependent on your location and management.
job_title: Test Engineer in El Segundo, CA
pros: The company is still producing some amazing air vehicles and is becoming proficient in other areas as well.  Working here definitely provides the opportunity to collaborate on products that will benefit many people with a positive impact on their lives.
cons:
The goal of "affordability" seems to be the only consideration, and employee morale is suffering because of it.  For example, the day after Thanksgiving and Christmas Eve are no longer holidays, and while that saves the company money, disgruntled employees will inevitably work less efficiently, thereby costing the company more money in the long run.

I think it'll be a better place to work for when the current generation of managers retire.

review_title: Not interested in employees trust or well being
pros: Get to see some cool stuff but ultimately, an aerospace company here to serve stake holders
cons: Cut benefits to their education program mid school year with less than 2 months notice to find funding elsewhere. Then held a webinar where they failed to see how severely this impacts their employees. Regardless if you were in a approved graduate program you are now limited to 10k/yr which covers about 2 courses. It’ll take something like 8 years to complete a MS at that rate. Also still trying to enforce the 2 year retention liability if you took any sort of assistance even if you drop out cause you can no longer afford school with the NG backing. I would expect there will be some legal issues coming soon. Pulling a bait and switch on your own employees is not a good look.

review_title: Run don't walk
job_title: Data Management Analyst in Irving, TX
pros: People are good and typically work/life balance is good.  9/80 work weeks are nice and some positions can telecommute 1 day and sometimes up to 3 days per week.
cons:
Leadership is where this company fails. Lack of direction and ability to drive objectives by the managers and directors is the biggest failure. It makes the job less desirable. 

Pay is also on the low end of the spectrum. Their recruits oversell you on all of the benefits and when you actually get into the role you realize the benefits they spoke of aren't available.

I have been with NGC for 2 years now and I have to say I have never seen a more ill equipped management group. If the company had good leaders it would be one of the best jobs in Dallas despite the inadequacy of the pay.

review_title: Stable job, chill environment
job_title: Communication Systems Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: The defense industry seems very stable, and my area keeps on hiring.  My job is fairly relaxing, and I enjoy working with most of the other engineers.  People are fairly laid back here.  Hours are fair, haven't had to work much overtime at all.
cons: At the area I'm at, there is no electronics design work.  As an integrator, we subcontract out all electronics work to other companies, and then put them together.  So, if you're looking to do some real design, this is the wrong place to look.  Information gathering is very infefficient as well, but that might just be a characteristic of a large company.

review_title: Losing the balance of employee and customer satisfaction
pros:
Great Benefits Package
Networking
Career Development
Great people
cons:
Decisions are made at such a high level and pushed down without much feedback from the technical employees.
During the last round of layoffs an announcement went out to let everyone know that they will try to relocate people into other positions prior to letting them go, overall this did not happen
The company says they support diversity groups, but the support is minimal other than accepting and encouraging groups to exist.
The pay is not very competitive.
Recognition from achievement varies based on the lead's interest in recognizing achievement.
Process is claimed to be important, but usually disregarded for a more reactive approach

review_title: Opportunity to learn and grow while working with some of the best professional experience in the world
job_title: Team Lead/Lead Mechanic in Fort Irwin, CA
pros: Great work models, pay, benefits, time off, regular opportunities to advance, opportunities to transfer to other work sites or cross-train into another field, full open-door policy all the way up to the top.
cons: Little supervision on some sites, union biases from supervisors at times, difficult work conditions (rain or shine the work gets done), and often the work is done outdoors regardless of the climate conditions (cold, hot, wind, sand, and humidity- doesn’t matter), pay generally compensates for difficulty, though the “military mentality” is the general culture where some may find this kind of environment difficult to work in.

review_title: I have a great boss who supports me and I have been able to work on many interesting projects.
pros: Northrop Grumman is a very large company, but it has sites which are both huge as well as tiny that are involved in many different things.  You can move around and try different things and see what fits you best.  I also like that they offer an optional brokerage window as part of their 401K which allows you to choose your own investments.
cons: Some NG sites are unionized (not engineering), which if you are a hands on kind of engineer, can be extremely aggravating.  i have never worked at one of NG's unionized sites so I do not have personal experience at NG with their unions, but I have worked at a different company that had unionized labor before and it was a substantial annoyance.  Picking up a soldering iron could get you a union grievance filed against you.

review_title: Positive experience 1st part of 21st century. Challenging morale environment past 5-years since onset of sequestration.
job_title: Exempt Non Officer in San Diego, CA
pros: Fullfilling employment and educational opportunities. Company appears to protect it's direct employees from reductions in force while optimizing its performance in an affordability focused environment. Shareholders are happy, stock is way up, cutting edge technologies suggest much promise.
cons: Recent Center of Excellence transitions derailed many career paths (similar to strategic realignments and downsizing experienced during corporate mergers & acquisitions). Resuting disenchantment, frustration, and fear of being exiled by the new guard has badly damaged morale. Affordability focused environment threatens quality for sake of cost and schedule.

review_title: Good Benefits, And They Treat You Pretty Well
job_title: Electrical Engineer in Redondo Beach, CA
pros:
I worked here (Space Park, Redondo Beach) for most of 1995 to 2017 (originally it was TRW, bought by Northrop Grumman in 2002). To this day, I still think the benefits are very good; there are many choices for medical, everything from premium PPOs to HMOs to opting out entirely (which some people do if their significant other has better benefits through another employer). Sure, it's probably not as generous as it was back in the 1990s, but where is that true today?

Also, management always treated me pretty well, and there was always some emphasis on life/work balance - some people took that more seriously than others, but if you weren't obsessed with rapidly shooting up the corporate ladder, it was always acceptable to have other priorities besides just work. And with a company this size, there were a lot of different opportunities, so I never got stuck in the exact same role for years on end.
cons: I was in satellites, and ever since Northrop bought the company in 2002, I've noticed a slow decline in the space side of the business (in favor of the much larger aircraft side). There are many more opportunities in aircraft these days, and I started to  get the sense that corporate management wasn't all that interested in winning a lot of new space business anymore (just not nearly as much $$$ to be made as there is in military aircraft). So if you're interested in the space side of things, opportunities here seem to be much more limited than they were 12-20 years ago.

review_title: Good potential company
job_title: Associate Systems Engineer in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: Job security, many younger people joining my team, very fun to work with
cons: Promotions are slow and very "years based" and you really need to push hard for it.

review_title: Northrop Grumman is a Good Company for Engineers
pros:
- Pretty easy to stand out
- Lots of career opportunities 
- Very good locations
- Excellent work/life balance (not much night shift)
- It's pretty hard to lose your job there
- Bleeding Edge product offerings
cons:
- Way too many layers of management
- Way too many managers at each level
- Management Oversight is too high on contract proposals; NG can't compete well as a result
- Transferring out of a department is difficult if you don't have someone pulling you
- It's better to look good than to be good
- Raises are the same whether you're Extremely Effective or Extremely Ineffective
- They lag upgrading personal workstations (For instance, I was upgraded from Windows 95 to Windows 2000 long after Windows XP was available)

review_title: Review of company after working 20+ years at NG
job_title: Engineering SpecialistConfiguration Analyst/Gen Ops Svc Representative in San Diego, CA
pros: Work/Life Balance, Flex Hours, Compensation.  Was an work environment that never became stale.  Great support for furthering your education and great tuition reimbursement program.
cons: On a project that was downsizing.  Every time on person got laid off, the remaining people had to pick up all the slack.  When the 2nd phase of layoffs occurred, those of us that remained on the project were expected to do 2-3 peoples work in our normal work week.  Very stressful environment and was like walking on pins and needles every day.

review_title: Flying into disaster
pros: In general, my coworkers are dedicated, and personable.  Free parking.
cons: Workloads are highly varied, and not recognized by management.  Bonuses were eliminated for all but management and the most senior employees in 2014.  Pay increase pools were in the 1-2% range for the last 4 years.  At the same time, open positions go unfilled because qualified people with a security clearance are a limited resource.  Morale is low as measured by corporate employee surveys, but there is no effort to correct the driving causes (low pay and excessive workload).  I've worked on average 400 hours of overtime for three years, which is incongruous with a token insulting pay raise.   Shareholder value is increasing geometrically, but with such low morale, expect that to be a short term spike.

review_title: Not a Company to grow with
job_title: Engineering Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Smart people, some leading edge technology if you're into aerospace/unmanned technology, 9/80 is nice when you can take advantage of it.
cons: SW development stuck in the 70's, old school mentality due to leadership being ex-military.  They just want people to salute and march to their orders.  There's no such thing as an enlightened discussion about other available options.  Pay and benefits for the basic worker does not match the typical tech company.  HR seems to think that salaries and benefits from the NW or MW are the benchmark for SoCal.  Continuos organizational changes.  As soon as a reorg occurs some new VP comes in and changes everything.  After a few of these you're not sure who's running what.

review_title: Not for the feint of heart...
pros: People are nice, I guess... If you want a really really easy job and have no ambition then this is great...
cons:
Innovation seems to be unwanted. Much of the time, one is handed 'legacy' code and expected to 'make it work'. No QA whatsoever, almost no standards, very much so an ad hoc culture.

It seems as though they have taken processes that may work for other industries and just applied it as a  'blanket' to everything. 

Benefits and pay are subpar for national average. 5/7 to be exact... 

Would not recommend. If you are a Software Engineer this is not for you, they will not let 'engineer' solutions, instead you will be asked to fix the borders on a table and be given code that does not compile. If you are a programmer and just want to program then maybe, but beware.

review_title: Overall it has been a good company to work for.
pros: Having worked here for over 5 years. This company is involved in some very interesting government projects. Many of the people are great to work with and the workforce is very diverse. And they offer very good compensation packages and a 9/80 work schedule.
cons: The politics at some levels of management is more than it should be and its top heavy in areas  Sometimes commitments are not realistic with customers, even though we need to work in the shrinking defense budgets. We need to be smarter, It takes long time to get things done. Its not that easy to move into other departments if you desire.

review_title: The work is fun and challenging, but management seems to take every possible step to kill the joy.
job_title: Engineer IV in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: The people here are first rate. Many of my colleagues are intelligent and driven, making the tackling of projects just a wonderful challenge to be overcome. There is great satisfaction in finding and delivering a solution to an engineering problem. I love how much there is to learn.
cons: The rules and structures that upper management puts in place makes life difficult for those of us that wants to do our job well. it feels like they are working against us rather than enabling the engineers to do the best job possible.

review_title: Good.
job_title: Senior Engineer in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: Interesting work. Some challenging issues. Some non-government related work that is of greater interest than the old systems sponsored through the military.
cons: Benefits diminishing by the day. Pension plan has been cancelled.  Harder and harder to make a livable wage as pay increases are almost non existent, and taxes, fee's, and state and federal issues far exceed any monetary gain made (especially for the area in which we work, i.e. Redondo Beach, CA - wish they'd relocate to Texas).  Can't really get ahead anymore.  Salaried employee's tend to be worked to death without any additional monetary compensation.  These are not really complaints as it is the same everywhere in the bigger aerospace companies (I've worked for them all at some time or another throughout my career).

review_title: Good time while it lasted, but then the world went to poop
job_title: Advisory Engineer in Linthicum Heights, MD
pros: Many high-tech programs.  Used to be good benefits (going downhill).  Many opportunities to find out "what you want to be when you grow up - but you must look for them to find them
cons:
Management is strictly out for its own.  Functional management (generally speaking) does not do a good job looking out for their people.  Program management tends to treat people poorly.  When things go wrong, they blame others loudly.  When things go well, they are short of praise.

One of the reasons I left was because other managers told me that I would not succeed in a management path, because I was the wrong sex/color.  How can I keep working for a place that's told me that?

review_title: Space Technology allows a healthy work-life balance
job_title: Product Engineer in Manhattan Beach, CA
pros: Space Park has a flexible work schedule. The 9/80 schedule means employees work 80 hours over 9 working days instead of the standard 10 days. This allows every other Friday to be an off-Friday giving employees 3-day weekends every other weekend. Also, there is an option to telework on a regular, part-time, or ad-hoc basis. Everyone is allowed to telework if their job responsibilities can still be performed and they have manager approval.
cons: Northrop Grumman is a big company so it has the big company mentality. In terms of engineering, there is a focus on modifying successful designs from the past rather than creating new, innovative designs for the future.

review_title: Outstanding company that invests in its people
job_title: Technical Project Manager V in New York, NY
pros: CMMI 5 company with a focus on integrity.  Tons of training and development opportunities.  Most benefits are excellent.
cons: The company takes on some of the toughest challenges in the world which can leave some folks overwhelmed.  You really have to take initiative to get caught up or it is easy to get left behind.  Tuition assistance is a little anemic.  You have to be well rounded to get recognition (i.e. A genius engineer who is weak in presentation skills is likely to get an average rating even if the program would collapse without them).  If you are not willing to relocate at the end of a program, it can be tough to advance your career.

review_title: Former HR and now consultant
pros: It took me 9 years to get one of the best people leaders of all time outside of HR.  I've received a retention bonus for the last 5 years intermittently.
cons: I would imagine it happens everywhere, but once a woman becomes a certain age, the environment gets a little hostile.  I'm not talking about harassment, but simply task assignment mis-match.  Recently one of my mentors was given very short notice that she should retire.  It broke my heart.  I'm making plans now to implement my exit strategy before I'm asked to leave and really thought that I would retire here.  Probably sounds familiar, but it's disappointing that you see this much more with women.

review_title: Corrupt and Retaliatory Company
job_title: Systems Engineer/Architect in Bwi Airport, MD
pros: Good work! if in good group!
cons:
