Very corrupt management! Security Officers abuse employees.  They will accidentally put things in your JPAS entry so you cannot leave.  They will communicate to other SSOs to prevent you from getting another job!

Management is very retaliatory!  Northrop touts you can change positions etc. but reality is if you try and leave the management and HR will retaliate against you!    Management and Executives are making up all this ethical company crap!  

Take a good look at number of lawsuits Northrop has for double billing government agencies.   Worked on six projects in five years and every single project got sued for double billing the government.  It really is pathetic that a large company like Northrop is only successful due to its dishonest illegal manipulation of labor.  Note: Definition of Organized crime is the illegal manipulation of labor!

Anybody going to hire into Northrop should read a book called A just Cause.

review_title: Wonderful place to work and gain real world, fast paced experience.
job_title: Manager, Information Security in McLean, VA
pros: Variety of opportunity. NG openly encourages employees to seek other internal opportunities. They would much rather see employees move into new positions rather than lose excellent talent. With multiple operating sectors, opportunities abound. NG is very open about flexible work arrangements and telecommuting; however, visibility in this large organization is very important, therefore it is best to consider working within a physical location when possible.
cons: Very large global organization and very "matrixed". There is definitely an adjustment/learning period everyone must consider just to understand all the services/lines of business, and how all the moving parts interrelate. Depending on what the role is and where the job function resides (internally facing vs. external/customer facing) this will impact training and learning opportunities. As with any large government contracting agency, job security can be a factor because the large amount of government contractual type of business.

review_title: Used to be a good place to work
pros: There is work to do, but not too much 'cutting edge' stuff.  Benefits are nothing to cheer about, but at least they offer them.
cons: There are plenty of 'jobs' listed in the internal website, but they appear to be written for a specific person when posted.  Rarely do you get any feedback when you are no longer considered for a position.  In an effort to be more competitive (standard line from upper management), benefits have been cut back in an effort to make NGC more affordable.

review_title: NG not bad for defense work.
job_title: Software Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Stability, benefits, and salary are all very nice.  It's a great first job for any engineer.  Rotational assignments are a possibility when starting as well.  There are a myriad of different job types, job locations, and people that you will work with at NG.  Chances are, you'll find your niche while working there.  The work environment is minimally stressful as well.  Defense schedules are generally more drawn out and forgiving then private industry engineering.  The work/life balance is quality as well as NG allows for a 9/80 schedule and very flexible work hours (depending on your immediate manager).  Benefits, vacation, etc. are all comparable to other defense contractors.
cons: Morally, you are part of the enormous war-making machine that is the defense industry.  Also, at a company the size of NG, feeling like an employee number is typical.

review_title: Northrop Grumman, Not a bad place to work if money isn't the most important to you.
job_title: Quality Assurance Analyst in Carson, CA
pros: Working for a large corporation has been good to me.  I feel a sense of security, I have benefits and a decent work-life balance.  Sometimes I think that in defense contracting, there are limits for younger employees.  There are many  forty and fifty year-olds making the management decisions.  I think communication is not always effective, where office gossip provides more information than you'll hear from management.  There are no bonuses or commissions that are earned when one is a full-time, salaried employee.  It's nice to get tuition reimbursement, though its at the rate of the Cal State Universities.  If you go to a private school, count on paying most of the cost yourself.
cons: I don't think the pay is where it should be.

review_title: Northrop Grumman, Not a bad place to work if money isn't the most important to you.
job_title: Quality Assurance Analyst in Carson, CA
pros: Working for a large corporation has been good to me.  I feel a sense of security, I have benefits and a decent work-life balance.  Sometimes I think that in defense contracting, there are limits for younger employees.  There are many  forty and fifty year-olds making the management decisions.  I think communication is not always effective, where office gossip provides more information than you'll hear from management.  There are no bonuses or commissions that are earned when one is a full-time, salaried employee.  It's nice to get tuition reimbursement, though its at the rate of the Cal State Universities.  If you go to a private school, count on paying most of the cost yourself.
cons: I don't think the pay is where it should be.

review_title: Falling into crisis and out of business.
pros: Decent work environment. Friendly people.
cons: Poor management with limited techinical knowledge, poor leadership skils and training are making it very dificult for NGSB-GC to incorporate the necessary changes into its corporate coulture to produce high quality ships on schedule and within budget. Things NGSB-GC must do if it is to survive.

review_title: High School All Over Again
pros: Pay was better than average for the area (I was scouted from another company, so pay was a little higher than some coworkers), the benefits and time off were good
cons: Treated like a high school kid. Was actually told that we had to send emails to management to go to the restroom. NO opportunity for advancement. It was a job, not a career position. Complicated reference process means there is no way to verify I have worked there. No information shared from other parts of company, a change would already have been implemented and we wouldn't know about it. Favoritism runs rampant, if you went to school with the right manager, you would be just fine.

review_title: Not a company for millenials
pros: Surrounded by tons of technical experts in their fields; you can learn a lot if you make an effort. 9/80 schedule is nice. We won the bomber contract, so lots of work will be coming through
cons: The average age at the company hovers around 48, but there are many people well over retirement age still working there. Some of these people are helpful and have a lot of knowledge to learn from, but the majority that I personally have interacted with are racist, sexist, and resistant to change. Not much gets done around here, and people hoard work because it comes in waves, and you always have to have a charge number. Moving up within the company takes a long time

review_title: Bad culture, ancient technology, poor infrastructure, poor management, no career trajectory
pros:
-Off Fridays!
-Can flex your work time 
-People are generally nice
-Pace of work is slow and mostly low pressure
-Lots of young people bringing in new energy
cons:
-Lots of employee turnover in engineering

-Benefits are really lacking (terrible medical plans, avg. 401k, very restricting educational assistance, almost zero company perks, etc.)

-Company morale is extremely low 

-Minimal pay increases and small competitive bonuses are not incentivizing

-Poor mentoring and training for new engineers and technicians - not a learning culture

-Training budget got eliminated 

-Very slow promotions and career growth for most. There is no transparency in career path and salary.

-Over hired engineers in 2017 and people got shifted into places they were not hired for

-Management communications are not transparent and the employee surveys are a big joke instead of development opportunities

review_title: NG is a great place to work -entry, mid, or senior level
pros:
- Time off / flexible schedule -- flex time, telecommuting, 9/80 workweek, paid time off program
- Opportunities for growth and learning - through new assignments, lateral transfers, and promotions
- Sense of accomplishment and Contributing to the mission
- Company makes an effort to communicate with employees/Most management seems to really care about the people
cons:
- Realignment(s) and changing leadership
- Company effort to migrate all parts of Northrop to common systems and processes after all the acquisitions - it's the right thing to do and will be worth it once it's done, it's just painful in the meantime

review_title: Not a bad place to work for, just not great.
pros: Good benefits, relaxed work environment, reasonable tasking.  The team environment is pretty good but the recognition of staffing capabilities doesn't exist.  The company absorbed multiple smaller corporations and is still absorbing the multiple cultures.  They are really trying but they are just not in good touch with their staff.
cons: no career ladder, management unaware of technical capabilities of staff,  crisis management of staff,Communication is management speaking to the technical staff.   There is excellent talent within the corporation but there is little attempt to take advantage of previous or current skills.  Technical talent is considered interchangeable without considering positive or negative skills.

review_title: A solid choice for an employer, but their are better opportunities
pros: Job security is high and the benefits are great.  A majority of the managers are nearing retirement, so if you're looking for promotion potential, you've found it here.  They are pushing many new initiatives to obtain a better work / life balance.  An example would be a 9 / 80 program in which an employee may work 80 hours in 9 days, given them a day off ever other week.
cons: A majority of the senior managers are nearing retirement.  As can be expected, their managerial styles are very conventional, which is less attractive to newer employees.  For example, my boss seems to place too much of an emphasis on ensuring that employees arrive at a certain time, and depart at a certain time.

review_title: It was great at first but they sure do not know how to cut cost the right way.
job_title: Telecom Tech, IT in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros:
If you have the time then taking time off is very easy
In IT you do what needs to get done then relax the rest of the time due to lack of management
cons:
When I was first hired it was great but now with them saving money they have no idea what they are doing.
In IT they have cut all middle management out so no way to advance in IT.
No communication with management due to my manager not even being in the same state as me.
No encouragement of growth, leaning, or advancement in any aspect of your job.
You are an ant. You have one goal, to stay alive. You fight to show your worth something and have no friends here. 
You are a high up rich manager or a low end heavy worker. All middle management are gone. 
The leaders of the IT departments do not know anything about technology. They only see cost so the wrong technology is being deployed causing even more cost in the end.

review_title: Same as it ever was
pros: Employment is stable in the business areas. Once you're in, it's possible to spend your entire career there. The work is generally interesting and rarely slow.
cons: Compensation is below industry standard. There are no raises to speak of (2% is a good year) and  because there is not a lot of upward mobility, your salary never changes much. There is little incentive to work hard and many do just well enough to remain employed. It is also very much an old boys club. Diversity is encouraged at the executive level, but almost never put in place at the functional level.

review_title: Clueless Senior Management; Culture of discrimination
pros: Wealth of knowledge in the few senior people that are still there, but that is decreasing fast as senior people retire.
cons:
Management for the most part is completely disengaged from the day to day jobs that the employees are trying to do.  Complete befuddlement of the requirements and needs of the DoD customer.  Mid to senior employees are not taken care of financially even though those employees are doing all the work.  Training of employees (other than the new college grads that are going to leave anyway) is something that does not even enter into the equation.   What few trainings there are must be done off the clock even if it has a direct relationship to job.

Misandry:  Discrimination against men.   Women of lesser skills and experience are given preferential treatment in all job categories.

review_title: Azusa Site is to be Avoid
job_title: Senior Principal Mechanical Engineer in Azusa, CA
pros: Some friendly coworkers, great benefits, beautiful campus
cons: Cronyism is rampant.  One manager went so far as to fly in a buddy from another state to complete a design review, rather than choosing someone local with similar experience.  Azusa is an hour east of Los Angeles (Redondo Beach, El Segundo, etc) where a large number of Northrop employees work.  I am a woman who was removed from a management position so that my boss could place his friend in the role.  His best explanation was, "I don't know you."  I had worked there for 3 years, but he was new to his role.

review_title: okay. not sure if future growth is possible.
pros: Benefits, work flexibitly (depending on your manager), vacations and major holidays off.
cons:
Since my time with the company has been limited to one program, I have a limited view of the company overall.  There are a lot of issues on this particular program I support.   Haven't worked on any other programs within the company but those who have moved off to other sites have had better experiences and are more satisfied.  It could just be my luck.

It's been more difficult to get basic office supplies.   It shouldn't be that complicated to get a mouse pad or wrist guards or even paper or pens.

review_title: Engineer
pros: Once you self teach yourself the basics of the job, it becomes almost thoughtless process. Simple remedial tasks where it seems like groundhogs day everyday, but at least it makes the work week go by super fast since it is like a competition who can do the task quicker.
cons: Company focuses on shareholders and not the employees building the product. Benefits and raises primarily go to the upper management, while the pay increases for engineers and technicians are made such that it offsets inflation, while still being the minimum required. A majority of what an engineer is self-taught, no real guidance from mentors or formal training.

review_title: Public Health- Needs improvement, but overall a quality employer
job_title: Health Research Analyst in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Stability-- The company values its talent and works to keep employees across contracts
Friendly work environment
Great Benefits 
Great Work Life Balance
cons: NG is still learning how to operate in the public health field and still has some improvements to make in terms of employee titles, salary, and expansion of work into other organizations outside of CDC. Improvements also need to be made in closing the disconnect between NG employees working at the corporate office and employees working full-time on customer sites.

review_title: Decent company
pros:
Good starting salary, decent benefits.
Fellow co-workers are what make the job satisfying everyone is easy and collaborate with.
Schedule is pretty good with the 9/80 and flexible hours.
cons:
Little to no upward growth opportunities.
Promotions seem to be based on the "Good ol Boy" system instead of merit.
I have received no guidance from my management on expectations they have for me with the program, or what I need to do stand-out. 
There is next to no training, for positions... it is expected to hit the ground running.
Management seems disconnected from the workers, and tries to make up for it by micromanaging every situation.

review_title: High tech, Cool work, unrealistic program management
pros: Our products are all about the technology.  The technology is interesting, the work is challenging.  We work on products that bring war-fighters home alive, or better yet, keep them out of harm's way altogether.  The engineers are focused on providing new, creative better solutions to our customer's problems.
cons: The relentless pressure on productivity.  Every program is too tight on funding.  Baltimore has a unionized manufacturing workforce.  We are in a continual mode of rationalizing cost over-runs because we cannot seem to accurately bid any job.  Our typical program management response to any quote is "cut the dollars by a third, and the time in half."

review_title: Employee retention is a huge problem, less than three years for new hires.
pros: I work on projects that are interesting and I have minimal supervision.  I am employed Northrop Grumman only because my previous employer was purchased by Northrop Grumman.
cons: Senior management is feathering their beds at the expense of the employee.  Changes in policies and procedures that take from the employee and give to the company.  Senior management is extremely insecure as witnessed by three reorganizations in two and one-half months. I was employed by a small company that got gobbled up by NGC and had experienced the benefit of working for a small company. New hires tend to be over worked and not given challenging work.  With supervision the work challenges could be increased.

review_title: Still a decent place to work, but things are shifting...
job_title: Software Engineer IV in San Diego, CA
pros: Compensation is performance-based, which works well provided you're in a visible role.  Top tier technical folks rival the top at any tech company.  Domain knowledge is well established.
cons: Opportunities for "new" development are dwindling thanks to sequestration.  Instead the interest seems to be in gluing existing components together in new/different ways.  While "innovation" is touted the majority of programs are on the trailing edge (older technology, using obsolete compilers, etc.).  Management of internal r&d (IRAD) efforts is a tug-of-war between too many parties (BD, individual business units, etc.) which hampers getting anything done.  While I have no personal complaints, the shift to functional organization is not treating the majority of engineers all that well.

review_title: Great 3 years until this 4th one...
pros: The everyday person is typically great. About 65% to 70% of management is nice. The executives are great all around. There is room for diversity and engagement activities. I was given the freedom to be a top performer for 3 years until recently.
cons: The merit and increases are general low-single digits each year based on your salary. Merit is awarded at a quota, so how awesome you are matters less than you would hope. Lastly, your growth is dependent on your management. Good things can never flow up, only down. So if you have a manager that is not in your favor, you're pretty much stuck.

review_title: Good job with some drawbacks
pros: Good pay, good benefits, good opportunities for advancement, the company does have a forward looking mission in terms of investing in IT.
cons: Bureaucracy, large Corporation, it is easy to be lost in the shuffle.  Many times the employee will not be given to proper amount of consideration because the company is too large for specific people to be noticed and praise or admonished for beneficial or negative performance.  Raises are tied to division wide performance, which does not really reward an individual for their performance, as many tens of thousands of people are considered when making the decision whether or not to give raises.

review_title: A great company witrh competive pay and benefits.
job_title: Senior Database Administrator in Washington, DC
pros: Northrop Grumman is one of the few remaining companies with a pension plan. The benefits and 401k contributions ALMOST make up for the lack of fairness and respect toward their employees. Northrop Grumman integrates new technology and continually upgradestheir database systems.
cons: The philosophy of matrix supervision used by middle management  often results in sporadic coverage over multiple systems. One administator may be supporting as many as five project managers, all requesting 100% of your time. I'm willing to give 200%, but 500% is beyond my ability!  Employees are frequently left with the responsibility of deciding which customer will be short changed in support .

review_title: Prioritize career development
job_title: Digital Design Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: 9/80 and flexible work arrangements. Depending on which site you’re at, will have exposure to interesting/cutting edge projects. Educational assistance is helping me pursue a Masters at a fraction of cost.
cons: Teams in disarray, managers don’t make career development a priority. I was hired as an FPGA designer with strong software skills but have yet to be given a relevant workload: the offer letter and job description was almost “false-advertising”.

review_title: NGC, a great place to settle, but look elsewhere if you're ambitious
pros: Very stable job. The company takes care of its own and move people that don't fit in where they are working to somewhere better suited. Especially for someone that has a background in the military, the company is very friendly and easy to work with. They weigh experience as well as credentials when determining if someone is a good fit for a job.
cons: Compared to other contractors, the salary is low for system engineers. By moving across town, it was possible to double my salary and greatly improve my working conditions. There was also an "old boys club" that crept up. For those familiar with the military, it will seem familiar.

review_title: It's working for a big company, with lots of interesting work and lots of bureaucracy
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Decent benefits, good pay, somewhat flexible hours.  Able to maintain a work life balance. As a major contractor they get lots of work so something is always going on somewhere. 9/80 schedule.
cons: Feels like many little companies in one. Middle management seems to try to maintain individual fiefdoms so sharing across programs doesn't happen often or easily. Impossible to get rid of incompetent employees, and its pretty easy to stay under the radar and just "get by" (though that might be a pro for some people).  How and why people get promotions seems inconsistent, and its never before time in grade requirements are met.

review_title: Too Big to Fail
job_title: Systems Integration in Newport News, VA
pros: Resources, Evolving focus on talent development, Leadership with technical backgrounds, True desire to build value and quality and to innovate.  Very few people issues I've seen.
cons: Most work is with Govt contracting agencies who are typically wholly incompetent as an organization.  There are too many layers on the customer side between the true customer (the soldier/airman) and the developer (NG).  There will be a few who "get it" but the Draconian govt process will erode away at the final product only to leave the blame on the contractor.  This can be frustrating and you must maintain optimism and find the ones who "get it".

review_title: Some good managers in the company but cutthroat environment when layoffs occur
pros: I had a couple of really good managers who were very supportive, and I enjoyed working for them.  When our department was downsizing and I was laid off, they were very helpful in trying to find me more work.  They were able to bring me back on for a year.
cons: When I was first hired, it was a little chaotic and I received very little training.  There seemed to be no strong corporate identity since so many people change jobs within the government contracting industry.  As the defense budget was cut, there was definitely an "every man for himself" mentality as people were trying to find secure jobs.

review_title: Northrop Grumman is just like every other large corporation out there.
job_title: Software Engineer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: The company is huge and has tons of jobs available and they pay pretty well.
cons: The work is pretty boring with no room for any self-expression. You have to use lots of out-dated tech because most of your work has to work on government computers that are always way behind on updates. Worst of all, you mean absolutely nothing to the company as a whole you are one of 10s of 1000s of employees. You are just a number on some other person's spreadsheet. It just so happens that these are also the people who decide what kind of raises you will get, the people who you've never met who have never actually seen your work and you are only ever have heard you talked about 3rd or 4th hand.

review_title: 50 % satisfaction rate can easily be improved.
job_title: Engineering Tech IV in Memphis, TN
pros: My direct supervisor is a true PEOPLE manager, Time on job is one major reason for continuing to work here. Location is close to my personal life. I love the WORK. I do learn new things.
cons: Any extra effort or passion for the job is not rewarded.We are  paid on a job definition rather than what we actually do. My actual work differs greatly from what my job "Title" states I do. We do not get raises. we as a group had gone 4 years without even a cost of living increase. We are on a "special" NG contract and do not get the benefites that all other NG employees get.

review_title: Good job, not a bad company, but definitely not software minded.
pros: Good Benefits! Its also a job! Got a clearance!  I work on a smei boring job here in Melbourne, but I have heard other places as working on some state of the art activities.  Melbourne location is for support of JSTARS and Tanker which isn't a drag, but it isn't innovative.
cons: Very little advancement. Sit in a cube all day. Management doesn't listen to its grunts. Takes a long time to start using new technology.  We aren't even using IE 7 yet and IE 8 is about to be released.  We are still using SQL Server 2000, when 2005 has been released for 3 years now. We are not on the cutting edge at all.

review_title: Northrop Grumman provides valuable resources for our Nation's defense.
pros: They provide very valuable support to the troops and are always engaged in missions that matter to the Defense Department.  You have enormous opportunities to work just about any where in the world because of the size and scope of the company.
cons: Difficult getting truth to power.  Much of the middle management is entrenched and will filter information before it can get to decision makers.  Many middle managers are required to find billable hours so are less available to provide management support than other large companies I have seen.  Infrastructure is not adequate to support a very flat organization, so you are forced to managed in an out of date style.

review_title: Big Company.  Worth becoming another cog in the wheel?
job_title: Software Developer II in Newport News, VA
pros: Large company, lots of variety in job duties.  Potential for many different opportunities.  New hires seemingly make decent money.  They restructure everything about every 12 months, so if you don't like it, just wait - it will change.  Those doing the best seem to be on their second or third "tour of duty" - left, but came back.  More money?  Everything else out there was worse?  More experience?
cons: Continually see the people with seniority getting their benefits slashed and hacked.  NG has seemingly started punishing those who stay around the longest.  "Promised future benefits" should not be counted on.

review_title: In general, I like it here.
pros: The benefits and company retirement/stock contributions are great. Salary seems pretty competitive. Education assistance (for pursuing continuing education) is excellent (at NGES). Generally, flexible work hours and work weeks (9/80, 4/10 schedules).
cons: Management seems a little bloated. Too many cooks in the kitchen... This is my first job, so I don't know about other companies, but it also seems like more time is spent in meetings than actually doing productive work. As a software engineer, the infrastructure for developing software is dated and unnecessary. Who uses a mammoth of a package like ClearCase when there are other FREE, simpler CVS systems like SVN, Git, or Mercurial? Also, some nicer chairs would help, considering we sit for 90% of our days. I'd like a second monitor too...

review_title: Great for short term plan and fresh from College  -- longevity is not rewarded!
job_title: Buyer Specialist in El Segundo, CA
pros: It is really hard to find them...
cons: It's obviously called WORK for  a reason!  Not that I mind hard work... I don't!  I gave my 150-200% all the time!  But it always seemed the more you did, the more they gave you... without any compensation or thanks in the process.  Most of the employees are being stretched too far-- Ones with good work ethic are undermined and railroaded .  Too many favorites... the rest will die trying.  And nothing seems to change. Past 3-4 yrs of annual layoffs really undermine employee morale.. which is still at an All-time low!!

review_title: Could be MUCH better
pros: Flexible work hours (9/80), Business Casual work environment, 401K matching.  The people you will work with are helpful and support each other; first level managers at least give you the time of day now, they're just as hand-tied as you are.
cons: Bonuses were taken away, lost another paid holiday (down to 10/yr), benefits have slipped significantly, work environment is not conducive to getting quality work done.  Upper management is satisfied with mediocrity and does not single out those who go out of their way to overcome obstacles and turn out great work.  You can expect to remain at your current level for 5-10 years without any prospect of moving up.

review_title: Becomming just an average place to work
job_title: Mechanical Engineer IV in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: A lot of smart people work here. They have good processes in place. Very few cliques and mostly inclusive of everybody.
cons: Upper management has for the last few years has waged a continuous assault on benefits. From cutting down paid holidays (they recently cut the day after Thanksgiving), eliminating yearly profit share bonus for most employees,  to massively raising the cost of health insurance and blaming it on Obamacare.

review_title: Engineer II
job_title: Engineer II in El Segundo, CA
pros:
- Every other Friday off
- Flex time allows work/life balance
- Good salary
- Interesting work
- Great place to work if you are ambitious (Dont expect to be spoon fed work)
- My next 2 levels of management are great, pleasant and engaged
cons:
- Lots of nay-sayers who are jaded and are content on cruise control
- Poor review structure, "Everyone gets a 3" (scale of 1-5)
- Raises are a joke (2% - 3%)
- No bonuses, 401k match is just ok (3 year vesting)
- Benefits continue to be reduced (recent change to vacation structure reduces PTO accrual)

review_title: Many diverse opportunities for ambitious engineers to develop core skills
pros: A lot of other highly intelligent and motivated people you have opportunity to work with on mid-size to very large teams. A lot of interdiscplinary interaction with room to be autonomous but opportunity to contribute to or lead a technical team once you have gained sufficient experience. Company is open to moving you around if you want to move in a different career direction.
cons: Can be easily stovepiped or pigeon holed to a specific role once you have demonstrated aptitude in that area; this can be detrimental if you are trying to develop breadth in your field. Bureaucratic processes can often get in the way of technical progress. Sometimes the working environment loses appeal to the youthful, energetic and empassioned crowd.

review_title: Good place to start, but not friendly to those with "outside the box" thinking.
job_title: Training Representative V in Dallas, TX
pros: Steady work if you're not in a contract.  Great benefits.
cons: Extremely conservative and non-innovative corporate culture.  If you don't fit the traditional corporate mold, kiss your chances of advancement goodbye. HR makes promotions, raises, and bonuses a mess unless you know the right people. Management tends to be 45+ that view employees as assets to be used and abused as the business dictates. Young, innovative, and outside-the-box thinking is discouraged at best, punished at worst.

review_title: Legacy company
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Falls Church, VA
pros: Great benefits! Outstanding internal educational resources.  Maximized employee discount with multiple partnerships. Stock options, company credit union and company educational reimbursement programs.
cons: With most major companies employees can be lost in the numbers. Some departments(sectors) lack clear steps to career progression. Performance reviews are impersonal in large sectors from not having direct work engagement with management. Lack of mentorship( or management) who either seek to groom  personnel or recognize personnel capabilities.  Company culture tends to struggle with peer to peer support. Dog eats dog!!

review_title: Stay far away
pros: Good pay and some good programs, but that’s not worth putting up with all the other headaches that come with a job at Northrop Grumman.
cons:
Work/life balance is nonexistent.
The corporate team micromanages everyone.
Having your own creative ideas is looked down upon. The people that thrive are the ones that sit with their heads down and do just as they’re told. 
Tools and access needed in order to effectively do your job are not provided.
If you are below the director level your opinion and input doesn’t matter.
Short, sometimes impossible, deadlines are constantly expected to be met.
Team morale is the lowest I’ve ever seen in any company I have worked for.
Fosters a “dog eat dog” culture.
It’s impossible to move up unless your management is willing to fight extensively for your career growth.

review_title: Good job if you like working on Defense contracts
pros: You get to work on defense contracts.  Basically some of contracts involve designing and building large carriers or frigates for the Navy.  The work environment is also fairly stable since most of contracts or jobs seem to last anywhere from several months to several years.  The people who work there tend to be more laid back.
cons: I don't feel that the compensation is enough from the engineering side.  The bigger companies such as Shell and Exxon are paying their engineers generously and are till reaping a ton of profits.  I do believe that an engineer should be paid on his/her merits or accomplishments and his/her seniority.

review_title: Listen to the little guys.
job_title: Designer II in Newport News, VA
pros: I work with a professionals that are good at their jobs and are willing to help you if you get stuck on a problem.  The immediate supervisors understand what we do and why we do it.  We are encouraged to seek out and make improvements in processes and procedures.  Overall, it is a good place to work.
cons: Sometimes the politics of such a big company can keep some of the better improvements from being implemented and the tools they give us are not as good as they say they are.  Also, salaries have not quite kept up with the cost of living in our area.

review_title: Does Not Live up to the Hype...It's a Job
pros:
Opportunity to learn different aspects of the business
Northrop Grumman harbors some talented individuals whom are great to work with
Great Company After Hour Events
Time Off
cons:
Work and Responsibilities do not align with Defined Roles, Job Title, or Compensation (Ex. You could be doing Senior Network Engineer work, being called an Engineer Assistant, and being paid Administrative Assistant Salary)
Not a Great Career Starting Environment - Mid Level to Senior Level is suitable (Does Not Treat our youth well; taken advantage of, misguided, and misinformed)
Understaffed in major areas
Non Practiced Business Processes
Performance metrics are inconsistent and 100% subjective with minimal oversight
Management does not manage other managers, mid level managers do not have enough direction or oversight, hence teams are unorganized and overloaded with work

review_title: Loosing Employee Focus
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oklahoma City, OK
pros:
Large company that is doing very well in the defense market.
Top of the line innovative technologies have been made by this company.
cons: Slipping employee focus has resulted in the lowering of benefits, and more focus on shareholder wealth than the betterment of employees.While the matrix structure of management can be useful, Northrop uses it poorly.The emotional feel is becoming bitter toward management because of the calculated cold treatment of employees. The vision of this company seems limited.

review_title: Underwhelmed - don't stay here long, just get some experience and leave
pros: Mostly hardworking coworkers focused on the deliverables we've committed to.  There's a strong sense of purpose to completing team goals.
cons: Terrible focus on employee growth except for interns and short skirts.  Northrop's annual salary pools are worse than their competitor's and don't inspire anyone to excel.  There benefits are becoming less competitive every year.    They really don't plan to keep anyone longer than a few years since they only pay new employees well to get them to join.

review_title: Interesting engineering work but poorly managed
job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Good pay. Strong customer base.
cons:
Careers are easily derailed by a minority of incompetent people in positions of power. Thus eventually the best engineers leave and go to companies that care about their key personnel. 
Management is incredibly incapable of distinguishing between the two despite the vast evidence. I was treated fantastically for 15 years with high ratings for my great track record. Then 2 years of being treated like chopped liver was enough to get me to quit and find respect elsewhere.

review_title: Great place to start a career
pros:
Amazing 9-80 schedule - you can make your weekend a vacation just by off setting time. It is very flexible. 
Lots of work available - 
Lots of educational benefits - pursue all sorts of classes, graduate degrees through NG. 
Great people - Northrop hires the best of the best.
cons: Melbourne site is still growing so there is a lack of facilities in my opinion. We could benefit from a coffee shop and some food vendors on campus. Parking is a big hassle.

review_title: Not in my job description!!
job_title: Contract Administrator III in San Diego, CA
pros:
-Salary is high
-9-80 work schedule
cons: -Beware of what job you applied for! I got a job offer for Contract Administrator 3, but based on what management told me how to do my job, they should reclassified my position as Contract MANAGER, because when a contract administrator is always to blame for everything that goes wrong in a contract. Hell, even when acts of God caused something wrong in my contract, it was still my fault! And I'm not the only one who feels this way. There is a high turnover in the Contracts department for this specific reason. I wonder if this is why most NG Contract Administrators decided to go to General Atomics because of this reason....

review_title: Outdated and sub-par procedures in certain engineering departments
pros:
Great work 9/80 work schedule although I'd prefer 4/10s. Flexible time is nice. My management chain is mostly incredible and kind people. Competitive pay and benefits.

Sometimes it can seem like a really progressive place to work in spite of being a massive defense contractor.
cons:
Terrible time management system. Engineers are 'salaried' but have to log time to the tenth of an hour across tens of charge numbers: meetings, trainings, projects, etc. Everything has a charge number. 

Many white haired engineers doing things the way they've always done them such as manually performing repetitive tasks that should easily be automated at such a huge company. Using less-than-rigorous tools and procedures to accomplish tasks when much better ways and means exist. Things are done well enough but lack true technical excellence. Older engineers are extremely resistant to process improvement.

review_title: Outdated and sub-par procedures in certain engineering departments
pros:
Great work 9/80 work schedule although I'd prefer 4/10s. Flexible time is nice. My management chain is mostly incredible and kind people. Competitive pay and benefits.

Sometimes it can seem like a really progressive place to work in spite of being a massive defense contractor.
cons:
Terrible time management system. Engineers are 'salaried' but have to log time to the tenth of an hour across tens of charge numbers: meetings, trainings, projects, etc. Everything has a charge number. 

Many white haired engineers doing things the way they've always done them such as manually performing repetitive tasks that should easily be automated at such a huge company. Using less-than-rigorous tools and procedures to accomplish tasks when much better ways and means exist. Things are done well enough but lack true technical excellence. Older engineers are extremely resistant to process improvement.

review_title: A Place with Potential
pros:
Growth potential
Recognition for job well done
New area's for development in technology
Challenging work
cons: Need for clear communication among leadership and unity as a team

review_title: Overall, a good company to work for
pros:
*Great environment for those who like loose management (not the case 100% of the time though)
*Good benefits (Education reimbursement, 401K, health, etc)
*The company as a whole is great - fantastic CEO
*Good facilities
*Many opportunities to learn from knowledgeable people
*Fascinating work
cons:
*Very, very little accountability; those who were a detriment to the company weren't dealt with very well or at all
*Very little acknowledgement for those who performed in an outstanding manner. Generally in the form of "Lets just make everyone feel good" rather than pointing out stellar contributors
*Multiple reductions in force over the last couple of years, >50% downsizing in my division
*Poor communication between management and the production floor
*Poor design for manufacturing
*Poor designs in general many times
*Military contract dependant

review_title: Northrop has done right by me, they have taken an interest in my continued education and training. I like it here.
job_title: Information Assurance Analyst in Alexandria, VA
pros:
I am working with high end systems, current programs and standards, supporting customers who have very high expectations. I am super pleased with how hands on, and challenging this position is.
I also know that my job is somewhat portable, if I need to move for some reason, or if I want a change of pace, I can look for another Northrop job, and transfer rather than go job hunting and deal with the uncertainty of searching for a new position.
cons: I really can't think of anything that I would call a con, unless you are a person who does not like working for a large corporation. In which case Northrop would definitely not be for you. But if that is not a deal breaker, then I highly recommend working here.

review_title: Great place to get a start, but don't expect to stay... Seriously disappointed.
pros: Northrop Grumman Aerospace Systems Sector offers many advantages to it's employees where teaming efforts are involved. They afford the employ an opportunity to travel world wide, Telecommute, flexible shifts and reasonable time off for work life balance. The projects and aircraft are amazing in their capabilities, employees can be proud of their accomplishments. The culture is generally a family of friends making things happen. They look out for one another and offer assistance and guidance where needed. The benefits are reasonable as tis the compensation.
cons: Northrop Grumman has many Sectors. None of which are created equal for various reasons. This makes for an environment of the "Haves" and the "Have Not's". Many employees are jealous of other sector employees because of their benefits, schedules and general work life culture. Northrop Grumman Technical Services is the worst offender of this in my experience. They have poor benefits, expect way too much from their employees and pursue unrealistic goals. Some of the Senior Leadership have a "Bully" mentality where middle Management are afraid to speak freely for fear of reprisal. Expect layoff's every couple of years and don't think you are safe from being escorted off the property with no notice. (A very humiliating practice) This is especially true for Contractors, they are hired on and let go frequently.  Those of us who have the intestinal fortitude to stand up for what is right, are short lived in the Technical Services Sector.

review_title: KC-10A aircraft manager
job_title: Aircraft Mechanic in Lake Charles, LA
pros: No A&P required. No Tools required. good plane to work on. you get to work in a hanger (no AC con) most managers will work with scheduling conflicts without having to use your pto.
cons: Gaurentted no pay raises, tools are cheap and limited. You have to be on a special list to move into management. Your co-workers will steal your stuff and lie to your face, (not to leave out throw you under the bus just for a little recognition) the managers stick up for their friends and cover up violations but are quick to get rid of people.

review_title: Excellent place to start a career
job_title: Professional Development Program in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: Excellent experience. As PDPs, we are treated very well and considered to be the future leaders of the company. Though this experience depends on where your rotation is at, so far I have received more than adequate support from fellow coworkers and even upper level management who realize the importance of injecting youth into the aging work force.
cons: None to speak of. Though the PDP is now enterprise-wide, you may find that each sector runs it slightly differently. You might notice this if you try to rotate out of sector. More of an observation than a con.

pros: Stability, due to US and UK Navy contracts that could last 40+ years.  The origional contract was to update the entire missile launcher systems for the new submarines.  However, the military budgets were reduced so much that only minor upgrades are affordable.  In other words, this is boring.
cons: Operates like a big jobshop, facilities here are ancient, dating back to 1906, and are unhealthy!  Does not meet modern codes.

review_title: Great pay but communication could be better
pros: You are compensated more than fairly.
cons: There is a lack of communication between management and employees.  When circumstances dictates meeting a time critical schedule the management doesn't fully explain why it's time critical and what the outcome would be if not met.  Furthermore when an employee does go "beyond" the call yea there is a pat on the back but not in front of peers where it has some meaning.  A manager will give praise in private and scorn in public.  All management training I had tells me the opposite.  Praise in public, scorn in private but since the money is good I will continue to work here as I really enjoy my standard of living.

review_title: Great place to begin your engineering career
job_title: Engineer Systems III  in Newport News, VA
pros: Great place to start your engineering career.  There are many hands on engineering opportunities throughout the shipyard with many very experienced people to learn from.  There are also a wide variety of engineering departments to choose.  NGC also allows for internal transfers between sectors.
cons: The main downsides concern this specfifc sector of Northriop Grumman.  The shipbuilding sector in Newport News still has pockets of "good old boy" culture.  As a result, promotions are slow for mid level engineers, that is unless your one of the "Boys".  The Career path and compensation rates are not transparent.  Most folks do not know where they stand with regards to Market rate for Salary.  most folks also aren't aware of a career path nor how they can proceed with advancment within the sector.

review_title: Merit Pay Is Possible, But Expect to Work Long Hours
pros:
Flexible working hours.  

Varied job opportunities.  

High achievers/perfomers can reap significantl merit raises.   

Employees are accessible and very willing to share information and lessons learned on projects.  Employees can seek training virtually, via in-house seminars or via formal courses at colleges/universities.
cons:
Expect to work over 90 hours per pay period.   

Human Resources is very tight-lipped on compensation range for one's current position.  For me, starting salary/compensation was non-negotiable where company appeared to have an arrognant  attitude.

Employees have to remember they are expendable and have to ensure they are marketable by taking advantage of training opportunties..

review_title: Great big company
job_title: Embedded Software Engineer in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Big company with lots of resources.  Good place for young engineer to learn corporate life.  Interesting and sometimes challenging technical work for software engineer - mostly C#, C++ and C using Visual Studio, although some Linux work as well.  Lots of online training opportunities.  Pays reasonably well, especially with overtime (if available).  Good benefits.
cons: Corporate culture is focused on stockholder value, meaning profit margin.  Lots of corporate hoops to jump through, yet focus is nominally getting quality work done on tine and within budget.  Not surprisingly Northrop Grumman has an uptight atmosphere.  Lots of Government, especially defense contract work for US Navy.  Multiple layoffs in 2010 and 2011 contribute to low morale with workforce cut nearly in half.  Likely more layoffs to come if defense contracting does not pick up soon.

review_title: Business outlook grim
pros: It was a great place to gain experience right out of college.  Benefits are good, especially the tuition reimbursement
cons:
Management and BD are not doing their jobs.  Despite defense cutbacks, contracts are there to be won.  However, the Apopka management decided to invest in facilities while laying people off at the same time.  Now overhead is out of control so they can't bid competitively on contracts anymore.  They're circling the toilet bowl.  

Disclaimer:  I was not laid off.
Layoffs were ridiculous.  They targeted the older employees with the most valuable experience.  They spared many incompetent people.  Very few managers were affected.

review_title: Good work just gets a pat on the back
pros: The travel opportunities have been fantastic, I have great insurance at a good price, and I get to work with some truly talented people everyday. I also have a flexible work schedule, so I can shift my hours around as needed to accommodate outside activities.
cons: Despite excellent performance reviews, it can be difficult to advance here. This is based on both my own experience as well as watching several others get frustrated and eventually leave the company for large pay increases and better work environments.

review_title: Company actively stagnates the professional development of employees
pros: Eh, compared to industry, there aren't really any pros that stand out at NG.  They're wonderfully mediocre in employee support.
cons: No actual benefits, just the illusion of such by offering plans in a marketplace they curate.  Technical development is a dirty word at the company, as doing anything outside office tasks is frowned upon since it's likely to elevate you in qualification above your current position.  This is an issue since most of NG has such a high turn over rate, mostly due to not catering to the career development of it's employees and just treating them like a resource to slowly burn out.

review_title: NG - Learn and Leave
pros:
Competitive salary (coming in the door
Benefits start on day one
Savings Plan (401K) and Retirement Plan (vested after 3 years)
cons:
High over head ((i.e. too many high level managers, BD, sector positions that do not directly support a customer base, etc.)
Too many 'leaders' (all drinking the muscle juice and not talking to each other)
Little to no growth potential (depending were you are - on contract or support position)
Compensation behind on equity adjustments (wait until people threaten to leave).

review_title: The work is fun and it pays better than unemployment.
pros: Northrop Grumman is a good place to work because it is challenging, they are open to new ideas and using new technologies. There are always new projects coming up and I'm given freedom to explore and invent.
cons: NGC doesn't pay very well and the benefits are mediocre. I have worked on several projects that have saved or made thousands of dollars for the company. To date I've received zero kudos. The salary is well below average for the job performed, and my job title doesn't fit my responsibilities. No one has received a promotion here in 5 years.

review_title: Time for managers to grow into Leaders.  There is a difference and it can improve performance and P&L!
pros: People want to do a good job.  Opportunities are available.  You have to push for them.
cons:
Lots of politics and infighting among executives delaying decisions

Sometimes more concerned with protecting themselves, then doing it right.  Not a lot of courage.

Lack of communication and direction, and sometimes fear based decisions.  Very few real leaders, lots of bureaucracy

review_title: Help Desk Technical Support
pros: The office environment of the company the position is contracted to is very laid back.  They encourage you to further your education and certs with a tuition reimbursement program.  You are also encouraged to give suggestions that increase efficiency and cross training is encouraged.
cons: The pay isn't great, raises aren't much. Don't look for advancement unless you know who to brown-nose or flirt with.  Even if you are great at your job, over-qualified for your current position, cross trained for other position, it won't matter.  Turn-over is significant unless you are in the higher levels of the company.

review_title: Unsatisfied
pros: The company does have good benefits and the pay is at or above industry levels.
cons: In the division, and specifically the department that I work in, it is truly unbelievable how much management does not know about the job function that they are managing. There is no career progression, there are no promotions, there is no listening to constructive feedback and the philosophy is you can be replaced by a person with a lower salary who won't ask questions. It is even comical that they have actually stated that employee engagement rating scores that are significantly below industry norms (red) are good. I guess employees are now to believe that red is the new blue (high ratings).

review_title: Use for a "port in the storm", not a long term career employment! Managers suck!
job_title: Software Engineer in West Chester, OH
pros: Xetron might be a "port in the storm". Don't be naive & think of it as anything but a temporary work place. Keep your better ideas as confidential as possible! Keep records of executves' bad actions and statements. Keep your resume up to date!
cons: Xetron screws hard working senior engineers to prevent vesting.  Unscrupulous management sets themselves up for big bonuses by creating phony cut backs to prevent workers from getting vesting retirement benefits. NO ETHICS AT THE HIGHER EXEC LEVELS - JUST GREED! Consider employment as a short-term "port in the storm" while finding a better place to work and actually have a meaningful career!

review_title: Good benefits but some culture issues
job_title: Associate Quality Engineer in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros: Very good work life balance due to optional 9/80 schedule (you can work 9 hours most days and then get every other Friday off, which totals 80 hours of work in each two week period). I enjoy having at least two 3-day weekends each month which allows me to travel, book appointments, or run errands. Also, overtime is paid by the hour on top of your salary, and is usually optional if you communicate well with your manager. $10k/year towards masters degree.
cons: Northrop Grumman can be a bit hierarchical which comes from its relationship to military customers, which can result in lower level managers focusing more on pleasing their management than truly identifying and solving important problems. Also, they have a ways to go when it comes to true agile development.

review_title: Northrop Grumman - an ok place to work
pros:
Good benefit plan
Company seems to want to retain good employees
New CEO seems to be working very hard to improve employee perception of the company Many training opportunities
cons:
No defined career paths
minimal salary increases
At the end of a program/contract company does not help much in finding a new position; they have a site to post your resume, but unless you hold a Top Secret clearance hiring managers do not seem to look at it.
HR reps do not help employees and report any conversations to management

review_title: Stability at it's best.
job_title: Systems Engineer II in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: Extremely stable environment with reasonable to slightly above average pay for an Engineer working in Defense.  Very ethical company with a good and very structured management hierarchy.  Training budget is increasing starting 2014, and the company provides unmatchable time-off polices with a flex-time work schedule.  No other company can give you better work-life balance.
cons: Northrop is very process oriented, and new employees unfamiliar with defense will need to get accustomed to it.  In order to increase profit, NGC is slowly taking away the little "perks" we used to have as NGC employees.  Salary is decent at best, but consistently hard workers who exceed expectations will be rewarded in the long run.

review_title: IT Program  Manager
pros: Worked at NGC for 35 years. Great company to work for. Many opportunities to move within the company, however you have to look for and develop the opportunities. You are generally rewarded for what you do and for your performance. The benefits are better that average. You can make a great career if you work hard, contribute and are good at what you do.
cons: It is a large company and there are political influences you will have to deal with. As a primarily DOD contractor the annual raises can be slim to non existent in some years. Benefit cost have been going up the last few years. Work life balance is preached but not always practiced.

review_title: Great People but Bureaucratic and Siloed
job_title: Systems Engineer in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros: Excellent people of high character that are friendly.  9/80 work schedule is accepted by all management.  Pay is pretty good.  They are trying to get better and value employee feedback.
cons: Poor collaboration, questionable quality of work, siloed work environment that they blame on need to know.    You may sit on overhead for months before getting a halfway decent project.  Even then it may only last a month.  Being locked in a closed room sucks.  Northrop needs less table scrap small contracts and more larger ones to keep people doing steady and interesting work.

review_title: Poor Management, Boring Work
job_title: Business Management Analyst in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
Flexible work schedule
Overtime pay based on prorated hourly wage
cons:
Poor communication and organization from management
Lack of work most of the time, when there was work it was extremely unorganized and mundane
Pay was well below the market rate for the Bay Area
Work was repetative

review_title: Take your career to new heights at Northrop Grumman!
pros: The benefits (401k matching, pension plan, 3 weeks vacation per year, 9/80 work schedule, full tuition reimbursement/disbursement) are all exceptional.  In addition, I feel that the opportunities for professional and personal growth are wide open if you are willing to take accountability for your own career path.
cons: The campus location that I work at has a heavily tenured population with 20+ years of experience.  This base of employees has seen many corporate mandated changes.  So, now, as we are embarking on some cutting edge cultural change initiatives to increase workforce engagement, there is some strong resistance to that change by some upper management members.

review_title: I can think of worse places to work, but not many.
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: If you are the type of person who likes to work 40 hours a week and then go home aerospace is the industry for you. NGST is no exception to this rule.
cons: Corporate culture is stuck in the 1960's. There is very little design change since everything has "heritage" and the reason for keeping things the way they are is simply given as "that's how we have always done it". There is very little straying from the norm in any design. If you like to try to change corporate culture this isn't the place for you.

review_title: Great company
pros: Tons of opportunities if you can network with others throughout the organization.  As a new employee, NG offers 40 hours of PTO and then you can accrual throughout the year. In addition, they provide benefits and 401k.
cons: Young talent aren't seen as powerful as  seasoned employees. In some areas, compensation isn't as competitive as other organizations. Not enough work life balance. Also, performance reviews aren't accurately captured for those who aren't managers- compensated with a maximum bonus of 3%.

review_title: Great company
pros: Tons of opportunities if you can network with others throughout the organization.  As a new employee, NG offers 40 hours of PTO and then you can accrual throughout the year. In addition, they provide benefits and 401k.
cons: Young talent aren't seen as powerful as  seasoned employees. In some areas, compensation isn't as competitive as other organizations. Not enough work life balance. Also, performance reviews aren't accurately captured for those who aren't managers- compensated with a maximum bonus of 3%.

review_title: Interesting developmental work, Needs more investment in reducing waste
job_title: Mechanical Engineer in El Segundo, CA
pros: Good Accrual of PTO, A wide breadth of possible statements of work, New contracts being one and old contracts being extended.
cons: The management is struggling to improve the working experience, More money is being focused on infrastructure and less on people, Work is being moved from more desirable locations (Redondo Beach/El Segundo) to less desirable locations (Palmdale CA, Melbourne FL), Constantly trying to reduce costs by reducing overhead rather than solving existing problems.

review_title: It's a very good place to work
job_title: Production Planner (A2) in Newport News, VA
pros: The flexability to start new programs, if a need can be shown. A flexable work schedule that spans the pay period. I am recognized by management and peers for the effort I put forth. The ability to move around to different jobs within the company has become much improved. It used to be that unless you were asked to apply for a job, you didn't dare apply. Failure to follow this unwritten rule was cause to be "blackballed"and the offender's career was over.
cons: The environment of the shipyard is hard.  The good-old-boy network is slowly leaving, but not quick enough. When ther is a problem, there is often more finger pointing, than a desire to find the root cause. This has changed somewhat, but its still prevelant.

review_title: A company that has lost its way.
pros: Excellent pay. Interesting and challenging programs. A valuable resource for national security.
cons: An overly large conglomerate/holding company where people are treated like furniture. A company that lacks any team spirit whatsoever.  Employees are so busy looking over their shoulder that they often walk into walls.  Policy, procedures and bureaucracy are venerated while customer satisfaction, quality and innovation suffer as employees spend an inordinate amount of time maneuvering  through the internal labyrinth of non-sense checks and balances.  Northrop is consumed with fear of making a mistake or losing a dollar. This has killed the entrepreneurial spirit.  Management  is highly accusatory and would rather excoriate an employee than roll up their sleeves and help with the problem.

review_title: Never a dull moment.
pros: Working for  a defence contractor gives a person a chance to make a difference to the the war fighter and support their country in this way while making a living.
cons: Computer tools and applications put in place may not make a division a cost efficient place to work.To make emplyees accountable for the bottom line then they need to change the mangemet structure from right now such that these emplyees get to keep their jobs if the General manger gets a bonus for making sales. instead make it an employee run company?

review_title: Bureaucratic Corporation
pros: Excellent 401k, Credit Union, and Medical plans. Decent retirement/separation packages. Onsite fitness center and fitness classes. Excellent tuition assistance.
cons: Incompetent and undeserving middle and upper management. Poor strategy planning that causes unnecessary time constraints and inefficient use of resources. Onsite HR is worthless. Promotions are only given to those that are in the right circle. It's hard to get recognized for hard work and talent unless you know the right person.

review_title: Northrop Grumman --Great peers, great executives, not such great mid-level management.
job_title: Software Engineer in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: My peers are outstanding.  The executive team is outstanding.  There is a ton of room for growth within Northrop Grumman.  Saying that, it's a great company and I would encourage anyone to pursue an opportunity within Northrop Grumman.
cons:
1) Raises are given to groups rather than to the individuals who do the most. 

2) My biggest complaint is mid-level managers aren't up exactly "with it".  The ones I work with rule with an iron first and are ignorant of the current business climate in America.   This might just be in my business unit, but from talking to others it seems to be some type of odd trend.

review_title: Good place to work
pros: Like many defense contractors, your mileage may vary depending on what contract you support. It is difficult to give pros and cons for the company as a whole. In my experience, Northrop Grumman does a great job of hiring great talent but fails to keep the best talent. The work environment is collegial and enjoyable, but the pay and benefits are at best at par or slightly sub-par.
cons: Only criticism is that pay raises seemed to be very butter spread. The raise given to the best performer was only slightly better than the worst performer. This strategy hardly inspires exceptional effort.

review_title: Poor Work Environment, But You'll Learn A Lot
pros: Northrop Grumman is the upper echelon as far as work skills and training are concerned.  Pay is decent, and there are opportunities to transfer around.
cons: Employees are not valued.  Management frequently does not follow through with their promises so get everything in writing.  Red tape bogs down everything, making things inefficient and slow.  Management will do things the wrong way just to get through management approvals and sign offs.  Promotions are few and far between.  Employee quality of life is non-existent.  Health insurance is overpriced and varies from sector to sector.

review_title: Great Company
job_title: Electronics Test Engineer in Grand Prairie, TX
pros: Northrop Grumman is a well established company, and as such has a high quality infrastructure. I never had any doubts about for what the company stands, nor did I ever hesitate to put my name on any product or service provided to the customer. I really appreciated the fact that all documentation was kept up to date and accurate; a necessity in the work I was doing for them.
cons: While the contract to which I gave 8 years of my lie was small in comparison to other NG contracts, I was still working for a huge company. Consequently, I was nothing more than an employee number. When the contract was terminated, the people were just abandoned with a shrug of the shoulder. None of us ever felt like we meant anything to them.

review_title: Excellent high level management opportunities if you're a retired military officer
pros: Good work to life balance; decent pay; great paid time off and vacation; good education reimbursements; and excellent medical/dental/vision benefits.
cons: Regardless of your credentials, unless you're a retired military officer there are not many opportunities (if any) for growth into management; Management is typically run by military retirees that aren't business or technical savvy; Performance appraisal process is unfair/fixed and the manager's favorites will always get the higher merit increases, regardless of how good an employee's actual performance is;  Many of the former military officers now managing in NG are incompetent as managers; and The majority of management are top heavy with old timers.

review_title: Innovation is key
pros:
Great opportunities to do different stuff, you just have to put yourself out there
Support from upper management about getting more involved in the company and persuing activities
Management is trying to be more "innovative" which is really (slowly) shaking things up (positively)
Internal programs to stimulate employees being empowered to take over their own careers
cons:
If your project ends, you are out of luck.  You have to find your own new position and you are given the same priority as an external employee. (although I think this situation depends on the group)
HR center is worthless, you call for help and they just read back the literature.  No deeper understanding of benefits.

review_title: Northrop Grumman Aerospace Systems Test Engineer
job_title: Test Engineer I in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: Northrop develops ground-breaking technology and engineers are constantly faced with technically challenging problems that often require novel and/or complex solutions. Several older employees are retiring across the board which will create opportunities for young engineers to thrive.
cons: Northrop is not a "cutthroat" company, meaning once an employee gets a job, they typically won't let go of him unless he has done something extremely wrong. This causes laziness in the work place and several people working on a job that could be done with less people. Northrop is also very bureaucratic, making it sometimes impossible to get simple jobs done.

review_title: Do not work here.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros: The development and production NGC executes for its clients is impressive. Other than that, I guess having every other Friday off is nice. But you need to work 9-hour days M-Th.
cons:
Every single minute of your 9-hour day is documented. If you take a 5 minute bathroom break, you can't charge that time so you need to work 9 hours and 5 minutes, for example. Furthermore, the facility at Rolling Meadows is atrocious. No windows, terrible culture, even worse "amenities." 

Also, the benefits package is not good. Anybody who says it is does not have knowledge in this arena. Rx coverage is lacking severely, contributions are high, and the "benefits center" is a useless resource. You need to communicate all requests through the benefits center, but this is impossible when their employees do not know what they're talking about. I have never been more frustrated with a benefits package.

review_title: read before hiring on
pros: Drive to work is relatively close to home and traffic is not too much of an issue.  401k available, dental available, medical available, and vision benefits available.  Company matches your 401k dollar for dollar up to 4 percent.  Some sectors are given the opportunity to share in the profit at the end of each year.  The company provides a new percent goal each year that ranges from 1 percent to 4 percent.  Of course, the 4 percent goal can never be reached.  Average bonus received each year normally runs around 2.5 percent against the employees yearly salary.  New employees receive 2 wks vacation after 1 year and accrues additional hours for each year worked thereafter
cons: cronyism and nepotism exists among the management

review_title: Decent place to work.
pros: My job is challenging.  I was quickly put into a leadership role.  My manager pushes us to produce quality work.  Job stability appears to be excellent.  For me, the location is ideal as I am close to my family and friends (unlike my previous job).  All overtime is paid beyond 40 hours/week.  The 9/80 program that allows employees to work alternating 44 and 36 hour weeks and get every other Friday off is a big plus.  The week off between Christmas and New Years is also a nice benefit.  The relocation package was good.
cons: There are no bonuses or profit sharing, stock options, stock purchase plan, etc.  Salaries could be a more competitive, particularly considering the lack of an incentive plan.

review_title: Northrop-Grumman ship Systems New Orleans (formerly Avondale Shipyards) is a good, secure place to work.
job_title: Subcontract Manager I  in New Orleans, LA
pros: Job security, benefits package, 401K, pension plan, 4 day work week, 2 weeks off for Christmas, building ships to keep America strong. Northrop-Grumman ship Systems New Orleans (formerly Avondale Shipyards) is a good, secure place to work. I came here at the age of 18 years old with no skills whatsoever and this place trained me to become skilled at my position; first as a pipe fitter, then as a material handler, then as a computer operator. Previously I didn't know how to turn a computer "on", and now I am helping people use computers, sharing the wealth of information I acquired here through the many learning tool at my disposal. I you can't learn at Northrop Grumman, you can not learn anywhere.
cons: Early starting times (6 a.m.)

review_title: satisfied with internship
pros: career advancement options that accelerate progression in company.  family-friendly environment.  as an intern, i have heard a lot about a desire at the executive level to hire and retain young talent (interns)
cons: seems like either you are totally committed to career progression, or you are stuck in one job.  company seems to be only working toward strengthening its profile as a missile defense contractor, and hasn't really pursued much in the area of space exploration.

review_title: Everything you expect from a big corporation
job_title: Software Engineer IV in San Diego, CA
pros: The manager I have is nice. Do not work at corporate so do not have any contact with the suits.
cons: Raises below inflation, even for high performers. Raises tied to mythological predictions of poor culture performance of the company, which never match what stockholders are told, and never pan out as the company still rakes it in. Benefits keep dropping. Ridiculous culture where upper management tries to tell engineers that they care, are diverse and other ridiculous ideas while they cut benefits and do not even try to keep up with inflation on raises. Layoff culture. Upper management received obscene benefits and pay packages and reorganizes routinely to increase their pay. And they conduct "anonymous" surveys which are mandatory and not really anonymous. It's really just a big Dilbert strip.

review_title: Great place to start a career if you luck out with the right project, team, and manager
job_title: Software Engineer in Redondo Beach, CA
pros:
0) Work-Life Balance, 9/80 Schedule
1) You get to do a little bit of everything: Design, Code, Test, etc.
2) You can work on different projects to get experience in other areas like Hardware or VLSI
3) You get time to learn and even though there are deadlines the environment isn't stressful
4) Good benefits like Education assistance
5) Monetary rewards (TAP rewards) & recognition (Everyday Heroics) for doing a good job
cons:
0) Some of the tools are outdated and frustrating to use
1) I wish the pay was higher, at least a $10k - $12k bump where level 1s start at $75k
2) Some new employees don't get interesting things to do and aren't challenged enough

review_title: Great place to start a career if you luck out with the right project, team, and manager
job_title: Software Engineer in Redondo Beach, CA
pros:
0) Work-Life Balance, 9/80 Schedule
1) You get to do a little bit of everything: Design, Code, Test, etc.
2) You can work on different projects to get experience in other areas like Hardware or VLSI
3) You get time to learn and even though there are deadlines the environment isn't stressful
4) Good benefits like Education assistance
5) Monetary rewards (TAP rewards) & recognition (Everyday Heroics) for doing a good job
cons:
0) Some of the tools are outdated and frustrating to use
1) I wish the pay was higher, at least a $10k - $12k bump where level 1s start at $75k
2) Some new employees don't get interesting things to do and aren't challenged enough

review_title: Interesting programs but lacks diversity especially at Executive Level (CxO)
job_title: Program Control Analyst in Arlington, VA
pros:
- An abundance of interesting projects / programs that are geared towards our Nation's Defense.
- Tons of experience can be obtained in multiple competency areas
- Great place for someone to kick-off their career, allowing individuals to better plan for future career development opportunities
cons:
- Lacks diversity, especially at the senior leadership level
- Roles are practically silo-ed and opportunity to advance is slim
- No real learning development for employees
- Company relies on work provided in Government contracts and its success is largely dependent on it

review_title: Systems Engineering
pros:
NG provides products that really make a difference to the end user.  NG's products support the warfighter every day.  

NG also provides opportunities for employees to take on larger roles as they develop, and training/development activities are available from the individual work site level to the sector level.  

NG values and applies systems engineering principles during the development of its products to ensure that the end user experience is a positive one.  I've had the privilege to work with excellent engineers who are passionate about their products and customers in every role I have taken over the past several.
