cons: As a government contractor, many programs (but certainly not all) at NG are slower paced than in other industries.  Some NG programs are heavily risk driven which comes with a certain level of administrative burden.

review_title: Outdated culture
pros: The benefits are really good. It's a good place to start if you have no experience and want to work in defense contracting
cons: The culture is too old and toxic for young professionals. Terrible engineering practices and the work you do will set you back 30 years. The pay is some of the lowest I've seen across similar companies as well. Management has a bias toward hiring people from their small private college, and most higher managers all come from said unknown private college

review_title: Racisist work culture, aggressive management, the kind of company where an employee will die and nothing will be said.
job_title: Flight Test Technician in Palmdale, CA
pros: Good hours when you work what is actually scheduled.
cons: There is so much racism here it's incredible that there hasn't been a lawsuit already. I have been in 3 different facilities and on each crew I have had to deal with racist comments. Aggressive management that approaches you daily asking you to do more with less. In my time here I have seen 3 suicides and 2 deaths caused by accidents in response to the suicides there was none but when asking fellow employees you will get a response somewhere along the lines of these people know they can quit right?

review_title: Would not recommend this company.
job_title: Engineer I in El Segundo, CA
pros: If you like working on defense contracts, and don't mind paper work, it isn't a bad place for job stability (and knowing what to expect on a day-to-day basis) when there are plenty of contracts.  Watch out when contracts are about to end, though.
cons: Once contracts come to a close, you may be laid off (it's the nature of defense contracting).  Middle management is pretty inept in terms of assigning adequate work and encouraging career growth.  Everyday operations are incredibly inefficient and riddled with large amounts of paperwork and Powerpoint presentations, but very little actual design work.  Promotions are given out based on tenure, not merit.  And raises are given out based on averages amongst people with your same job title, so all-in-all, raises are given just at the level of inflation (or a bit lower).

review_title: Looks great at the hiring event... then reality hits.
pros:
Flexible work week (9/80 every other Friday off)
Employees are knowledgable and willing to share their expertiese
100% Tuition Reimbursement for Technical Degrees (MS, PhD)
Builds world class technology products
cons:
Casual (i.e. unpaid) Over-time is the norm
Promotions promised and then never received
Jobs vacated by retirees are filled by college new hires, but the new hires make half of the pay but are expected to complete all the same tasks as the previous employee, this makes for real quick burnout
Many office areas are lackluster and old, some renovations are in process, but turning into a cubicle city, which results in loud and noisy workspaces in which it is difficult to conduct work
Lacking in adaquate facilities for nursing/lactating mothers
Only four days of sick pay allotted per year

review_title: Professional Development Program
job_title: Cost Control Analyst in Baltimore, MD
pros:
Flexibility (9/80 scedule); rotational assignments; diversity.
Professional Development Opportunities - NGES offers 100% tuition assistance and is very supporting of requests to take both internal and external training courses.
cons: It's a huge organization where it's difficult to get noticed for above average work. Yearly raises are fairly standard across jobs, regardless of how you perform, and employees do not receive a salary increase after earning an advanced degree or completing a certification. Salaries are lower than industry average, at least for business professionals, and many new employees leave within 2-3 years. It's very easy to leave Northrop after a short period and move to another defense contractor within the area. Management regularly discusses the need to retain talented young employees, but so far it appears to just be talk.

review_title: Tools to do the job right are available here.
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: There are many cross training opportunities in the sector.  They are plenty of training opportunities within the company.  Management is usually flexible about balancing work and life outside of work.  The benefits are among the best compared to other large companies.  The software tools are second to none.
cons: It is a large company with a lot of inertia behind existing policies and procedures.  It takes years of many people pushing to make a procedure change for the betterment of the individual worker bees.  Promotions are unfortunately not based solely on individual performance but require that the success of the project or program that you work on.

review_title: Great place to work, with typical big company issues
job_title: Member of Technical Staff III in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: NGST allows engineers to work on technical and very complex projects.  It has the resources and experienced personnel to find answers to almost any problem.  They will send you to school, send you to workshops/conferences, and bring in teachers for technical subjects.  Good managers who treat you fair and let you take vacation.  Because it is big there are a lot of other people your age and experience so you can make connections.  Pay a bit more than average.  Opportunity to make your own career path.
cons: Typical aerospace problems not really NGST specific.  Slow pace work, risk aversion, dead wood, government funding cycles, and despite their best efforts promotion by seniority not merit

review_title: Every Empire has its downfall
pros: Its great rewarding work. The products we work on are something to be very proud of;. the company is always leading in innovation. Great Future in the Company as a whole. Its future is bright except for some declining programs because of the lack of government funds. Ok pay, great benefits and excellent place to gain experience.
cons: Once in company favoritism seems to arise depending on dept management. It used to do more employee appreciation. Everyone knows each other everyone talks to each other. Rumors spread pretty fast.

review_title: Constant Change
pros: Benefits are decent but constantly being rolled back. The company realizes it must do more to attract and retain young talent as the world of tech is very competitive and is making a genuine effort at culture change. The company creates some amazing technology for it's customers and there is a genuine esprit de corps and pride in being at the vanguard of the industry. CEO is visionary and has managed the company's stock price extremely well.
cons: Latest performance evaluation scheme smells like stack ranking. Employees must work on shoddy, antiquated equipment much of the time and physical plant is often run down. Constant change and restructuring makes for lack of vision and stress over direction and stability. Very bloated management structure with cuthroat culture to get ahead.

review_title: Employment Feedback
pros: Northrop Grumman Technical Services Inc is the smallest entity of the organization and it allows flexibility for employees to telecommute up to one to three days a week.
cons: Northrop Grumman Technical Services Inc has the tendency to treat upper management personnel that are not qualified for their positions better than personnel who actually knows how to perform their job at the lower level. Basically it's the good ole boy system because personnel who can't perform their job at the lower level would be terminated whereas upper management keeps their position or is just transitioned to another position.

review_title: Shiny Apple, Rotten on the Inside
job_title: Systems Engineer in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros: Stable job, career advancement opportunities, able to move around the company.
cons: Company cares more about metrics and the bottom line than their products and people.  Job roles are extremely limited to specific tasks with a lot of emphasis on 'staying in your lane.'  The beauracracy here creates immense delays and waste, but the company knows the govt will just keep paying regardless.  I personally disagree with these predatory practices being levied against our tax dollars.

review_title: NGIT-Some interesting work but the company's nothing special
pros: Leading edge work, with the ability to do things important for the country.  You can work on things that you won't find out in the commercial world and have a chance to make a difference in protecting America.  There are a lot of good people who are hard working and are pleasant to be around. You often get to work with a mix of other contractors and government people, which allows for a different experience than being insulated inside the "company culture".  There are some reasonble benefits like discounts on merchandise and services as well as educational opportunities, depending upon your location and your managment.
cons:
Giant Buerocracy
Too many ex-government hired for their connections rather than their abilities

review_title: Solid place to work
pros: NGES is typically a more than stable environment that provides engineers the opportunity to work on cutting edge technology as it pertains to RADAR, sensor development, and other DoD warfighter technologies. They are trying to become more proactive in providing employees with work life balance (9/80 work schedules, employee resource groups, etc.,) and compensation is comparable to other large DoD companies.
cons: The downside of the company is first and foremost, that it's a DoD company who's program budgets will (and did) dry up as government administrations change. That, along with the tough task of keeping it's large employee pool constantly working, are the major cons of the company.

review_title: Retired
pros: Benefits are quite good.  Compensation is adequate for the location.  HIstorically the opeartion was Sperry Marine and the employees take pride in thier products and results of operation.  This organization (NG Charlottesville) can be an excellent career stepping stone if you are willing to play the NG game.
cons: Top management tends to want employees to give all and then expect little in return.  Thus work/life balance is quit bad.  Middle managment operates via intimidation.  Workpace can be what may be considered hostile at times.  Senior management believes that the only good ideas come from NG Sector.

review_title: Good company for 28 years until I got over 50 and they laid me off
job_title: Systems Engineer in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros: Good first job for an engineer as they have top notch facilities, lots of  contracts but you will start off at the bottom and move up slowly according to your abilities. I would suggest a systems engineer job as you can see and work with many disciplines.
cons: Like most companies they are whittling away at benefits, be careful as you get older- there is no loyalty to you, it is all about the shareholders. Keep current on your skills and position yourself correctly for further advancement. Do not trust mid-level managers as they have no concern other than their own career.

review_title: Good company.
pros: Good company with lots of flexibility to work in jobs around the USA and around the globe. Tuition reimbursement, good healthcare, 401k matching. I've worked as both management and technical staff and have enjoyed each job for about 4 years and then transferred elsewhere.
cons: It's a big company. You can feel like nothing more than a number, especially when you have to deal with their benefits center (outsourced to Fidelity) or tuition reimbursement people (outsourced to EdAssist, quite possibly the MOST FRUSTRATING PROCESS EVER!!!!)

review_title: It is a great place to start your career.
job_title: Software Engineer II in Melbourne, FL
pros: My direct technical supervisor never comes around and hassles me about what I'm doing or how I'm doing it.  The other software engineers here are mostly competent in their line of work and don't mind helping each other solve difficult problems.  The employee base is fairly older, though.  This isn't really a huge problem, but some of the technical work models and ideas are a bit dated.
cons: I question the ability of management to make practical and sound technical decisions.  A lot of times it seems the best way to solve a problem is over looked for the most expedient.

review_title: Management decisions make it hard to be positive
job_title: Quality Engineer in New Orleans, LA
pros: The pay is extremely good for the work that you accomplish. The benefits are excellent. It will depend on who you work for as to whether you boss is okay.
cons: Upper management at Northrop Grumman is not always fair.  Most of their recent decisions have made it extremely hard to be positive.  Overall it's a negative place to work that may bring you down. It takes acts of congress to get anything accomplished and/or changed. This may be everywhere though, it's the first company I've worked at.

review_title: Great Experience for Interns
pros: Northrop Grumman provides a really great intern program.  It keeps all the summer interns around the sector to be involved, learn, and socialize with other interns during the summer.  They take pride in their intern program and want them to be more like employees than interns.  They provide meaningful work during the summer so it doesn't feel like that stereotypical intern job of getting coffee and making copies.
cons: From the perspective of an intern,  you won't get feedback very often like you would in an academic environment.  It is an adjustment and really the only con.

review_title: Northrop Grumman is a great place to work.
pros: Benefits are very good, it's large enough to find multiple opportunities, it's flexible about working at home or on flex hours in most locations.  In my location, we have "9-80", meaning that we work 9 hours a day and take every other Friday off.  It's a very nice benefit -- even if you don't take the day off, you have a chance to catch-up since you aren't supposed to schedule meetings on that day.
cons: It can be really hard to make Director for even talented people with good leadership skills, and it is almost impossible to make VP.  They like to hire from outside for upper level positions, and lately I've witnessed a couple VP positions filled without competition.

review_title: Great company overall
pros: Northrop is huge and therefore gives a lot of potential if you're willing to move around. They also have a pretty awesome SEA program if you want to try different things and see different places. The people here (at least in my office) are great to work with, very laid back environment, and everyone knows their stuff.
cons: The employee review process is somewhat of a joke (if you're not one of the "important people" or in high visibility situations). Managers will give you no areas to improve upon, yet rate you low, give a low raise, and make you wait longer than necessary for a minor promotion. There is a high turnover rate because of this process.

review_title: Good Stable Job on the Right Contract but No advancement
pros: If you are on the right program then it's a safe and stable job.  I say that b/c in the aerospace industry the budget is always a hot topic and the contract can change.  Standard benefits and Paid time off accrual.
cons: Found it very difficult for upward mobility.  I was in 2 different locations w/ Northrop and for many years but never promoted.  You do get a standard raise most years but nothing great b/c of the matrix system they have to even out everyones pay.

review_title: Logistics Management Analyst
pros: Great company to work for!
cons: Nepotism, to many friend and high school friends, family members, boyfriends & girfriends working in the same sector

review_title: Nothing is perfect, but a great place to work
pros:
The people - best team I've worked with in a long time.  
Work life balance - the 9/80 schedule is brilliant, plus there is the capacity to work from home if you need to.  Great locations and offices.  
And my manager. Definitely in the grand final of best ever.
The vision - they definitely are always looking up and out. I love that.
cons:
Branching off from a US company causes some teething problems with Australian processes.   
Slow at times - approval from the USA -  see above re developing processes.  But that is absolutely not out of the ordinary for a big company.

review_title: Nice place to learn things/start career. Not sure about long term though.
pros: Best reason to work for NG is the variety of projects that the company is involved. If you are able to get involved in them you can learn a great deal. Working on a small team is probably a good deal as you can wear many hats.
cons: The nature of the work is mostly government related so you have to deal with a very very slow moving environment which can be annoying to anyone who wants to work in a fast paced environment. The company also has huge layers of bureaucracy. Seems like many employees are treated as replaceable parts. Compensation is just average. Like any government contractor they will pay you as low as possible.

review_title: Good management is key to your growth and career opportunities at Northrop Grumman.
job_title: Software Engineer V in Carson, CA
pros: As part of a large company, there are many projects and opportunities to find a niche.  Once you demonstrate competence and consistency, management is quick to recognize your contributions and give you any support that you feel is necessary.
cons: So much depends upon who your immediate supervisor and management are.  Perhaps as critical is the project that you are on.  We've had good people leave the company, not because of management or coworkers, but simply because the demands of our customer created an unworkable environment.

review_title: Why you should work at Nothrop Gurmman
pros: The PDP program allows you to rotate to different, disparate assignments before choosing your permanent position. You could do one rotation in Engineering, the next in Business and one in Sales. The people at NGES are extremely nice, professional and caring. A very relaxed environment for how challenging the work is allows you to feel fulfilled but not overwhelmed.
cons: There are really no downsides that I've seen as of yet, but I have only worked here for a few months. One of the potential downsides is the process of obtaining a security clearance as you will be interviewed and investigated extensively; but again its part of the job.

review_title: Great to work for if you are a VP
pros: Good prospects for growth. It is a good place to work once out of college because they put so much focus on new grads. But there is little attention paid to veteran employees who have spent their lives making the company successful. So, get a few years of experience and move on.
cons: Unless you are high in the management chain, there is little chance of making signifigant progress in the company. Even with a stellar year in new business, merit raises are poor.

review_title: Avoid
job_title: Field Engineer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Really difficult to find something positive.  Talent + for the one place to list employee career goals.  Now if management and talent acquisition would use this tool correctly to move employees around within the company like they should.
cons:
Benefit cuts.  Used to be 8% for a 401k match.  Dropped to 4%.  Healthcare skyrocketed.

More and more tasks were added to job jar.  Workers neither compensated or recognized for added tasks outside of job description.  Performing multiple jobs and only paid for one.

Talent Acquisition (TA) is woefully unskilled at finding talent within the company for placement in other positions.  Zero assistance or placement provided to skilled employees with varied backgrounds and degrees.  

Severe lack of communication from management at all levels.  Same issues are addressed yearly by a survey and nothing ever changes.

review_title: No direction
pros: The mission at NGC is ultimately to protect the United States, and this creates a shared sense of purpose and urgency. In general the facilities are well stocked with necessary equipment. The people are friendly and helpful.
cons: NGC puts people in mid-level management positions that have no desire or skill to be a manager. These people are also expected to continue to perform a technical job at the same time. The review process affects your raise with a numerical rating system, but the system is so poorly defined that managers can rank anyone based on personal preference instead of performance.

review_title: Systems Engineer
job_title: Systems Engineer I in Chicago, IL
pros: Working there can be interesting especially when diagnosing hardware. Some teams work better than others, and some managers don't always work well with each other. It's a hit or miss. Working with advanced hardware and you can be very outspoken when it comes to ideas. You've got room to grow if you are on the right team with the right manager.
cons: Some managers do not help you grow within the company and you must be very careful sharing your ultimate goal with them. If your goal doesn't align with the position or the managers vision, you may be in a fine line from being removed.

review_title: Stable Opportunity
job_title: Engineer III in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Northrop Grumman provides a stable career path to people out of college.  The company does take care of you and helps out with relocation or business travel.  Good environment to start your career.
cons: Compensation wasn't that good.  They sort of low balled me on the offer.  It was hard to get a promotion in the company, you almost have to relocate or change divisions.  You have to be lucky in where you are placed or who you get to work for to get the best learning opportunity and get raises.  If you are motivated, you can venture out and try learning outside of your work or transfer to a different department.

review_title: Good company overall, R&D gets lost in internal chaos
pros:
-Good salary 
-Benefits good except health care plan
-lot of opportunities on different programs
cons:
-Executive management is re-org happy, causes a lot of internal chaos that lower level people are left to deal with 
-Health plan is poor, especially for such a large company
-Low commitment to R&D
-Politic turf wars are common and easy to accidentally run afoul of

review_title: Stable but Slow
job_title: Systems Engineering Manager in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros:
Northrop Grumman is a great place to work if you are a seasoned professional who values your life outside your job. If you work overtime, you get overtime pay at 100%, which is fantastic. As is pretty standard for the Defense industry, there is a program called 9/80, whereby if you work for 9 hours a day, you get every other Friday off. It's pretty great. 

There some tuition reimbursement, but it is contingent on your manager approving it. Up to 6% 401(k) matching with a 3 year vesting cliff is nice as well.

Lastly, Defense is a very stable industry that will always be around and never outsourced, which gives you enormous job security.
cons:
Being a defense contractor, the pace of work is painfully-slow. Contracts are always delayed by months, which can be very frustrating for young professionals looking to make a splash in their career and stand out among the masses. 

Moreover, there is a huge problem with knowledge sharing. The old guard is retiring or getting grumpy at all the work they are doing to support their programs because their colleagues of 20-30 years are retiring. There is incredible disorganization in onboarding materials and no clear system for how to learn the way Defense work gets done. Directors will point you to intranet websites with broken links, and there are few human beings who are dedicated to your continuous learning. It's all on you to ask questions, which makes you feel like a pest.

Lastly, senior management feels immensely disconnected from frontline managers and their engineers. They talk in lofty terms without understanding how hollow and aimless their strategies are.

review_title: Northrop Grumman Aerospace Systems - A great place to work!
pros: I like the vision "To be the leader in preserving freedom and advancing discovery by providing our customers with innovative and affordable integrated air, space and ground solutions".  The Senior Management team does an excellent job in driving the performance of the Sector.  We have a tremendously bright future with many emerging opportunities on many exciting programs.
cons: As a large company there is a tendency to be too bureaucratic  in portions of the sector.  But this is not the case in all areas.

review_title: Civility and Loyalty Still Exist
pros:
They are not interested in rapid turnover of employees.
They will give you lots of responsibility.
They value loyalty, while understanding personal needs.
You can work on a diverse number of projects at once.
Good benefits and stability from the larger Corporation.
cons:
No big contracts this year (although they may have some in the next year).
Available skills training is mostly geared toward skills that would be used in the defense industry.
Their funding is subject to federal and Navy administration.
Long product development timelines.

review_title: Outstanding company.  They make you feel like part of the team, and motivate employees.
pros: Instead of threatening employees to comply with new policies, they try to get buy-in, and focus on team effort to achieve the goal.  This type of leadership philosophy separates them from many of their large competitors.  They strive to obtain highly trained professionals, and then keep them.
cons: The company is struggling to consolidate the acquisition of many companies into one company.  They are also trying to establish the focus of the company into the area of Global IT Security, and there is a lot of restructuring pain in the process.

review_title: Communications Systems Engineer in San Jose, CA
job_title: Systems Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Good facility, few very bright people.
cons: Low salary. Most engineers do not keep up with current technology. Management is out of touch with current technology and does not try to put the right people with the right skill sets in the right job.  Management is not generous on paying for technical training for their employees.  Their business is declining.  There are too much internal politics between various sites, work place bullying (taking credit for other people's work) is common.

review_title: Northrop Grumman provides a excellent work environment with great benefits.
job_title: Computer Systems Security Analyst III in Washington, DC
pros: I enjoy coming to work and being able to to work with other strong performers and provide a service to the government keeping it safe and secure by what I do on a daily basis.
cons: Learning the office politics inherit in government jobs, and not only educating yourself on these nuances but learning that navigating around roadblocks in successful mission accomplishment takes a lot of time and energy which often you have to self-learn if your in a remote assignment.

review_title: This company is completely overrated when it comes to diversity.
pros: 9/80, family time, pay, cafeteria food.
cons: Discriminating HR, incompetent management. They both work together to keep the employees that don't want to work or use their brain. They treat Union members like garbage. The professionals are highly underpaid, especially the engineers that are well educated and highly intelligent.

review_title: Recovery Support Specialist
pros: This company is made of hardworking employees who really care about the field. They foster hard work and compassion and I am happy to be working for them. The people they hire are all amazing and you really feel like you are on a team from the CEO to your co workers. They are making a difference! They also try recognize their employees hard work in any way they can, which is uncommon in this line of work.
cons: The turn over rate is high and can be emotionally draining but its overall rewarding. Can be frustrating work, but that is usually because the govt system is frustrating.. not the company.

review_title: Hostile Work Environments
pros: Job Security, every other Friday off
cons: The sexual harassment, ageism, and blatant disrespect for fellow humans within some teams on this campus is downright disgusting. They do whatever they want with you, with no regard to your individual goals. You’re there to meet a quota and that’s it. Respect for you as a professional adult is throw out of the window if you are younger than 35. I have been made fun of for being a millennial and a female many times, two things I can do nothing about. HR blatantly doesn’t care about employee satisfaction, they’re happy to let people leave, only for new suckers to take their place.

review_title: Typical small fish in the big pond
job_title: Level V Engineer  in Melbourne, FL
pros: NG still maintains a pension program along with a 401k (100% matching up to 4%).  Pay is reasonable (competitive) and the location can't be beat.
cons: Raises are predictable (3-5% based on performance).  They award a 2-3% bonus each year to avoid giving out larger raises.  The facilities are average at best.  Vacation starts at 12 days and only improves to 15 days after 10 years, 20 days after 20 years.  Recognition is infrequent and usually insignificant monetarily.

review_title: NGIS is a fantastic organization to work in - If you like exciting projects, this place is for you.
job_title: Engineer IV in San Diego, CA
pros: Many opportunities to do a lot of interesting things. NG Aeronautical Systems leads the way in the industry for developing unmanned systems. Global hawk, BAMS, Euro Hawk, Hunter, Fire Scout, UCAS, etc are fantastic programs. We get 2 weeks off during the Holidays, NG treats the employees pretty damn good.
cons: It is a huge organization, sometimes slow to act - it moves, you cant direct it, like an iceberg. There are often very lengthy processes that are not very transparent such as procurement. Why is IT and facilities approving my purchase of a workstation or server? No insight into the process at all. Big mystery.

review_title: Lack of Leadership. self-focused, bonus-motivated people in charge
pros: salary, benefits, working level people below the "VP-bonus" level.  there's great collaboration amongst the working level folks that just want to get the job done.  at the executive level, it breaks down - REALLY QUICKLY.
cons: seems like middle-senior management is SELF-FOCUSED - their bonuses.  they treat people under them like plow mules, no respect.  LOTS OF HOURS.

review_title: not competitive
pros: Cool Technology,  You work on and produce military products.  The new technology is exciting and challenging.   Thats of course when actual development was being performed and over the years this opportunity has dwindled away.
cons: You are not cared about as an individual.  Management will move you around without notice and since the business is declining, there is little to no opportunity to advance in your career.  You will not be rewarded for doing your job.

review_title: Limited Upward Mobility for Senior Employees
pros: Overall good place to work. Staff are overall extremely dedicated and professional. Provides ability to work with major USN unmanned air vehicle systems programs.
cons: Part of a small field office of a major DoD contractor company with minimal growth opportunity.  Less opportunity for advancement in the senior technical and management areas because it is not a major site.  Less visibility to key leadership that can enhance advancement opportunity.

review_title: NGC is A Better Place To Work Than Raytheon and Boeing!
job_title: Engineer V in San Diego, CA
pros: Involved in the development of leading edge unmanned aircraft systems.
cons: No professional growth.  Engineer V is the highest level.  I was hired in as Engineer V so for the rest of my career at NGC (may be the next 20 yrs) I will be Engineer V.  Lack of training.  Lack of investment in its employees (computer resources and tools to perform job).

review_title: Great first job, make sure to move around after a year.
job_title: Mechanical Engineer I in Newport News, VA
pros: The job security with working at Northrop Grumman Shipbuilding is very solid. Unless world peace breaks out the US Navy will continue to require Aircraft Carriers and submarines, our only two products at the moment. Additionally there are many different departments doing a wide variety of tasks that one can transfer into.
cons: My department is very micromanaged and I get very little interaction with people actual building what I put on paper. Also there is very little actual design experience to be had. All real design work is sent out to subcontractors and the engineers really only serve as ship integrators for each system. If you like project management this is your place.

review_title: If all you want is money...
pros: Good salary and cutting edge projects.
cons: Once you are hired you become a number. If you are geographically separated from the main offices you are on your own. Don't do anything wrong because the company does not believe in second chances or making mistakes even insignificant ones. Very much an "us and them" mentality...no common culture or concern for personnel. Too many people just taking up space and earning a salary. Team concept is only given lip service. No room for growth in smaller offices. They expect loyalty but none is returned.

review_title: Solid Job
pros:
Strong ethical culture. 
Flexible hours at some positions.
Decent benefits.
Many opportunities for advancement for those who want it.
Many good people.

Working conditions, benefits, hours, etc vary by sector, business unit, and even in the same building.
cons:
Benefits have declined a bit over time, and new employees are offered a bit less.
Frustrating corporate bureaucracy - shared services (payroll, HR, IT, etc) are accountable to no one and act like it - some good people in there, are some not-so-good.
SCA employees get less benefits.

For many years, this has been a great place to spend a career. More recently, this quality seems to have declined, with many moving on due to various frustrations.

review_title: Great Opportunities if you are willing to work hard
pros: NGC has come a long way in the 15 years that I have worked there.  There are more and more opportunities for advancement but you have to be willing to work hard and demonstrate competency.   The red tape and bureaucracy can be frustrating, but overall I love working at Northrop Grumman.  The company is ethical and values performance.  Having a great manager makes all the difference.
cons: Red tape and bureaucracy.  It's a challenge to hire enough qualified staff so we end up relying on the same people to do all the heavy lifting and risk burning them out.

review_title: The place where your career will stop...
pros: In general, the group which I worked with at Northrop Grumman IT was very close and collaborated a lot. The people that I worked with was the only reason I considered staying because I made friendships that have lasted for years.
cons: There is no career advancement opportunities. Management cannot tell you where your career will be headed. Along with raises which according to my manager didn't measure your performance or aptitude at the job only current market value, it became very hard to work with for people that didn't appreciate your skill set. There were people I worked with that had been doing their same job for decades with no room for advancement

review_title: ONE GOAL: WALL STREET
pros: Fellow employees are good, hard-working and well-intended.
cons: CEO's #1 focus is shareholders.   Management's #1 focus is their next promotion.   Salaries are stagnant and are often less than the Federal COLA's.  Bonuses go to the top 1%.  Promotions are politically driven within a "good ol' boy network."  Employees are expected to brag about their accomplishments at review time because managers are too busy promoting themselves to know what their staff are doing.  Seagull management style is rampant.

review_title: A failing company
pros: The actual engineering group is a nice group of people.
cons: The Newport office is the mistreated  stepchild of Northrop, all the bureaucracy of a big company,  none of the benefits.  The management is terrible and just biding their time till they can retire.  The company in general can't figure out what direction they want to go. They reorganize every couple of years,  fire some upper management,  then do it again a couple years later before they even have time to change anything.

review_title: Good Professional Company to Work
job_title: Supply Chan Planning Specialist in Woodland, CA
pros: Good salary and benefits, multiple programs, new businesses & good job security.  Promote diversity and inclusions. 9/80 work schedule is good.
cons: Company makes large profits; employees only gets 2% salary merit per year and high cost and out of pocket medical insurance deductible and out of pocket expenses

review_title: Great Company to Stay with for a Long Term Career
job_title: Industrial Security Analyst in Linthicum, MD
pros: The company overall is amazing.  I transitioned out of the military a few months ago and wondered how well it would go in corporate America.  This company and it's management, everyone from the higher-ups to my immediate supervisor is highly qualified and competent.  They show great care in hiring excellent individuals for their respective positions and the competency shows in how they run the various areas of the company.  Very flexible in work hours and it feels like they really work with the employees to retain talent once their in the company.
cons: Pay could always be higher, but I feel like that's at any job anyone would work anywhere.

review_title: A solid engineering job if you can deal with the inefficiencies
job_title: Test Engineer I in Newport News, VA
pros: Once you cut through the red tape the work is generally satisfying.
cons: It can be amazingly difficult to cut through the red tape and actually get to the work.  The processes we use can also be pretty ridiculous and wasteful, but I imagine to some extent that comes with the industry.  Opportunities for real advancement also seem few and far between but to be fair I have been with the company a relatively short amount of time so I certainly can't speak definitively.

review_title: A review of Northrop
job_title: Technical Intern in El Segundo, CA
pros: Love of airplanes, enjoy the opportunity to grow and find what you really want to do in a large company, great opportunity to try new things and see what you are the best at. The people are really great and allow you to work on different projects so you can try out different positions and work on different programs.
cons: It is difficult to get changes implemented. Also, defense is a very cyclical industry so it will always be up and down depending on how much money is being spent on defense. You work with government companies which tend to be slow.

review_title: Decent place to work
pros: If you work on a good product, the technology is great.  You rack up a lot of travel as well if you want.  There always seems to be travel required due to the nature of the products.  Some engineers have a fairly smooth time, while others depending on the project can be quite stressed.  The more talented you are, the more they work you.
cons: Pay is average or below.  Raises are very small.  Bonuses are project based and that can be political.  Average engineers get caught in the politics of the management.  A lot of the workers have accepted their fate and simply cruise on by.

review_title: Tough place to be successful
pros: Big, stable company. The checks don't bounce. Decent benefits, though in Jul;y 2012 they drastically increased the cost to employees for health insurance. This COULD BE a great place to work.
cons: All internal processes must comply with federal gov't standards and requirements, regardless of whether or not you are working on a fed project. As a result, working at NG is just like working at the DOD or any federal agency. Red tape, bureaucratic infighting and ridiculously complex and convoluted internal processes stifle the ability to get things done in a timely fashion. The customer is almost an afterthought to NG. Since I've been here, we've lost more deals due to our own internal incompetence and inability to deliver a timely proposal response than we have lost to genuine competition.

review_title: Pretty good work-life balance but relatively low pay and very limited opportunities for growth
pros: Surrounded by friendly, smart people, the work (of the company although not always of the individual) is meaningful and important. The navy and airforce customers are highly professional and knowledgeable. Work-life balance is one of the best aspects of the job with 9/80 (every other Friday off) schedule and a "work whenever to get your job done by the deadline" mentality.
cons: Funding issues, contract issues, poor management have gotten progressively worse over the 4 years of working here. Even work-life balance has suffered as people get laid off and contracts are bid at lowest possible price. Non-existent raises and promotions, very limited training opportunities (mostly online classes and brown bags).

review_title: the good, the bad, the truth
pros:
program managers are receptive to employee feedback
Great co-workers, great worker bees, some reminescent of the good old days of Aerojet when it was more design, now it is all red tape and tons of paperwork…
cons:
some functional managers are not receptive to employee feedback
HR doesn't do a good job of disciplining those managers with numerous complaints against them. they drag their feet and blame the fact that it is "One HR" and pass the buck to Baltimore because that is where headquarters is. Apparently Azusa HR are puppets with no power behind their words of "we will investigate and properly handle your case" (aka, throw it trash)

review_title: Systems Engineering, Integration and Test (SEIT)
pros:
Opportunities for growth if you're willing to put yourself forward (also see cons).

Flex-time schedule is fantastic for people with families. Also have the option to work 9/80.
cons:
Be prepared to hear, "no" a lot if you're looking to move upward.  Eventually the right person will hear and see your value.  I'm not sure if this is much different than most other companies.

Health benefits are sub-par.  Deductibles are now set at catastrophic care rates.

review_title: Program Cost Control Analyst
pros: Great place to work for a recent college graduate, job was slow pace. Staff was always friendly and willing to train on any issues. Software had funny quotes and comments when you would open it every time.  When software would crash after working on (or newly opened) received funny quotes ("It's all fun and games until you lose an eye"  "Don't run with scissors you may hurt yourself" "If it is not on paper, it does not count").  Good exposure to work with great engineers and project management team.  Good place to work, personally not interested in type of work.  Clean office.  Would highly recommend to a new college graduate.
cons: Need to spread out work on projects more evenly between staff.

review_title: Mechanical Engineer
pros: I really like the 9/80 schedule.  Not everyone onsite gets to enjoy this due to working overtime, but most do.  In my area I enjoy the experienced leadership that I work with and support in my job.  I believe the pay is very fair and Northrop does a good job of trying to find a place for you if work slows down in your area.
cons: There can be a tendency for some people to not get things done very quickly, which is sometimes a bit frustrating when you're trying to meet a schedule, but I'd much rather have that situation than what I've had in the past at other companies, where you're pushed so hard and fast that you can't plan or do a quality job.

review_title: So much potential, so much disappointment
job_title: Business Management Analyst in Aurora, CO
pros: Time off is relatively easy to get approved.
cons: Promotions are based solely on time in a position and have nothing to do with skill. The culture is toxic. It is extremely common for people to get reported to HR simply because others do not like them. "Salaried" really means salaried if you work overtime, and hourly if you work less, even if they don't have enough work for you.

review_title: So much potential, so much disappointment
job_title: Business Management Analyst in Aurora, CO
pros: Time off is relatively easy to get approved.
cons: Promotions are based solely on time in a position and have nothing to do with skill. The culture is toxic. It is extremely common for people to get reported to HR simply because others do not like them. "Salaried" really means salaried if you work overtime, and hourly if you work less, even if they don't have enough work for you.

review_title: Stuck in the past, little innovation, too much management.
job_title: Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
Exceptional work life balance. I was never asked to stay late. 40 hour work weeks, on the dot, plus the 9/80 schedule.

Higher management is competent, and responsive. If you can ever find time to get a hold of them.
cons:
Employees seem to just want to "do their hours" and get home. There's no passion for the product.

Too much middle management (and old middle range engineers), filled with self centered and arrogant people who have been in their positions for decades. You do it their way, or it doesn't happen at all. It's trickle down engineering. The higher ups make all the decision and there is no consideration given for ideas that come from below, regardless of their merit.

Engineers have seemingly been there forever. Some looked at me quizzically when I asked Java questions.

review_title: Great Company
pros: They offer great training opportunities and have great potential for growth and potential to transfer to other locations if desired.  They value their employees and recruit top talent.
cons: Compensation if above average for the area.  Benefits are comparable to most large companies.  There are several sectors which operate independently with different rules and procedures which can cause difficulties and confusion for employees, suppliers and customers.  It needs to be a more cohesive, streamlined organization.  The office space itself is not desirable - no real break area and crowed work spaces with no privacy.

review_title: Good experience overall (except last couple of years), good opportunities but be proactive if you find your job at risk
pros: Benefits are good, 9/80 work schedule, work is interesting, opportunities to learn, ease of moving within company, well managed, disciplined, good employee discount program
cons: Lately, particularly in the last couple of years, the company has focused far more on the bottom line than on developing and taking care of its employees.  Reorganizes/realigns often.  Work life balance - while my division had every other Friday off, it could have been executed better by staggering schedules rather than having the entire division off so that employees could truly enjoy their day off.

review_title: Nine Years and still counting
pros: Knowing that what I do can make a difference in the security of this country makes the job worth it.  Great company to work for - work/life balance is a nice plus.
cons: HR is awful.  This department needs an overhaul.  Treat your employees like you would want to be treated.

review_title: Program Cost and Schedule Analyst II
pros: Helpful and supportive direct management.  Generally work with friendly peers.  If you are looking for a stable job to put in 40 hour weeks with great job security this is a good fit.
cons: Growth opportunities (both financially and professionally) are mostly below average.  The culture is not very positive and no one really likes their job.  Upper management can treat more junior employees disrespectfully.  Because of the job stability, poor processes, and lack of incentive to perform well employees don't always try their best.

review_title: Launching pad to successful career in Aerospace Industry
job_title: Industrial Engineer in Saint Augustine, FL
pros: Northrop Grumman began to position itself to become an elite company in the Aerospace industry by making organizational and procedural changes across all divisions. This is a great company to start your career. Though your compensation is not always what you deserve, you will enjoy excellent health care benefits despite of increasingly high health care costs, 9/80 or 4/10 schedules, rewarding 401K options, tuition reimbursement, and exceptional paid vacation scheme.
cons: Some facilities in the AS division are located in isolated areas of the country where you may not find a fulfilling social life; typical goverment bureaucracy culture still present in some organizations; unless you're extremely well qualified, you will have to play politics to be promoted;

review_title: Technical Writer
pros: Northrop Grumman is a good company to work for if you are a recent graduate. They have several internship positions for various career fields and interest. Full-time employees have the opportunity to continue their education  with financial assistance, up to 10K per academic year and full access to premiere Lynda.com.
cons: Northrop Grumman provides lots of opportunities to sharpen your skills, great benefits, networking events, and more, however getting the word out about all that NGC has to offer falls a little short at times. Awesome company though!

review_title: EHS Engineer
pros: At Christmas we usually have one week as our Holiday PTO. You can extend the holiday by using personal PTO. Most salary EHS Engineers work 9/80 work week so every other Friday off which is approximately 26 more days off than the typical company.  PTO for new employees is 120 hours which is usually better than other industries but aligns with other aerospace companies. Some locations, and departments allow you to have flexibility in your schedule. Salary is better than other aerospace companies, benefits are pretty good. 401K match is outstanding, superior of that of the competition.
cons: The organization is very complex. It takes a long time to understand how everything all fits together. Although a technical company, technology used for the job seems to be subpar.

review_title: The company is changing, some good, some bad
pros:
9/80 schedule
Predictable promotion scheme
Good work life balance
Due to the recent hiring surge I would recommend only looking at reviews from 2018 going forward, its not the same company as before.
cons:
HR department is truly terrible, do not trust them
Frustrating bureaucracy
Everyone works in a different building, which kills cooperation/collaboration
They recently changed the education benefit rules, very few people get these benefits now

review_title: Not a bad place to work, really.
pros:
The benefits are great and the pay is decent. 
The company provides a good educational reimbursement plan which has recently been harmonized across the corporation. 
Health and dental coverage options are varied and provide choices to meet most of your needs. 
The company also offers the option to purchase an extra week of vacation each year, which is a nice perk.
cons:
There is a definite lack of career growth for non-engineering types and employees receive too few personal/sick days. 
There is also a definite lack of stability in defense contracting (as in all business sectors at this point in time).

review_title: Great people to work with, up and down the chain of command.
job_title: Program Manager in San Diego, CA
pros:
Great products, great technology, great people.  Good pay, and good educational benefits. 

401k matches plus the company retirement saving account (stay at least 3 years), multiple health insurance plan to choose from, etc.

Manager is great to work with, very understanding, easy to talk to.

For a large company, within a program, the structure is fairly flat, at least in the Aerospace Sector.
cons:
At upper middle management levels, unclear what the career track is.  Some programs take an inordinate amount of dedication and time (hard to balance work), while others are simpler.   
Not easy to change projects.

review_title: Good, Interesting work
job_title: Director, Business Development in McLean, VA
pros: Large company -- many opportunities exist to make lateral transitions and expand your career
cons: The company is large enough that it has to manage by the numbers -- it can't take care of individual employees like it did in the past.  Your career development is 100% on your shoulders and your continued employment is 100% on the company's shoulders.  In all fairness, I was layed off by this company and it was a total surprise to me at the time which clouds my review.

review_title: Some unique perks, but limited long term growth
pros:
some amazing critical thinkers and managers
co-workers were on the older side, but also empathetic & help you succeed ("I have a son your age....")
9/80 schedule is amazing. great 401K, one of the few companies that still offer post grad tuition reimbursement (with 2 year commitment upon graduation)
cons:
Promotion isnt necessarily merited by performance alone - seniority is a large factor and not much to aspire to
The company is enormous -- it'd take years to truly understand the process by which a product is delivered.
Longevity isn't guaranteed - gone are the heydays of 20-year contracts.

review_title: The Rolling Meadows campus can be described as a windowless bunker that is as mid-managed as its buildings aesthetics.
job_title: Supply Chain Planner in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros: They have Friday’s off every other week and that’s about it. There are okay 401k benefits with company matching. Not much else.
cons:
Anyone not an engineer is severely underpaid. You have to wait 3 years to even be considered in moving up in a pay grade. This means there is no incentive to meet the objective requirements and gain the necessary skills because you’re up against time. They don’t listen to employees feedback. In fact, in the employee survey that is taken every year my manager got the results, reviewed them with us, and then told us to come up with plans to solve them. 

I would advise any non-engineer to steer clear of this campus. Not a good place to build a career by any means.

review_title: Large company with many opportunities, and all the politics and red tape you can eat!
pros: Large degree of opportunity to climb the corporate ladder and work on amazing projects for those willing to put in the effort to network and play the bureaucratic games.
cons: It can be difficult to stomach the wasted spending and loafers who do the minimum effort required.  Do you read Dilbert comics?  Yeah, they're all true.

review_title: Good people, horrible working conditions.
job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Sterling, VA
pros: The people are great. The projects are awesome. The pay is ok.
cons: The pay is just OK. I work in a building that has around 300 people and 9 bathroom stalls. I've seen cleaner bathrooms at a music festival. The building is kept at 50 degrees F year round. My team tried asking management to help get the building warmed up and we were told to bring jackets. People are crammed into offices and tiny work spaces in hallways with no windows. I'm forced to work in a room that has no wifi and 4 hard lines, we share internet access.

review_title: Good money and  work life balance, poor management.
pros: Flexible schedule with offsetting time. 4/10 schedule allows to have 3 day weekends. Good pay and benefits
cons: Poor management. Engineering in a high production rate has caused a toxic work environment. Old school engineers need to know how to not be hot headed and solve an issue calmly. Training is NON EXISTENT in Northrop and results in a lot of wasted time and money. Culture can be really good or really bad. Lack of accountability has lead to problems never being corrected by those who create them.

review_title: Interesting work.
job_title: Software Engineer V in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: There are many interesting projects, and there is quite a bit of stability if you perform well and are highly regarded by your superiors and peers.
cons: Large company with quotas for promotions, good evaluations, and lack of taking care of good employees and making sure their salaries meet or exceed the industry averages. There are quite a few people in this industry that come to work for the paycheck and sit around doing nothing or less than they are capable of doing because they will not get fired unless projects get cancelled and are laying off.

review_title: Good place to work if you just care about flexibility, but not so much if you want to work on innovative products.
job_title: Software Engineer III in Carson, CA
pros: Time is very flexible and the atmosphere is laid back.  We have a 9/80 schedule that allows us to take every other Friday off.
cons: Little opportunity for growth and creativity.  I find myself doing the same thing over and over again for every task.  Most of my energy is spent dealing with politics rather than developing.  If you work here and want to retain your intelligence, I suggest doing a side project to keep your mind fresh.

review_title: Great Place
pros:
Management Involvement is top notch for me, they seem like they care about my advancement in my field
Benefits are better than most in the same industry, very good 401k w/ matching. Medical benefits seems to be on par with average
Work/Life Balance management is flexible on when and where empolyees work, which can be helpful is saving the much needed vacation hours for an actual vacation
cons:
Compensation seems to not be too competitive, especially when earning professional degrees or certificates while empolyeed. Seems like you need to leave the company and come back in order to advance in position and salary
Managment Knowledge- older workforce in the IT security field, they dont seem to keep up with trends, which makes it harder to get management backing on various projects
Sometimes Long Hours

review_title: Not a place to work!
job_title: Software Engineer I in McClellan, CA
pros: 9 hour day shifts, every other Friday off. Flexibility.
cons:
Toxic environment to work. Legacy software with no documentation at all. Go Fish mentality. They throw you in the water and if you swim, you survive. Not a collaborative environment. People hold their knowledge (job security) and you get clues instead of answers when you try to resolve problems. You can go in circles for days trying to get an answer for a simple question or problem you need to solve in the system. There are only few people who know the system. All the others do not work there anymore.
Defense industry depends on politics. At the meetings, managers forecast all the great opportunities and contracts to come but in reality they didn't have much. Defense industry has a lot of up and downs. Hence, lot of layoffs.

review_title: Trying to rebuild, but struggling to adapt
job_title: Project Manager in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: If you're an engineer of some sort, your work can be really interesting and important.  If you're not an engineer, it's much harder to find positions that offer any kind of new/exciting work.  As most people have said, it's a decent place to build experience if you have no better options; just don't expect to really build anything lasting.
cons: A select few executives are really making an effort to bring NG into the 21st century, but they are being constantly battled by an entrenched core of management who do everything they can to stymie any progress.  These mediocre managers are good at playing the bureaucracy and political games, so they don't want to see meritocracy take hold.  The company claims to want the best and brightest (to compete with the likes of Google and Apple), but they aren't willing to invest the resources to compete (salaries, bonuses, perks, etc).  It's tough on morale because you hear all these awesome goals for the company, but then you watch each initiative slowly starve from lack of funding, lack of progress and lack of follow-through.

review_title: Rolling Meadows Location
pros: Large company with several job opportunities for mainly lateral movement. The ability to flex work times and 9/80 schedules is great. Tuition assistance offering is higher than similar companies.
cons: Culture has been to promote by tenure without considering qualifications or capability. As a top hiring company for veterans, there's a lack of support and appreciation for reservists . It's frowned upon when it's time to go on any orders during the work week. There's no real emphasis of work-life balance by immediate management, but it's advertised throughout the company.

review_title: Company is out of touch...Junior engineers beware: cuts to education assistance.
job_title: Mechanical Engineer in El Segundo, CA
pros:
-Semi stable assignments
-experienced senior staff
-classified programs
-flexible work times
-possible to transfer departments with some effort.
cons:
-corporate management is out of touch with employees.
-accountability is not a priority.
-profits most important at end of day.
-uncompetitive salary/raises.
-hurry up and wait

-education assistance keeps getting cut. NEW GRADS BEWARE: education assistance benefit cut to $10K per year Jan 1, 2020. If you are expecting to study for a Master's degree while working, you may be served better elsewhere. Employees in the middle of a master's program will not be grandfathered in, meaning multiple hundreds of employees are being stuck with massive out of pocket costs and others are contemplating dropping their programs. Others are now dissuaded from starting in the first place because of this change.

review_title: NGES - Lots of opportunities if you are a self-starter.
job_title: Business Development Manager in Baltimore, MD
pros:
Opportunity to work with many brillant minds.  Cutting edge advanced defense technology.  Large organization with many opportunities for interesting work.
That said, employees need to definitely take charge of their own career.  NGES does have some outstanding leadership and developmental opportunities, but not all supervisors are aware of them, nor will they necessarily go out of their way to recommend them.  It is also important to build strong cross division and cross functional alliances so that you can take charge of your career progression and next job opportunity within NGES.
cons: Seemed as if there was a reorganization always occuring.  Culture could have been better at valuing customer needs over corporate profits.

review_title: "B" - good potential, needs improvement
pros: NGES tries to build a team towards long-term objectives, versus the typical short-term hire-for-the-current-contract-at-hand narrowsightedness of most defense contractors
cons: It's a company of engineers for engineers...  Most others are 2nd class employees unless you're related to people in high places or connected to the Old Boy Network of Westinghouse alumni...  A mere cog in a giant machine...

review_title: Overseas Living is Fun!
pros: If you can secure work overseas it's a great way to travel the world and live on the economy BUT have the reach-back capability of the U.S. military base (APO/FPO box, BX, etc...) If you get on the right contract it can be very rewarding. NGIT will also work with you to secure employment at another location if you lose coverage.
cons: Lack of training, lack of upward career progression. To be fair most contracting companies have the same problem. Moving from contract to contract can be a drag but some people like that sort of thing.

review_title: Great Company!
pros: As an engineer, Northrop Grumman has a very long list of career opportunities.  They are one of the top Defense companies in the world.  If you are interested at all in engineering / sciences, they offer some job that you will find exhilarating and stability that is hard to find in other industries.
cons: The one downside they do have (and this may not be the opinion of everyone) is that they are such a large company that communication across all levels is not as easy as it would be in a smaller company.

review_title: So of the best professional experience I have ever had in my career.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Sierra Vista, AZ
pros: For the team I was on - great synergy, always worked with the latest technologies. Some of the things we developed were very progressive and innovative - leading edge stuff. That had a lot to do with the customers and their missions.
cons: For that particular project, not enough space for all the people who worked on the project. It got better with time though. I think fewer retired military in senior positions would have made a big difference too.

review_title: Challenging but management lacks direction
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Little Rock, AR
pros: Interesting projects to work on.  Sense of purpose with each project completed. Laid back atmosphere.  Not the typical boys club mentality like many software companies.  Decent bonuses for projects completed on or before schedule.  Great benefits.  For all the frustrations I had, I really liked the company and would work there again.
cons: Unbalanced work/home life.  Management does not take care of dead weight leaving the employees that get the job done, no matter what it takes, to be frustrated.  Lower than average wages for the area, with little opportunity for promotion.

review_title: Interesting and challenging work
pros:
On the space side of the business, NG retains capabilities and expertise to build in house if it chooses to do so.  Company and space programs really drive problems and issues to the ground (get to root cause).  Thus there is always unique and challenging issues that crosses many disciplines and it is always rewarding to see how these issue are finally resolved.
Has 9/80 work schedule.
cons:
Basic philosophies or business model for a space program/product and airborne program/product do not mix for the simple fact space products are not repairable or serviceable.  Just don't know how NG (functional management) is planning to organize/segregate the company with respect to space and airborne/avionics. 

Services within the company  (IT, Benefits, Security) are being relegated to automated or web based.response systems.

review_title: 5 years of wasted time.
job_title: Field Engineer III in Buffalo, NY
pros: The pay and benefits were good.
cons:
* untrained managers
* If issues arise more concerned with placing blame and you will be put on the naughty list if you deviate.

review_title: Going Down Hill Fast
job_title: Program Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Ability to move around within the company
cons:
Good Ol' Boy Network Rules, regardless of how incompetent they are.
The good ol' boys make sure they get the incentive pay, regardless of their performance,
at the expense of their employees, frequently changing the rules after the fact.
The minions get little to none. Broad Sector Incentives have been chopped.
They are shedding experienced mid level management (the people who do all of the heavy lifting) by the thousands.
Work environment is poor at best.

review_title: Great place for your career to die.
job_title: Software Engineer IV in San Diego, CA
pros: Steady work.  Can't have your job off-shored.  Flex time and 9/80 schedule is nice.
cons: Chances are that you will do boring, mundane grunt work most of the time.  There are a few opportunities to actually get your hands on new things and to actually write a new application but those are rare.  Mostly it's fixing bugs, porting those fixes to various base-lines, and doing grunt work like Fortify analysis and fixes.   But on the plus side, at least you won't be paid very well. .

review_title: Program Cost Control
job_title: Program Cost Control Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I've been there almost 20 years. Can't complain. My tiny merit increases over the years amounted to a lot over time. I had a couple big ones, that over time, helped a lot.  I'm paid well now. I always find my job is as good as my immediate manager. I've had 2 bad apples out of 15 or so
cons: People are hired at lower salaries now. Merit increases are much smaller. Hard for me to get a promotion I deserve, managers are limited in promoting people because of policies at higher levels.

review_title: Good place to work
pros: Highest pay that I've seen in that entire area.  Very good benefits.  Co-workers are nice if you get on the right crew
cons: Leaving the parking lot in the afternoon is a nightmare.  Most times I just sat in my car and waited 45 minutes till the traffic cleared out.  Tough work depending on what your job is in the yard.  Lots of "white hats" wandering around wanting to tell you what you should and shouldn't be doing

review_title: Review of Intern Program
pros: Great events and workshops put on for the interns, lots of opportunities to see many parts of the company, diverse work assignments, especially in Space Park, there are tons of fun events and a great community to be a part of!, you will most likely receive a return offer
cons: Easy to get overlooked as an intern or run out of tasks to do, often won't know what you would be working on until the first day, which unfortunately, some interns don't end up enjoying their project or task

review_title: Graphic Artist
job_title: Graphic Artist in Rancho Bernardo, CA
pros:
- Great colleagues; they love their own occupation and staff is very friendly and understanding when being a rookie and getting used to the daily system rhythm there. 
- I learn something different every day 
- Dedication and hard work, merit is highly praised recognized.
- They're strong advocates of skill enrichment and have already been on travel 3 times withing my 1st year as a Full-time Employees.
- I started out as a Contractor for 7 months, and then turned Full-time.
cons: Nothing negative, I love working for Northrop Grumman. I love the respect that they have for our troops and veterans. Everyone is respectful that I've encountered so far.

review_title: Working in Australia Business
pros: Part of the US based Northrop Grumman Corp, NG in Australia is growing and the company seemed to be investing in good leaders; employee benefits and safety. Servicing the defense sector can be demanding but the people are motivated and there is a big emphasis placed on doing business ethically. There is work going into improvements in facilities ,  IT and processes to mature the working environment.
cons: Some of the processes can be bureaucratic  and increased freedom from the US parent company would allow us to better serve our customers.

review_title: Working in Australia Business
pros: Part of the US based Northrop Grumman Corp, NG in Australia is growing and the company seemed to be investing in good leaders; employee benefits and safety. Servicing the defense sector can be demanding but the people are motivated and there is a big emphasis placed on doing business ethically. There is work going into improvements in facilities ,  IT and processes to mature the working environment.
cons: Some of the processes can be bureaucratic  and increased freedom from the US parent company would allow us to better serve our customers.

review_title: Overall Northrop Grumman is a decent place to work.
job_title: Software Engineer in El Segundo, CA
pros: Northrop Grumman offers onsite classes for continuing education.  This offers opportunity to learn things.  It has decent benefit packages as well.  They have good work and life balance, and flexible schedule.  The one week company shutdown at the end of the year is nice too.
cons: Northrop Grumman is a large company.  You feel like a small fish in the ocean.  Some decisions are made based on politics.  I seen some bad managements and people who should not be in management role.

review_title: NGMS high intensity but quick burnout.
pros: The best reason to work for NGMS is to get your foot in the door with defense contract support.  There are many opportunities to take courses offered by the company. The company also offers tuition reimbursement if your degree is approved.
cons: The downside of working at NGMS at my particular location was the odd long hours; unfortunately overtime was not paid until you had 16 hours of overtime in a pay period and no opportunity to take it as comp time.

review_title: Great company; lots of room to move around and grow. Not always the most secure place to work though.
pros: Great company overall. There are lots of opportunities to move around, the other employees are great.
cons: Senior management is not very open with information. Defense contracting means you often don't know if you will have a job 6 months or a year from now. Corporate policies can be intense but not all offices enforce all of them. Not getting this or that contract may mean you get 'moved around' against your will. I also didn't think they compensated enough for jobs based in expensive locations.

review_title: NGIT
pros: NGC is a great company to grow with.  The longer you stay, the better it gets.  The best part is the people, everyone from jr. level to upper sr. management is really nice and respectful of you.  Also, knowing you work for a company that helps our country stay safe is def. a morale booster.  Plus they design some really cool stuff!
cons: It's a big company, and like all other big companies, it is easy for you to feel like just a number.  Experience is definitely valued more than smarts, and if you are a jr. person, you are not encouraged to think on your own.  Thinking outside the box is ignored.

review_title: started great; ended miserable
pros: pay and benefits.. most of the people are wonderful.
cons: I am still haunted and upset. If you get the wrong boss watch out. nothing is fair.. all politics.  Never go to HR for help.  They always take managers side.  Fit in with the culture.  Keep your mouth shut, do your job, and go home.  Never try to shine... you will be sorry.  I worked harder and longer.  My boss was threatened and found a way to get me out.  My first boss was a dream come true.  Second boss nightmare. She made up lies, was condescending, and only got the job after 30 years because she was a woman.  Terrible micromanager who didn't care about company.. only cared about saving her own skin and being right.

review_title: Mediocre company with average benefit/pay and no work life balance
job_title: Senior Digital Engineer in Baltimore, MD
pros: Overtime pay can help you financially.
cons: Most project managers have no idea what it takes to design a product. Often make unrealistic schedules and the team is forced into working a ton of overtime. The benefit is mediocre. if compared to the private sector. The company has no real attraction to keep young talents for long term career commitment. Almost all of the top notch people that joined the same time I did are gone.

review_title: NG
job_title: Supervisor, Staff Engineer, Technical Test Lead and Proposal Lead in Charlottesville, VA
pros: People, work was interesting, most of the time we were busy.  Pay was good with excellent benefits.  Technology was top notch and up-to-date.  Tools were excellent and current and well maintained.
cons: Managers sucked, never enough time to complete jobs, schedule always dictated and quality suffered.  Decisions were always made in a vacuum with little input from the people doing the work and knowing the job better than anybody else.

review_title: The Way Aerospace Should Be
pros: Northrop Grumman is on the cutting edge of technology and design, and fosters new, young perspectives maintaining  experienced people as mentors. The combination leads to bright, motivated people who are able to bring forth "next generation" products and designs.
cons: Work/life balance and benefits are not what they once were. Pensions are a thing of the past, although their was an increase in starting wages, and several excellent savings plans to compensate.

review_title: Not as Good as they Used to Be
pros: Most of the people I ever worked with are hard-working, dedicated, and loyal to NG.
cons: In the past IT managers were also hard-working, dedicated, and loyal to NG, but not anymore. They are more concerned with micromanaging than anything. Too much infrastructure may be to blame for this. Not as many career opportunities as there used to be. Benefits have severely declined over the past decade.

review_title: Large Company swallowed up several smaller "good places to work."
job_title: Principal Systems Engineer in Washington, DC
pros: Large company with many project possibilities and locations for employment.  Excellent mentor program for new college grads and children of employees.  Many opportunities for in house training and some external training fund are available.  Ease of moving from one project to another as long as you don't mind long commutes.
cons: Large company with little "personal" attention to YOUR career.  Automated job research system not helpful in finding follow-on work when your contract ends (and all contracts eventually come to an end!)  Performance review process is proforma rather than really helpful in guiding you career growth.  Raises are usually low ... Get a good salary package when you start!

review_title: Insights to NGES
job_title: Senior Manufacturing Engineer in Annapolis, MD
pros: Pride in the systems being designed and built. Tuition reimbursement policy. Opportunities to see systems in the field. Travel opportunities. Opportunities to work with other Northrop Grumman divisions and sites.
cons: Stagnate environment. Limited career paths and opportunity for advancement. Outdated management philosophy. Management rewards years of service and long hours rather then performance and skills. Lip service given to work/life balance. A clear tier two provider with no real aim or pathway to grow the company. Travel policies lag similar defense contractors. Benefits lag other defense companies. Limited opportunities to excel technically or climb management ranks. Lack if transparency in hiring practices.

review_title: Great place to work when you have some connections
pros: Great company, takes care of it's people when it can. Great vacation during winter shutdown. Many have flexible work schedules. Great work environment. Great people to work with. Everyone that works there thinks in more or less the same direction. Lots of great perks and they do not underpay. 9/80 work schedule is amazing. Management is great for the most part, especially at the lower level. You can work there for an entire career and still find the work very interesting and rewarding.
