review_title: It has been the best 16 years of my working life!
pros: They are very competitive in the DoD market and look out for their employees. Compensation and Benefits are above the norm.
cons: Defense contracting leads to a very unstable outlook in future years. Your only as stable as the contract your on and the one you need to be bringing in to ensure your longevity.

review_title: Proud to be with NGC
pros: Northrop is one of the only Fortune 100 companies with a clean record. We are a company that is proud of our moral behavior, and we would rather lose a contract than violate our ethics. While competitors may offer more financial incentives, NGC offers employees a clean conscience.
cons: Northrop is not known for particularly strong benefits. We certainly do not lead the industry in paid time off; however, the work we do is more rewarding than a vacation.

review_title: Robust transition experience from senior military officer to mid-level manager in a major corporation
job_title: Project Manager in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: You are hired for your demonstrated ability to get the job done, company gives you significant room for professional autonomy which not giving you too much room to cause serious financial harm, I came into corporate world expecting to be "spoon fed" training on how to perform at the PM level and being a profit and loss entity individual training dollars are tight so you are left with a lot of OJT or self training.
cons: Too little resources for new hires (managers) to get acquainted with the corporate's tools and procedures

review_title: So much disappointment and frustration after four years in engineering at Northrop – Rolling Meadows.
pros:
Opportunity to work on some fascinating technology.

Opportunity to do some real hands-on engineering work.
cons:
There is entirely too much management at this company.  There are Engineering Project Managers, Program Managers, Logistics Program Managers, Engineering Functional Managers, the list goes on.  There is an overabundance of people trying to direct the work, and never enough people who are actually doing the work.

Engineering Supervision (Engineering Functional Management) is almost completely broken.  These people are the direct supervisors of the engineering staff, and have an outsize effect on the quality of work coming from the engineering organization.  And yet, they are consistently staffed with people who are duplicitous, incapable of critical thought, and unwilling to stand up for their people.

The constant push for more diversity has gone completely out of control.  People are hired not because of their skills, but because of their gender or race.  Unqualified people are promoted up the ranks in order to fill a diversity quota.  It’s maddening how much this occurs, and incredibly frustrating.

Compared to other defense contractors, there is a very small number of military veterans working here.  This is true at both the worker-level, and in the management ranks.  Military experience isn’t valued.  Very strange for the defense industry.

Programs and projects are always in a state of chaos.  The only way things ever get done is via last-minute scrambles.  Management treats this as the norm, and the “way things have always been done.”  Efforts to institute some semblance of planning always fall on deaf ears.

For the past couple years, there has been a significant trend in engineering staff.  People start here early in their careers, many fresh out of school.  They start very motivated and dedicated, but after 3-5 years, they all leave for elsewhere, bitter and jaded from the experience.

review_title: Great Place to Work But Depends on the Management
job_title: Systems Engineer II in San Diego, CA
pros:
Great career advancement opportunities if you're open to relocate to one of the corridors. (NOVA or Southern California)
Some of the brightest engineers I've ever worked with.
cons: As a defense contractor, you're consistently looking for new work based on contracts closeouts. If you're a high performer, this is not an issue but you may have to work a program/project that you may have no particular interest in.

review_title: Dependable and laid-back, but not exciting for young hires
pros: Since it's a large reputable company, you never have to worry about job security. Work-life balance is also great, as I work regular 40 hour weeks, no more and no less. Compensation is on par with other technology companies in the same class, so very average. There isn't really anything special about Northrop.
cons: I'm a young professional recently removed from college, so the biggest con is the company culture. The average employee age is probably the same as my parents, and the culture is old-fashioned. Don't expect employee events like Tequila Fridays or any other exciting company-sponsored things.

review_title: Continuous change of leadership and direction: Good for some not for others
pros:
With the continuous change of leadership and business model there is opportunity for people with certain skills to gain promotion and recognition. 

The people here are great to work with. 

Good place to learn and gain experience.
cons:
Constant restructuring of the organisation and business model is an issue. People are put in roles where they are not equiped for success.

Once you have broadened your expereince and skills there is not a definitive next career step. Many skilled people have left over the years who would have been fantastic employees to keep.

review_title: Software Engineer
pros: DTO comes in handy but not all sectors carry it. Non-capped tuition reimbursement policy (huge plus). Flexibility to change projects every so often. Casual/business casual dress for some offices.
cons: Lower to mid-range engineering salaries for some positions. No workspace available; engineers forced to share small cube space. A lot of the areas are device-free zones so for those walking around with ipods and such get used to not carrying them around all the time.

review_title: Good for a short term position
pros: 9/80 work week  Does have a tight screening process on hiring employees - so work force is well qualified. Does have and use training budget - so an employee can learn certain skills.
cons: Eliminated pension in 2008.  Has a 401K plan that is not very employee frriendly.  People hired pre-2008 can get a company match of 4%, but have to contribute 10% of their salary to get the Northrop 4%.  People hired after 2008 get a 6% match, but conditions are also hard to meet in order to get the full 6%.  Matching conditions are not easily discoverable.  Raise pool over time has become very unfriendly to employees.  Performance appraisal process is not connected to salary.  Employees get ranked based on how they meet their goals.  Then the company decides on a yearly basis what percentage of employees need to be ranked as Level 5, 4, 3 or 2.  Level 5 employees can get a decent raise, even in the 10% range.  But about 1/2 of the employees get a 0% raise - because so many people have to be ranked Level 3.  Then the salary decides what raise the person gets - if the employee makes over the mid-point salary of the employee grouping, the raise is likely to be 0% for all Level 3 employees.  This is incredibly demotivating for employees: they can work hard, meet or exceed all of their goals, and still get a 0% raise.  Years ago the company implemented a policy that disallows brining personal plants to the office - to eliminate using Northrop water for a personal plant.  Benefits costs are skyrocketing as the company tries to eliminate money it spends on employee benefts.  However, Northrop is truly a 1% company.  Executives are treated much differenty than non-management.  VPs and above receive large salary increases, as well as bonuses - while ~50% of the normal people get 0%.  Over years, the company has eliminated many grade levels - making it very difficult to get promoted.  It is a good company to work at for 2 - 3 years, but not for 10 or more.

review_title: Get in as a higher level engineer (Entry level not advised)
pros: The 9/80 scheduling is really nice, and you get the last week of the year off. Flexible scheduling, and the ability to work from home if need be. Pay is also excellent.
cons: Not advised for entry level as training, and knowledge retainment is a major problem. It's a very sink or swim environment, with leads generally to bogged down with work to offer a clear cut "mentor" status.  Had a member on my team that had worked weekends since they started. Work/Life balance is quite hit or miss, just depends on the team you're placed on.

review_title: Think twice

Free Coffee

great co-workers

review_title: Overall, A Great Place to Work, But...

review_title: Northrop Grumman -  Mixed on Satisfaction as an Employer

review_title: Fantastic experiences, highly intelligent staff, great benefits......overall a great place to work!
pros:
Cutting edge technology
Great people
Diverse assignments
Technical Breadth and Depth
Above average benefits
Honorable Mission
cons: Staffing shortfall causes many individuals to work excessive overtime.  Difficult work/life balance in some instances.  Large company and facility can make it difficult to know the experts.  Due to the high degree of technical expertise in product areas people become highly stovepiped.

review_title: More integration, less development
pros:
Good work life balance.
Depending on the project you are on, there could be some really fun and smart people to work with.
cons:
Low pay
Decreasing benefits
Inept middle managers
Every year there would be funding problems causing you to use vacation days to fill the gap in funding.
There were more managers on projects than engineers.
Yearly increases are limited to 10% unless approved by a VP. Which will never happen.

review_title: Business Management Intern
pros:
This is strictly a review for the summer internship program. I am very thankful for the internship.
-Competitive pay
-Not very stressful
-Strong company name and connections
-Easy to network
-Many baby boomers retiring soon so more open positions
cons:
-Many inefficiencies in the company
-Lots of different managers 
-Amount of work is extremely varied (too much or too little at once)
-Some of the older employees are bad with change or new procedures
-Could have learned more

review_title: NGC
job_title: Human Resources Manager and Business Partner in Carpinteria, CA
pros: Northrop has a noble purpose and sense of mission.  C4ISR  technology that saves lives and makes a difference everyday throughout the world.
cons: Roller coaster ride with the ups and downs of defense contracts won and lost.  Best to have a long legged program to build your career on.

review_title: Mediocre place to work
pros: Mostly a stable place to work. There are opportunities to work on cool tech, but they can be hard to find. Undergoing a generational change (like many big old industrial companies). There are pockets of youth and good people.
cons: Facilities are old and out of date. Few perks. They will pay you as little as they can get away with. Leadership is uninterested in employee well-being. Weighed down by crank-turner worker bees who will never be fired.

review_title: A good job for someone who is happy taking a big paycheck home for little work.
pros:
Company name is strong in the market right now. You are valued much more highly outside of the company with NG experience. 

The people are generally nice and friendly. 

Management is keen on addressing employee concerns. Lots of surveys and employee feedback efforts. 

"Business" casual attire which means casual at NGC

Pay is higher than most other companies.
cons:
Work is not challenging at all, especially for entry level positions. Even if you are capable and willing of taking on more challenging work, they don't have enough work to go around. They recruit individuals with high GPAs and strong academic backgrounds just to sit in cubes and surf the Internet. 

There is a large retiring population that is heavily compensated for doing very little work. It is demoralizing for younger employees that senior professionals just come into work to collect a paycheck. 

Nepotism is everywhere, especially in entry level hiring (intern/PDP). Most everyone is related to someone. 

Tuition assistance is nothing like it used to be. Lots of fancy verbiage used to sugarcoat the program so that a lot of entry level professionals are incentivized to work for the company.

Lots of office gossip and backbiting. Directors can be overheard gossiping about other employees. 

The work culture is very boring. Everyone wants to get in early, work through lunch, and then leave as early as possible. The company promotes this culture with another perk- 9/80 fridays. The reason people love it so much is because literally no one wants to be at work.

review_title: Supportive management, cynical and disengaged workforce
pros: I was lucky enough to have had supportive mentors and managers who nurtured my career and provided opportunities that I hadn't gone looking for myself.
cons: This may be typical of the defense industry in general, but many of the people I worked with were doing good work, but not particularly happy to be where they were. This seemed especially true of people who remembered the good old days when working in the defense industry garnered more generous benefits and bonuses. This wasn't helped by some rather tone-deaf attempts at engagement surveys.

review_title: Challenging Technical Projects, Interesting Opportunities, Use Technical Services as a Starting Point
job_title: Principal Electrical Engineer in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: The technical work is challenging, but Northrop supports you with all the software you need to accomplish goals. Support of engineers is quite good. Very good pay. Benefits are industry average.
cons: Technical services division takes some getting used to. You are a federal contractor, so that designation comes with odd work situations. It is a good place to meet and get connected to government agencies. Use it to get to a better job though.

review_title: Good defense company
pros:
Have decent pay and good working environment.
People respect your privacy and managers do not pressure employees.
There are interesting projects but you have to make sure to make your stance known to management.
cons:
Very slow.
The average age is very high, so there are many people who collect money for doing nothing.
Often it's more about making it seem like you do work than actually doing the work.
Systematic issues with version control, chip design flow, test plans.

review_title: Not an Equal Opportunity Employer. Opportunities are for some not all! and are only for the choosen few.
pros: It was a good place to work for the first 5 yrs or until your vested. If you are young take advantage of the knowledge you will learn from older experienced engineers. Then wipe your feet of them, and move on like so many have done.
cons: If you are a loyal dedicated a hard working individual and inspire to have possibly a future. Do not count on it. They are ruthless with no respect or compassion to you as person, and they will kick you to the curb. 21 yrs. of positive efforts gone.

review_title: Exciting, Interesting work
job_title: Systems Engineer II in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: Great work life balance; interesting challenges on the job with all levels of engineering done; decent pay given perks of the work life balance; Flexible hours
cons: Difficult to advance financially or with job titles, forced (usually) minimum number of years of experience before the ability to advance; pay differences between high and low performers are not as large as with other companies; lots of government work means stability but also slow progress of work

review_title: A good company
pros: health benefits were very good and the company has on site health clinics every 6 months or so. Cholesterol and blood pressure screening for free.
cons: Not too green thinking or eco friendly, insisted on using fluorscent bulbs and when asked if we could turn them off overhead they would not allow.

review_title: Global company shows the schizophrenia inherent in growth through acquisitions.
job_title: Manager, Human Resources Business Partner III
pros: Depending on sector, smart people doing very smart things for excellent rewards and a feeling of accomplishment. This is really rocket science...maybe even rocket surgery.
cons: Some sectors thrive on bureaucratic, mission distracting, buzzword, bs. Plans are developed in the ether without connection to reality; connecting the dots requires the will to fight continuously.

review_title: Northrop Grumman - Woodland Hills
pros: Northrop Grumman has a great benefits package such as 9/80 work schedule and vacation.
cons: The division in Woodland Hills is suffering in sales.  Therefore, there has been three layoffs in the last year and a half.  This includes closure of at least three campus buildings because of the significant reduction in staff.  Overall employee morale is suffering as a result of the continuing layoffs.  In addition, seniority of the overall employee population (30 years +), there is very little room for growth.

review_title: Cyber Security Analyst - MD
pros: I worked at NG over 5 years. The benefits are decent, they give opportunities to "certain" people and the business process needs some work.
cons: Retaliation, clique environment - meaning that they stick to a certain group and I seen this throughout the company. Upper management do not have a clue how the employees feel or whats going on. However, It is a big company and I get it that they only have time for particular things. They preach diversity and equal opportunity, however that is just being said so they can continue to have government funding. They need to really get to the nuts and bolts of things to keep good people.

review_title: So so
pros: The company values education and provides education assistance. I believe it is a great company to begin your career and you learn a lot from many highly intelligent people.
cons: It's not a great company to spend your whole career due to limited upward mobility and lack of challenging or rewarding work.  The company has a very antiquated form of management and oversight.  People are not very motivated here from my experience and your opinion does not really count.

review_title: NGC employee
job_title: Subcontract Administrator in San Diego, CA
pros: Challenging and interesting work , serving the war fighter is very personally rewarding. I have had the opportunity to do lots of travel. Also work has been very good at supporting a work life balance.
cons: No respect from upper management. Treated like &$@! from all other sectors that are not global supply chain. No recognition for a job well done. Typically other functions get bonus' by claiming your work.

review_title: Lead Aircraft Mechanic
job_title: Lead Aircraft Mechanic in Front Royal, VA
pros: Pay is great. Most of the people are great.
cons: very top heavy company, too many assistant managers, assistants for assistant managers. Honestly seems more important to be able to convey a problem to the customer than to be able to fix the problem. Some people will do just about anything to advance it is sometimes disturbing.

review_title: Working in Supply Chain is a nightmare
job_title: Procurement Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros:
9/20 schedule
Tuition assistance 
Clean work environment
Employee resource groups
Parking 
Working computers
They want me to add 20 words of pros but to be honest it's hard to find that many pros for this place.
cons:
I thought I had gotten the opportunity of a lifetime only to find out it was all a sham. Working in the supply chain dept at the Spectrum Center in San Diego is a living nightmare. Very toxic environment!
The managers are the worst I have ever seen. They lie to your face, promote backstabbing and gossip among employees. You can't complain to HR because they are friends with the managers and will make sure you never get promoted or able to move depts. You will only get promoted if managers like you regardless of experience, education or work performance. Preferential treatment is at all time high. Just suck up to that lazy manager and you get your way. If you aren't one of the favorites you might as well leave because your career and salary will come to a halt. 
The turnover is the highest I've seen,  PAs are always going out on disability or quitting but the managers don't care they can always fill the positions with contract labor. The managers have all gotten the positions because they are friends with the bosses wife or some else, they bring nothing to the table while sitting in their offices trolling their phones all day. 
PAs get blamed for pretty much everything when things go wrong. We are the punching bag of other departments. Programs don't realize it's a tough job pleasing programs and compliance and when you have unproductive lazy managers life is very hard. The processes and procedures PAs have to work with are so outdated it's unbelievable for a company this size. Sucking up to compliance is what PAs have to do all day every day for no apparent real reason. 
I have never been so stressed at work in my entire life and can't wait to find a new job like everyone else.

review_title: Unfathomably awful in every way
pros: There are some professional, courteous, collaborative people here. Unfortunately they're not managers, directors or vps. Pros are execeedingly few and far between.
cons: Zero investment in people/management in the last 30 years. And it shows. Promotions based on who is in the right spot, at the right time, nodding in the right direction. Culturally this company is decades behind and smart people recognize that even if they're initially duped into accepting an offer. Poor leave, below average compensation, managers who have no people skills.

review_title: Saying/Trying Good Things, but Mired in the 20th Century
pros:
Smart coworkers
Cutting edge technologies/programs (for Customers)
Flexible work schedules
Generous tuition program
Trying to generate engaging & inclusive culture
cons:
Boomers/Federal retirees have a lock on upper management & their attitudes keep the company firmly entrenched in the 20th century
Northrop's Business Casual is the rest of the world's Business Formal
Stultifying bureaucracy
Substandard technologies (for internal use)
Horror stories from those in functions all doing at least 2 peoples work
Lots of perks touted to all (career mobility, relocation, international opportunities, etc) only available to very select few (Engineers, Developers)

review_title: Your mileage will vary.
job_title: Systems Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: 9/80 work week.  Would be assigned projects and roles according to skills and not limited to formal job title.  Example: a systems engineer could work as a software engineer on a project if he/she had the skills, desire and there was project need.
cons: Some locations are great, others were notoriously bad.  Management of the organizational structure often fails.  Re-orgs happen annually and management fails to execute on large re-orgs.

review_title: Great office, terrible work, terrible company
pros: Great people in the office who have formed a family through their shared frustrations at management
cons:
- Office receives little to no work
- Vindictive behaviour of management when ethical concerns are raised.
- Send employees regularly across the country needlessly and dismissing mental and physical health concerns raised from such behaviour.
- Strict 40 hour work week with inflexible working hours
- Offer little to no training except for internal mandatory trianing that is drawn out, outdated and useless to most of the staff working in the company.
- Most of your time at this job will be sat staring at a monitor waiting for work.
- Upper management do not exist at the site and never visit. Emails will be ignored and calls dodged if you want to get in touch with them.

review_title: Beware if you weren't referred by someone already there - Keep your Resume active!
pros: The pay was competitive, The manager (SH) is competent and has been in the role a long time.
cons: Lots of nepotism, the deputy managers and leads are very aggressive. The leads don't seem competent in the area they are leading. No communication, you have to research everything yourself. There are cliques and brown-nosing is a must to receive good increases. Too many different teams and I was often finding out information about my team from cross-talk from people outside the team. The constant change of work-order/pay codes gave an increasing sense of disorganization - at one point forcing employees to leave an area with one day notice because their contract expired.

review_title: northrop is a good place to work.
job_title: Software Requirements Engineer V in San Diego, CA
pros:
good place for engineers -- interesting problems
good support structures for employees -- human resources and career development resources available.
good place for networking -- lots of groups that cross program and job title lines if you are willing to step outside your comfort zone
cons:
finding a job can depend on who you know although most functional managers do try to help you find the next project
too much overtime
you can get trapped on bad projects where managers won't let you go to another program.

review_title: Great gig
job_title: BCTP Workcell Controller (P/T) in Fort Leavenworth, KS
pros:
Can work up to 20+ weeks a year and make about $40k.
Admin support for part-timers is great.
Can get positions working closely with soldiers.
Helps keep abreast of current doctrine.
cons: 12 hour shifts once an exercise starts.  Can get fairly boring, depending on the type of work cell you're in, because so many aspects of exercises these days are script-driven rather than simulation driven.  Also, the number of exercises, and the number of contractors req'd to run them, has diminished greatly in 2010.  I'll be lucky to work 10 weeks this CY, and that's better than most.

review_title: Decent benefits, low raises, "you are lucky to have a job mentality" until you put in your notice to leave.
job_title: Systems Engineer in Falls Church, VA
pros: Large company and you can get lost in the sauce.  Benefits are standard but are decreasing never increasing.
cons: Medical coverage cost went up every year, raises were low, does not like to move contractor employees to new positions, would rather hire from outside.  They have a lot of people that are "stuck" working there as they can't find better without losing accrued leave time.

review_title: Good
pros: Enjoy Working here, get every other Friday off, great flexibility, challenging work.  I've been here quite a while, and while initially getting onto good projects can seem like it will never happen, eventually it does, and you'll be busy your entire career here.
cons: I'm very positive about working here.  Like any place I suppose some things could be improved, the facilities aren't the best, sometimes takes time to get the proper equipment for the job, and IT can be draconian.  But again, overall I'm very happy.

review_title: Great Mid-Career Move
pros: I have always wanted to work for NGC. I have been working for NGC for close to 5 months and the company has not disappointed me. A few of the things that I love about NGC are the 9/80, salary, work-life balance, my organization, a few of my coworkers....
cons: I know NGC is attempting to adopt a one company philosophy. Hopefully, management speeds up the process and adopts best practices from each NGC site.

review_title: Gave it my best shot!
pros: Electrical, Mechanical, Components and Reliability engineers support each other and work well with manufacturing, quality and other staff as a team.  NG stock performs well.
cons: The Aerospace industry which drives a significant portion of Northrop Grumman is dependent on the US Federal budget.  Employment has been shrinking for many years as a result.  Job stability will continue to be an issue.

review_title: Subcontract Administrator III
job_title: Subcontract Administrator III in Baltimore, MD
pros: Only being here 7 months, I appreciate the 9/80 schedule and work/life flexibility.  Having worked for other large companies, both Commercial & Federal Contractor, NG definitely takes care of its employees.  Tuition Reimbursement & the ability to transfer to another opening within the organization after 6mths are highly encouraged. Competitive pay, PTO accrual, and benefits across the board.  Company values/ethics are refreshing.  OT paid extra hours worked.
cons: -PPO not offered to everyone in my Sector, previously ES Sector/ now MS Sector, something my HR recruiter was not knowledgeable about,

review_title: Security, but management can be less than helpful
pros: Longevity is possible, and a career can be sustained for many years.  Many changes in the 'rules' for continuing education, so keeping a career relevant and updated can be a challenge.
cons: There are times you get managers that are picked there because they don't perform highly yet are a 'great fit' with the rest of management.  When you get there, you will find your career stymied by those that don't want you in the 'club.'

review_title: Analyst 1
pros: The benefits are nice. They give new employees a lot of responsibility quickly.
cons: As a new employee, it takes at least 3 years and having someone in your corner to move up the ladder. There is no inclusion and diversity at the IL site. There is no proper training in any group. They throw you into the fire pretty quickly and then are quick to place blame when things aren't perfect. Complete lack of trust at the site. No problem making everyone work overtime.

review_title: Systems Engineer Staff
job_title: Systems Engineer in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros: Cafeteria clean and staff was nice.
cons: Terrible Management.  Their focus is on their personal promotions and placement rather the that of their employees.  They just use up their employees, causing them to work 60+ hours but only paying them 40 and promising them that it will help their chances of promotion at the end of the year only to elevate those who suck up rather then the truly hard workers who spend their holidays and sacrifice personal time with their families to see a program exceed.

review_title: Exciting & Growing Company
pros: This is a growing Company. There are not many opportunities to join an international organization as they enter a new Country. This provides new and interesting work that that is not often available in my profession.  The team I work in are one of the best that I have ever experienced and the leadership group genuinely do care.
cons: With growth comes some challenges - systems and tools are often trying to keep up. However, there is absolutely appetite to change and over the past 2+ years there have been many improvements made and more improvements planned.

review_title: PDP
pros:
Work Life Balance
Decent Benefits
Decent Salary
cons:
No Training for new hires
PDP rotations are difficult

review_title: Northrop Grumman - Not The Sexiest Job, But A Good One None The Less
job_title: Software Engineer II in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: Interesting work on diverse complicated systems, opportunities to move all over the country and the world, and flexible 40 hour work weeks w/ paid overtime (depending upon your program manager).
cons: Opportunities for growth can be somewhat limited depending on what program you are working for.  Promotions seem to be given for "time served" rather than being merit based.  NG is primarily a defense company, and SW program segments don't always get the focus/budget they need.  Development processes (CMMI level 5) can be cumbersome.

review_title: Great pay and work life balance
job_title: Subcontract Manager in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: 9/80 Workschedule: This is where you work nine hours monday thru thursday and eight hours on friday. In turn you get every other friday off. They also provide flex schedule so you can work variable hours to best fit around your needs and habits. If you like to come in early or late it doesnt matter with flex scheduling.
cons: Goverment work can be very hurry up and wait. The aging workforce can cause a disconnect if you are a young new hire. It can be quite a shock if everyone you work with is twenty to thirty sometimes even forty years older thank you.

review_title: Company cares more about shareholder value than their employees
pros: You can work on cutting edge technology if you are in the right field for the company. Salary and benefits are decent.
cons: This used to be a good company to work for but it has gone downhill in the last few years. Promotions are hard to come by. Annual merrit increases are small. Hardly any profit sharing. Growth opportunities and conference opportunities are almost non-existant unless you are in one of thier targeted retention groups.

review_title: Good company, not the best business unit
pros: Flexible schedule, great benefits, good pay, decent amount of training, reinvestment in company and programs, stock options.
cons: Cubical farm, overworked employees, no work/life balance for managers, its all about the bottom line, lack of leadership, too much NG-related paperwork/processes that get in the way.

review_title: Its not what you know its who you know unless you are a woman and in that case neither required.
pros:
- Impossible to get fired.  
- friendly employees
- year around 9/80 work schedule
cons:
- employeesssible to get an interview to get promoted in to management despite exceeding qualifications.   Jobs are predetermined for hand picked employees and posting to hire process is just a formality.  
- company has a "high potentials" list comprised by upper management primarily based on popularity and children of executives. If you didnt make the list then dont expect to move up in the company.
-   Personal salary increase of less then 1% per year over a five year period.  Despite the fact that work was highly regarded and only limiting factor was my compensation relative to my peers.   They bring you in laterally and then tell you you are overpaid according to market research ( source unknown).  If you do get an offer ask what percent you are to market.
- performance management system is waste of time because you rating is predetermined prior to your review and no negotiations on the number.  
- countless lip service but very little action by upper management. 
- this is an engineering company.  Raises are done in tiers.  Even though need all functions to run a successful program engineering receives highest raise, technical mgmt next and business mgmt gets the least amount. 
- employees to management ratio too low.  Most cases two employees to a manager which adds unnecessary layers and micro management. 
- work life balance is preached but NOT practiced.  its frowned upon to take time.
 I

review_title: Good at one thing... ripping off the government
pros: Good pay and benefits including a nice matching on the 401k
cons:
The contract I worked on was never expected to succeed. We billed a dozen resources in order to tap out the contract when three or four would have sufficed to perform the work. At the end of the contract there was nothing useful for the client to use.
There are so many levels of management it was not possible to determine how many people were between me and the CEO. I stopped counting at 10.

review_title: Great Company on Paper
job_title: Procurement Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros: Very Diverse, community active and Green Thinking, tries to do the right things.
cons:
So large that cost savings suggestions or ideas at the worker level are ignored. 
Pay is not close to average or competitive

review_title: political cronyism maintains status quo of inept workers - losing good employees
pros:
9/80 schedule
Decent benefits given the size of the company
cons:
Lack of leadership 
No clear objectives
Failure to be open to ideas that could prove beneficial
Little recognition for the best performers because only the politically connected receive it.

review_title: Software and systems test engineer 3
job_title: Lead Software Systems Test Engineer in Newark, NJ
pros: Cannot honestly give a reason other than you are reminded annually that at least you still have a job, but expect no raise - which interprets to find another position because personnel talent retention is not required by this company.
cons: No salary increases to match cost of living unless you count a low four digit figure equal to a percentage cost of living increase increase for specialized tech degrees plus experience and talent

review_title: Engineer
pros: This place is good for those employees that want stability for a long period of time.  Not a whole lot of change.  They offer good training programs for the various logistics fields.
cons: If you like change and moving through different fields, this does not seem to be the place. Many of the employees stay in the same field for long periods of time.

review_title: Laid back and work is at a good pace but some difficulties
job_title: Software Development Analyst in Little Rock, AR
pros: The work is very laid back and not too fast paced. Many of the clients are patient and are very approachable at DHS.
cons: Too laid back sometimes, many of the management and the fellow coworkers such as software developers are extremely hands off and any learning that is done is really done by yourself. This makes the learning curve unnecessarily steep and a bit slow and that in turn can lead to a lot of trial and error when working.

review_title: Not the best place to young go-getters
pros: The benefits are good, there is a lot of stability and it can be easy to make lateral transfers into different fields.  The company and it managers are generally very understanding and flexible of work/life balance issues.
cons: No real career paths, company is disjointed - you do have to fend for yourself.  There are over 10,000 Northrop Grumman employees in the mid-Atlantic - it can be hard to feel like you are part of big team rather than just on an island.

review_title: Good overall company.
pros: They strive to give you additional opportunities for growth. There are a lot of different types of positions so if you want to move to something else completely different you can. NGMS also has a good name within the Defense sector, and has positions all over the country and overseas, which offers a lot of opportunity.
cons: Poor pay and benefits compared to competitors. Put shareholders before employees. They also won't put you on overhead if your contract is cut, whereas most other large companies will at least short term. They are also just generally pretty stingy with money, such as no holiday parties.

review_title: Northrop Grumman Aerospace Systems (the space side of aerospace)
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Redondo Beach, CA
pros:
Highest compensation rates available for technical positions in public aerospace/defense companies.
Lateral movement across company sectors relatively seamless.  Many opportunities to try new things (economy permitting).
Working with really smart people.
Very good morale for a large defense firm.
Strong work ethic of coworkers.
Reasonably good relationships between management and engineers (as a whole)
Tremendous work-schedule flexibility for this sector (defense)
cons:
Merger woes (trimming of benefits)
"Cash is king" policy from corporate
Slow moving bureacracy (no worse than typical)

review_title: Experienced engineer who transferred between sites - big mistake
job_title: Software Analyst in New York, NY
pros: There is the possibility of working on some great programs with some very talented people, IF you can manage to get on the good ones.  The benefits are OK but not great.
cons: The current job site that I work at does not treat their engineers with the respect that they deserve.  Management makes unreasonable promises to the customer without first consulting the engineers to see if it is reasonable.

review_title: Great work environment provided you're on a program/contract with funding
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: On new development programs there are opportunities to innovate and use new/state of the art technologies.
cons: Company culture depends greatly on the "legacy" company your location or business unit came from (e.g. which acquisition).  Defense environment is shifting with the current budget situation; could turn into "musical chairs" when the smoke clears.   Opportunities for "new" development seem to be diminishing.

review_title: Northrop Grumman will take
pros:
- Great career path for engineering types and those with exceptional technical talents you're willing to sign over to the US government.
- Paid overtime for some positions
- Good benefits
cons:
- No credit is given for skills learned at other companies (especially non-defense).  The general attitude is if you didn't learn it at Northorp Grumman, you must not know how to do it.
- The bonus plan is unattainable for most individuals
- Work/life balance is all talk

review_title: Northrop Grumman Review
pros: Northrop Grumman provided excellent benefits and was able to provide the latest equipment to perform your assigned tasks. Working in a large company allows you to expand into new areas of knowledge.
cons: The statement of work you perform in a large company is more limited then working in a small environment.  Working in a small company allows to wear many hats.

review_title: Large stable company that offers diverse work experience due to encouraged job rotations
job_title: Program Cost Control Analyst in Linthicum Heights, MD
pros: Large company that encourages job rotations within company every 2 - 3 years, flexible work schedule  (9/80 Fridays ), and decent benefits (health, education  and 401k). Health care center,  fitness center, cafeteria and credit union on site make work life balance possible.
cons: Due to rushed rotations, sometimes knowledge isn't transferred which causes unnecessary stress.  Some positions lack desktop procedures.  Recent corporate reorganization of sectors is making things very difficult.

review_title: PDP Electrical Engineering
pros: Good company culture overall. The rotational program allows you to find your best fit in the company (I know I did). Good sense of community in the PDP program. 9/80 program is nice.
cons: PDPs are sometimes not given meaningful work. PDP management is understaffed. The company is stingy about raises. You sometimes feel like a cog in a machine, especially if you are working at central building. The company also cut educational benefits gradually over the course of 2 years, which leaves a bitter taste in our mouth for a large majority of young employees who picked Northrop for their educational benefits.

review_title: Un-engaged Management & Poor HRM Skilled Sectors
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: The diversity of the company is astounding, and what they offer globally to the economy is amazing.
cons: Workers are not allowed to expand on their own ideas and grow as individuals.  Management makes all decisions, and has no idea of knowledge of workers.  HRM is not in the same state and offers no local help to employees when needed.  Inexperienced young managers hired within.

review_title: Boring Work + Clueless Leadership
pros: Northrop Grumman looks good on the surface. It's possible to coast here for a few years without much complaint. Pay is okay.
cons:
Do not work here if you have any interest in growing your skills. This is not a place where you will be challenged. Management hates to invest in training. Lots of low level grumbling all around. Most people are just biding their time.

If you are young and excited about your career, this is not the company for you. If you're counting the days until you can retire, you'll probably be just fine.

review_title: Great job security, limited growth opportunities
job_title: Electrical Engineer I in Baltimore, MD
pros: Performance based bonus, plenty of overtime opportunities, plenty of subject matter experts to gain advice from.
cons: Work is not very rewarding. As an entry level employee, tasks are often repetitive, and managers seem less concerned about individual development. First manager pressured me to take less responsibilities on a program so his other employee could stay busy, even though I went out and secured the work myself. Current manager seems to be counting days until retirement.

review_title: Good, but not Perfect by Any Stretch
job_title: Systems Engineer in Manhattan Beach, CA
pros: It's one of a very few private employers willing to wait for the government to waste a year plus on an initial security clearance investigation plus adjudication. It does a lot of essential work for the U.S. national security establishment. It offers a good work-life balance, i.e., few 60-hour weeks and almost no late-night calls. Many good people work there.
cons: Its benefit package has only worsened over time. Only at most 10% of junior employees and 40% of senior employees get bonuses. You will eventually either get pigeonholed or become know as a malcontent if you aren't one of the blessed few whose careers are shepherded.

review_title: Lot of Experienced people (average age is 48 to 49), well Managed but very political, with little opportunity for growth
pros:
-Has one of the better if not best run Business Management and IT Groups in the whole company.  They are better run than 3 other large/medium size companies I have worked for. 
- Pretty good salary and benefits. 
- Good place to start out at due to mature processes, and management/tracking tools. One is able to see how very complex process work fairly well, and learn a lot of Good PM, Finance, Software, Purchasing, Contract, and Engineering  methods/processes. 
- Very well managed R&D projects. They tend to perform on below budget (there are exceptions). 
- If you know how, can learn a lot by talking with a lot of very experienced personal who are everywhere. 
-Lot of cool R&D projects going on all the time. If you are an Engineer, long hours but interesting work in many cases.
cons:
- Since a lot of Cost-Plus jobs little incentive to cut cost especially since this would decrease the profit margins. 
- To specialized, tend to get stuck in one highly specialized job for a long time.
 - Little opportunity for lateral movement unless you are part of the 5% of people on the inside (unless you move out of State). 
- Difficult to try new things, and present information in a new way or new information because of the mature processes, and culture. People do not like to shake things up or change unless it is from above. 
- Due to the above reasons hard to learn thru experience. Have to learn by talk and observation. 
- Highly political, a lot of B.S. trying to massage the message and data to Top Level executives, also Top Executives to the employees (little content to the message). HR communication is some of the biggest BS I have ever read in my life. Example: 500 words on new organization, that after I have read it I am still clueless at to anything they do.
- To get Salary increase you need to quite then come back (fairly typical in Corporate America I think)
- HR group worthless in almost all functions, act like big brother, very command and control.

- Business Magament  Directors/V.P.'s need to do a better job level loading the work load, then they would not need as many people. Hard, but a lot of ways to go about it. 
- Annoying trying to find something to do, partly due to to many people, but mostly do to not being allowed to try new things.

review_title: Political, and draining
pros: They appreciate the work life balance and strive to ensure employees are given oppurtunities to balance work and life. The 9/80 work week is helpful althought not consistent throughout the company, good benefits packages and depending on work location and job many promote working from home.
cons: No room for creative development, everything is dependent on government funding and peoples ability to kiss up and make sure the customer (internal and external are happy. There is no consistency throughout the company.

review_title: Used to be a great company, now just a huge bureaucracy
pros:
1.  The benefits (pension, 401K) , despite being gradually cut back (no vacation cash out, capping vacation hours, etc.), are still a lot better than most.
2.  You're pretty much left alone to do your job if you're doing it properly.
3.  Low-level management tries very hard to do a good job (only to be foiled at higher levels)
4.  Flexible work hours
5.  Have an excellent govt customer who provides the job satisfaction.
cons:
1.  Bureaucracy, bureaucracy, bureaucracy.  Nothing can get done without approval from the "cloud".  Everything has a process (although no one can seem to tell you what the process it).
2.  One size fits all.  Doesn't matter if the policy doesn't apply to your program -- have to follow it anyway.
3.  Corporate "spam" -- multiple company announcements a day.  Don't care that XXXX is being announced as director/VP.  This is taken as "communication" to the employee.
4.  Communications minimal from higher levels. We get the press releases, but not the real story -- like which program received a 25% award fee, and how that will impact the organization.
5. Current buzzword "employee engagement".  Pressure on employees to respond to the all of 10 question satisfaction survey (that shows their engagement).  Pressure to create a plan to " fix deficiencies". No one actually follows up to see if it did any good.  
6.  Employee review process is a joke.  Different types of jobs/job titles being evaluated against a single standard that is not necessarily applicable.  Those that don't fit the mold always give the low ratings.    
7.  Sometimes wonder when the number of VPs and other staff is going to outnumber the people delivering billable hours.
8.  Upper management seems to have lost sight of the importance of good people.  It seems that we're just a body shop now.  Pull an engineer from the pool when you need one.  And send him/her back when you're done.

review_title: It's about the bottom line; employees are ultimately dispensible and their wellfare is unimportant to corporate goals
job_title: Business Development Manager in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Decent pay and benefits; better than not being employed at all.
cons: Constant reorganizations, management by fear and intimidation, managers ill-equiped to do the job required of them, minimal career development support, poor workplace morale...just not a good place.

review_title: Fond Memories

It's refreshing to have that one on one with a company as large as NGC.

review_title: OK if you want to work for a big company

Even such things as "improving employee engagement" turn into an exercise in filling out surveys, going to meetings, creating action plans, etc... instead of realizing that employees just want to feel appreciated and valued as people instead of statistics...

review_title: Has its issues, but best large company to work for

review_title: Proposal Analyst 1

pros: Slightly higher starting salary, stable work hours / shift for entry-level employees, 401k, medical / dental / life insurance, tuition assistance / reimbursement up to $15,000 annually; some really good people & managers with whom to work in certain parts of the company; nepotism-----current employees know other employees very well & are likely related to others throughout the firm (parents, siblings, cousins, childhood friends, long-time coworkers, etc.)----good if you know and / or are related to someone in the firm.

review_title: Just Look The Other Way
job_title: Full Stack Developer in El Segundo, CA
pros:
-Off Fridays. 
-401K with matching
-15K a year for education
-If you just want to get in and get out, coast and have no desire to move up, this is the perfect place to work.
cons:
I could write a book on this...

-Getting a promotion is extremely hard and when you get the promotion the compensation is around 5%. Other aerospace companies give around 10% and additionally quarterly/mid year bonuses.
-Annual merits barely keep up with inflation.
-Facilities are disgusting. Some buildings are roach infested. Desks are from the 1930s. Chairs are uncomfortable and some are so old that they've retained the farts of engineers for the last few decades. Bathrooms are old as well and some have no ventilation so sometimes you get a nice surprise waft when you open the bathroom doors. It's honestly not the janitor's fault. The company just chooses not to provide money to repair the restrooms. Oh and sand paper is used in place of toilet paper.
-NGC has a contract with the food service, Aramark. The quality of food is equivalent to that which is served at senior centers. Mushy and tasteless. And of course the food is over priced. When there are meetings that do not provide charge numbers, the host/manager usually tends to "provide food" as to entice employees to come on their own time. Thanks, but I'm not going to wait until 1pm to eat Aramark mashed chicken even with a charge number.
-There is a lot of bureaucracy making it difficult to get work done. To get something like a Java profiler requires you to submit a request to IT and the job could be done anywhere from 3 weeks to 3 months, when it really should only take a couple of minutes. That's the "Value of Performance". Ordering and purchasing parts or software is a similar case, there is so much approval process you must go through that it hinders you from doing your job. At the end, your software which cost $500 ends up costing much more. 
-Health benefits are not full coverage like some other companies. Each year it gets more expensive and the coverage is less, but I'm not sure the company really has much control over this with Obamacare in play. 
-There is no free coffee and no free snacks.
-Wastes my weekend time writing reviews.

review_title: No company is perfect, why expect it to be at NG?
pros: In short, Northrop Grumman wants leaders or potential leaders, remember that when filling out your resume, job application and during the interview.  Depending on what you are looking for Northrop Grumman can provide a person with golden opportunities to grow in one's profession.  As with all other companies of this size there is the usual amount of office politics and throwing the employees under the bus by management to account for their own failures is unfortunately commonplace.  If you are thinking of working for Northrop Grumman chose wisely the section and management you will be working under.  It is possible to reduce your chances of working for a bad manager by asking the right questions.  Talk to one or more employees in the department off the record over the phone during non business hours.  Ask good questions, not "yes no" questions.  Once you have found a good department to work for remember to always turn down the first offer and ask for more along with an extra week of vacation on top.  If you take the first offer they will think that you do not hold yourself in good esteem. Once on the inside, remember Northrop Grumman management does not take the lead to grooming employees for promotion, that is the employee's responsibility.   You have to take care of your career development and carefully guide it in the right direction.  Otherwise you will not grow and without growth your value over time will diminish and your pay raises will follow in step.  Along those lines never stay in one location more than two years, you must move yourself in order to grow.  Always look for and take on opportunities to demonstrate and build your leadership skills.   You will know where you stand in the department ranking, make sure you are in the top 20%.  If not move yourself to another department ASAP.  Always be on your guard, watch what you say and do, the management is not the only people who are going to throw you under the bus.  It is a good idea not to use the company internet, phone, or email for personal use, all such media is monitored by the company.  Trust no one, no exceptions.
cons: Depending on which sector of the company you work for the work environment can vary quite a bit. Northrop Grumman is composed of a series of smaller companies that were acquired over time and each has retained their own culture and values to some degree. While the parent corporation has been making adjustments to equalize the differences between the various companies, it is only at the benefits level and has yet to alter the personality and culture of the existing management that much.   Over time the leaders within each acquisition will be replaced or re-educated, and those who cannot make the adjustment will be offered a golden handshake or demoted out of the way.  At the employee level little change has been observed as a result, except the unusual number of email notices of changes in management and promotions.  What does all this have to do with the question?  Any good reviews of NG does not mean the whole company is the same.  To be honest, currently the employees to some degree feel disenfranchised, they also feel that their management lacks autlntcity.   Along with layoffs of very loyal, long term employees, this has lead to demotivation that in turn lowers productivity and in a few cases raises issues concerning quality of workmanship at the customer level.  The bulk of the employees are trapped in Northrop Grumman and take the abuse of their management. this is due to current economic conditions. They are unable to escape to something better and management tells them they will not be able to find another job.  Once the economic conditions change, and they will,  one would expect an exodus away from the company of key staff members and the corporate managers know this is the case.  To head off this brain drain, and to pick up morale, they corporate management,  have started a review process of managers in hopes of giving the employee a sense of empowerment while leveling a degree of stress on management levels to improve their performance since the feedback polls will effect their ranking to some small degree. It remains to be seen if this latest corporate per rock will produce the desired results.  No matter what the result is corporate will declare it a success.  Remember you are a "at will" employee, which means they hire and fire at will, this means your loyalty to NG or any company is the equal to the loyalty they show you.

review_title: Northrop is not a Software Company
pros: Northrop Grumman Corporation works on very interesting projects. I had the opportunity to work on a team that gave me exposure to a multitude of different Software groups and platforms to develop on. The type of work you do here is difficult to find outside of the Defense Industry, and on top of that, Northrop Grumman is a leader in the industry for "smarter" vehicles such as UAVs.
cons:
1. Despite Northrop being the supposed leader in UAVs, it's software practices are terribly out of date. It's partially due to the industry and the length of the projects though. When a new project starts up, new tools are used and implemented, however those same tools will be used the entire way through, even if the project is more than a decade old. Trying to upgrade these tools or acquire new tools is a constant fight uphill with IT and layers of approval from upper management. 
2. Another con is not really a fault of NGC, but rather a reality of the industry. They are government contractors, and therefore bill the government a certain amount of man hours. This requires Software Engineers to always clock the hours. This is very out of the norm compared to the rest of the industry and takes a bit to get used to. 
3. There was a recent change to the rating program that rewards the top performers in the department with high score (5 or 4), normal performers with an average score (3), and poor performers with a poor score (2). This score is used to make the argument for raises and promotions for employees. On paper this sounds great, however a key detail is that only the top performers in the entire department are rewarded. This means even if you're a top performer in your own group, you can and probably will be passed for a higher score because only a percentage of 5's and 4's in the entire department. Managers convene to fight for the employees to get better scores, and use info written up by employees to help their argument. This is similar to the private sector, but I feel like it is handled a bit worse at NGC.

review_title: Slow, but steady, but mediocre
pros: Job security is not a concern, as long as you're not a terrible employee who causes problems. Some of the projects can be very rewarding and challenging. Some of the management personnel do a great job of not micromanaging.
cons:
Northrup Grumman career advancement is mediocre at best as it is not determined by your impact, it's how big of bragging rights do you bring your manager on *their* résumé. 

Northrup Grumman salaries, at least at my site, are not great compared to competition. One of the not-so-brilliant incentives Northrup Grumman has employed for ages is a bonus.. that you get in 3 years.. maybe. Basically, if the company does well, you get the bonus in x years. But the criteria for what determines if you get the bonus is not concrete, just ".. if Northrup Grumman does well..". In addition, you are sometimes competing against engineers that you'll never see, because they are not on site.. so prepare to not do as well as you'd expect because somebody somewhere that you've never met is better than you.

Due to the above point, Northrup Grumman has started letting in talent that would not be employed in past times. But since the salaries are not the best, the talent musts suffer. 

At the beginning of the year I strongly recommend taking a long vacation that goes well into January. If not, you'll be left stranded with no authorization to work as functional management and project management fight over who should be paying you during this "transition period". HINT: Neither end up paying you in my experience, so just avoid the headache and take an extended vacation.

review_title: Not what I expected, but potential
pros: I feel genuinely recognized for my work. When used, the corporate employee recognition system and internal career tools are great, but many managers don't use them. There are opportunities for internal lateral movement if you are unhappy, and the company will move you if it's reasonable (and you're cleared) without penalty. You're surrounded by lots of skilled people from all over the industry, so you can get a lot of perspectives if you're paying attention.
cons: Don't bother if you don't already have an ACTIVE clearance. I took a borderline insultingly low offer based on the promise of a specific, exciting kind of work. The security clearance process has taken OVER A YEAR, and that's perfectly normal around here. The job I was hired for had to be back-filled and I got stuck doing a job I never wanted, for less money than I'm worth. My managers have done everything they can to help, but all the great things that NG has to offer are behind the clearance wall. It's not NG's fault - that's the business they're in - but understand that every promise they make you is conditional on the clearance. And ask your interviewer about the program you'll be on. The programs within the company are essentially their own companies, so take all the negative and positive reviews with a grain of salt. My roommate works for a different program, and his management and work/life balance are completely different than mine. I haven't gotten a Friday off in 6 months and I regularly work every weekend for months at a time. He's home by 3:30 and takes ski trips all the time.

review_title: Good areas, bad areas, financially focused
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redondo Beach, CA
pros: Mid-level compensation for most employees compared to peers. Great leadership and introductory programs for junior employees. Comparable benefits to rest of big DoD firms. If you can find a good project, you can learn a lot from senior leadership.
cons: The company seems to be increasingly financially focused in the budgetary downturn. Engineering and technical strategy takes a back seat in all decisions. Management is currently struggling to figure out how to balance innovation and profitability.

review_title: Mostly interesting work
pros:
We worked on developing highly specialized new systems.  That meant there was always a lot of large-scope modelling and simulation and specification work to be done.  There usually wasn't an applicable tool to modify, so I got to start from scratch...which was awesome.
As an analyst, I had a lot of freedom to move between internal research & development projects and positions at different programs.  I worked with some extremely brilliant and creative people.
cons: Spec work could be dull, and with some programs was clearly just contractual work that did not seem to have much value.  Programs were frequently cancelled (or proposals not won).

review_title: Solid history, great prospects for the future
pros: Many opportunities to customize work/life options.  Lots of future work, growing manufacturing in the USA.  Dual career path options leave a lot of room for career growth while maintaining your technical expertise.
cons: The company is very focused on shareholder value which adds a lot of stress to internal spending and planning for the future.  It can be difficult to avoid the stress of getting more done with fewer people.

review_title: A company to be proud of
job_title: Business Development Manager in McLean, VA
pros: Northrop Grumman cares about its people, offering good pay and benefits, as well as good career advancement opportunities. Northrop Grumman is also committed to work place diversity, and provides a supportive and inclusive culture.
cons: Northrop Grumman is very strictly controlled by its customer contracting requirements and due to this, it can seem inflexible and unable to change to meet changing needs. This can seem tiresome and unproductive at times.

review_title: When you've had enough of other fun and challenging jobs, try to get a "coasting..." job in defense
job_title: Software Engineer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: A fantastic opportunity to see the Defense machine at work and get an early view at some really cool technology that public gets to see only decades later (if you're lucky to get on a project like that).  The salary is decent compared to your peers, just make sure you negotiate well up front.  Benefits (medical, 401, etc) are great but the incentive-based packages are non existent for non-managers (revenue sharing, stock options, bonus).
cons: It's the nature of the beast, but still a downside - everything moves soooo slowly.  But this would be a problem elsewhere as well - Raytheon, Lockheed, etc.  You will never ever get to see a full project from acquisition to deployment until you get higher up to be included on the acquisition processes and become so useless that they don't move you to another project and let you coast on one forever.  Most projects are miss-managed and developed with the Waterfall method which leads to buggy and delayed products.  Forget about voicing your opinion if you haven't served in the military or haven't been there a million years.  Speaking of which, the "good ol' boys" attitude of hiring and quickly promoting former military over well trained and seasoned engineers is pissing the heck out the generation of folks who didn't grow up with the draft, didn't serve (and didn't want to) and believed they were in a civilian job not the military.

review_title: Typical ES Engineer
job_title: Software Engineer II in Baltimore, MD
pros: Northrop Grumman is a great place to work if you want to maintain a good work/life balance.  Since you have to accurately record your time, you only have to work 40 hours a week.  Any more than that and you receive OT.  Management is pretty flexible about letting you work as much OT and comp time as you would like.  For comp time, you can work extra time within a month and use it to take days off.  Only 8 hours are allowed to be carried from one month to the next.  The company also allows employees to work a schedule 9-80, providing for an extra day off every other week.  Managers are understanding about the importance of life outside the office and rarely force you to come in on off days, prevent vacation, or make you work certain hours.  There are good policies put in place to pay for work related training or classes outside of work.  If you are a US citizen and can obtain certain clearances, Northrop will pay you a premium.  Northrop is such a large company that it is easy to try out different business areas and job roles.  Managers are pretty good about putting you in touch with someone to help make that happen.
cons: The company maintains many of the same beliefs as the government when it comes to raises, promotions, hirings/firings, performance reviews, and overall bureaucracy.  Many people are promoted due to the number of years worked for the company as opposed to actual performance.  It really takes a huge act to get fired from the company.  If someone actually performs poorly they are just shuffled around to a position that management feels is less important.  This causes there to be groups (Testing, CM) where absolutely nothing gets done.  Lower level management is also forced by upper management to greatly consider diversity.  This makes it very difficult to always find good hires.  Many times management will just hire diverse, but unqualified workers and place them in one of those groups they deem to be unimportant. Even if someone greatly exceeds expectations and receives great reviews, there are rules put in place on the maximum raise they can receive (~15%).  This greatly affects new hires as their initial salary is based on degree, grades, school attended, etc.  I have seen a range of starting salaries from 46 to 68K for the same position.  The performance reviews are also a joke.  The actual functional managers are very disconnected from their directs, so workers tell their managers who they would like to have do their reviews at the end of the year.  This means that employees do not obtain any real feedback and what they do receive does not help them do any of their tasks any better.  One of the reasons people used to work for Northrop was to work an easy job for life and then receive a decent pension.  That is no longer the case as Northrop has phased out pensions.  Due to all the bureaucracy, the technology used by the company is as up-to-date as the private industry.  You can also get frustrated with only being allowed to use certain software due to a fairly strict IT policy.

review_title: Great place if you like the big company feel.
job_title: Electrical Engineering Intern in Annapolis, MD
pros: There are definitely a large array of directions you can take to advance your career. The capital of such a large company makes it very easy to ask for things and get them, speaking in terms of equipment and supplies anyways. The online learning deal they have it pretty awesome too. You can, in your spare time, become certified or licensed in a variety of skills that will prove valuable on your way to the top of the corporate ladder. Personally, I could have learned JAVA and similar programming things if I wanted to, and once I passed all of the testing you could get a certificate saying you did it!
cons: It's a big company, so response time is slow. There are too many hoops to jump through in order to get anything done. The cost to the customer is far too high, but that is to satisfy the overhead costs of such a large corporate structure. Being in such a large community, it's even harder to become recognized, which also sucks.

review_title: Depends on the program
pros: Northrop Grumman is a huge company and like any huge companies, what team/program you're a part of will determine whether you like working here or not.   If you're a software developer working on a hardware program, then you will be working on fairly out-of-date technologies.  If you're working on a software-centric program, then you will be working on more current technologies.  Nothing cutting edge, but at least you'll be working on things that are industry standard.  So when you interview, be sure to join the right team.  As for pros, this company is very family friendly.  You work 40 hours, and you get out.  Sometimes you do have to work extra hours, but they're usually very rare and management is usually apologetic about it (and sometimes, you even get paid OT).  Northrop does have a very good continuing education benefits.  They will definitely pay for your masters degree here if you want to attend school part time.  They even hold classes on site for relevant technologies.  I also appreciate the better life/work balance that they're trying to push.  Things like having free flu shots or more frequent performance awards are always appreciated.
cons:
I've noticed that a lot of people just clock in and do the minimum in their work.  I haven't really met anyone here that is *really* excited to work.  I would venture to guess that most people enjoy their work due to their coworkers and not due to their work.  Also, as this is a defense contractor, you are really tied down to a schedule.  That great idea you have that will make the product better?  You will never get to do it if you it wasn't on the schedule.  Innovation only happens at prescribed times here.

Also, the red-tape and their obsession to the "process" is very discouraging.  You have managers from other team who don't know anything about your work trying to micromanage you by enforcing the process upon you.

Also as a software developer, you are at the very bottom of ladder here.  Any problems will eventually trickle down to you.  The power chain goes like this: Managers->Integration & Test->System Adminstrators->Software Developers.  So if the managers are trying to get more time in the schedule, they usually lessen development time.

review_title: Positive Experience - Well Run Organization, Excellent Legacy, Cutting Edge Technology
job_title: Logistics Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Educational Opportunities for life long learning are highly encouraged and supported.
cons: Limited career growth, salary increases plateau (essentially amount to a COLA),  which barely keep pace with inflationary pressures -driving the perception that you are moving backwards annually.

review_title: A good place to start a career but a lot of luck is necessary to reach the best programs and upper echelon.
job_title: Software Engineer II in Baltimore, MD
pros:
As a large company it provides various opportunities for engineers early in their careers to try out different roles and a position that fits with both their strengths and personality.  The company is involved in full life-cycle product development from inception to customer delivery to maintenance so it is possible to participate in multiple stages of a product's path to creation.

Those who perform well and aggressively seek out opportunities can find a rewarding career at Northrop.  Once you exit the company it is a large and known company on your resume to point to in future interviews.
cons:
Access to the best opportunities requires a combination of luck and ninja networking tactics to get noticed by senior engineers or program managers. 
Top performers who are not vocal about their career aspirations can find themselves stuck on a project and with a depressed salary.
Performance reviews are administered by a manager that meets with you at most twice a year.  The review manager is a different individual then the employee's direct supervisor (likely an engineer) and program manager.  The advancement process can seem slow and linear to the ambitious but this is common in most large corporations and not specific to Northrop.

review_title: Great Place to stay for the long term, Not a place for quick Promotions
pros: Family atmosphere, Working with some of the smartest people in the world. Opportunity to learn new things and be on the cutting edge of technology and defense.
cons: No opportunity to move up, very, very slow promotions. If the government pulls funding the program you are on can be cut at anytime.

review_title: Balancing act of keeping employees happy, while defense $$$$ dry up.Top heavy Managers just trying 2make2 retirement.
