review_title: Extremely Poor Management NGC Space and defense formally TRW
pros: It used to be an excellent place to work.  The benefits, pay, and challenges were great, but they are not during much research any longer due to government cutbacks.  Their are still great people working there with excellent work ethics.  My last supervisor was great and I worked in another department, which offered me a job, that was great.
cons: NGC took over TRW and their management really changed for the worst.  Under TRW the management wasn't great, but after it rely went downhill.  Management is not open and plays favorites with friends, which is fairly typical in a big company. However, now it is extreme in my department and the morale is terrible.  This is not necessarily company wide, because each department is run almost autonomously.  I have met people after I left that work for NGC and the overall consensus is that the effects of management are taking a toll.  Their employee reviews are worthless and if you did extremely well for the year, they will find any little thing to discredit you.  The management directs all promotions and it does not matter what your supervisor thinks, management tells them what to think.  The upper management builds their own little empires with their own minions and if opposition occurs they deal with it harshly.  I saw very good employees lose their jobs and replaced by incompetents.  My manager's buddy was a total incompetent that made about 170K/year doing technician the work.  HR is a completely company sided affair that any employee should avoid at all cost.  I stayed for retirement benefits, but wish I had pursued another field, which I am looking into now.  Be advised if your degree is not directly associated with your job, like a biology degree they don't recognize it.

review_title: Challenging Work, Excellent Benefits, Advancement is on a Rail
job_title: Software Engineer II in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: The benefits package is outstanding, with lots of options offered with very reasonable contribution.  Work is interesting and challenging.  Generally positive work environment (even if it's based on gallows humor) and most of the staff is easy to get along with.  Schedules are normally very flexible and work/life balance is excellent.   Very responsive and helpful HR, IT, and other administrative support.  Lots of opportunity to move about in the company with some patience.
cons: The pay is decent, but once you're in, you are one of the herd, especially if you are not in one of the major centers (such as El Segundo).  Development and advancement seems to be more tied to seniority than actual contribution and ability.  Performance reviews (and therefore raises and bonuses) are exceedingly subjective and seem to serve more to hit target numbers rather than provide meaningful feedback or incentives.  This is more specific to defense contractors in general, so I wouldn't single Northrop-Grumman out specifically for this, but if you switch companies, you aren't going to jump a spot in line.

review_title: 21 years of service at Northrop Grumman
pros: The managers with whom I worked were all very supportive and competent. They gave me numerous opportunities to learn and apply new skills and knowledge throughout my 21 years working in the intelligence community for Northrop. My managers encouraged me to expand my skills over time. I had a very rewarding career at Northrop Grumman.  Company benefits and compensation were definitely above average!
cons: I thoroughly enjoyed my years working for Northrop Grumman. I can't say that I ever had any serious problems with the company , the customer, or my managers and co-workers. It was a very positive experience.

review_title: Good employer if you don't mind corporate bereaucracy

review_title: Location of Work Campus drives your Career

The benefits are standard large company offerings (health, dental, vision, life ins., disability ins.,  401K) as well as some added options for legal plan, EAP counseling, elder care planning, adoption, and numerous discounts for local area offerings - (i.e. cell provider discounted plan, car insurance, moving co. etc).

Costs and options with the health  plan of course changes every year to something that most believe it rounds out to more money for less service or fewer options.
Certain areas of the company - whether by division or just geo-location - end up being short sighted in business expansion and old fashioned in their approach to employees (continual berating or demeaning people in the guise of "motivation').
Some locations are not conducive to career growth due to stagnant "lifers" in the organization that are allowed to stay employed while they do nothing to advance the work of the business and live in the "glory days" . These management in perpetuity  are still pushing old tactics and refusing to empower the employees to steer the ship in a new or advancing direction for growth/continuity. 
The leadership is old and out of date and resting on their laurels
Business is being lost to more agile companies while focus is still firmly on what use to work and why it still works,.

review_title: Overall Happy Engineer
job_title: Security Test Engineer in Aurora, CO
pros: I've been working here for 13 years.  I have enjoyed almost every minute of it.  I have had many opportunities to work different programs and positions, which ended up making me more valuable and well-rounded.  The work-life balance is fantastic.  I feel as if my management really understands that family comes first and allows me to make my family a priority as long as the work gets done.
cons: Sometimes I feel as if those that work hard and deserve recognition don't get noticed (I am not speaking for myself). Additionally, those that do not do their job well often get rewarded with promotions and/or more responsibility (I think this is more true with middle management).  I cannot stand the yearly-review process.  It seems so subjective and one bad comment on your review seems to hurt you for years to come.  By the time you receive your review, it's too late to change anything for that year.  However, if an employee was performing so poorly, it would be addressed immediately.  Obviously, none of these things is bad enough to make me leave.

review_title: Feeling used

review_title: Business as Usual

review_title: I don't recommend working here unless you are an engineer
pros:
- Benefits: Northrop Grumman has probably one of the best benefits I have seen. 
- Peers/Coworkers: strong, reliable, and supportive
- Gym: Onsite free gym
cons:
- Management
- Senior Leadership
- Lack of career growth opportunities for business areas
- You are forced to jump around departments/organizations to get that competitive pay bump. 
- Ethics/Harassment issues: once in a while you will observe some sort of harassment issue which is hard to report due to unsafe reporting system.

review_title: Come In, Get Experience, Leave
pros:
Great benefits, flexible hours, apparently respected in the industry.

I'm a recent college graduate and the only companies that seemed interested in taking new, untrained engineers were defense contractors. For that, this was a good match. Considering how others seem to react to my mention of my employer, it seems this is something that will look good on a resume.
cons:
First, there is no formalized training here. Presumably the company's solution, from what I've gathered, is that I am to be assigned to someone to learn alongside them. However it took weeks for that to actually happen in my case. Even then, rather than formalized points of contact, I just have a loose list of people I should talk to, all of whom are always busy and react to my questions with short patience at best, outright annoyance at worst. Independent training is all but impossible. I have tried using internal resources to shore up my understanding, but such information either doesn't exist, is scattered into some database I haven't heard of (this is an issue my manager has been having as well), or is out of date. Routinely I'd find a relevant piece of information, go to learn what I need to be doing to complete my job, and only find broken links when I actually go to investigate. I'm given conflicting information on how to handle problems, often by the same persons. What finally pushed me to write this review was an issue happening again:  being told by an advisor to contact one person for information, then being told off for bothering that person and not knowing better that I should have been able to do it myself. This is even worse when I was, in fact, fully capable of doing something myself but was given incorrect information, that I -had- to go to someone else. Routinely being made to feel foolish, told I'm ready to launch meetings despite missing crucial components, the utter lack of training, all being made out to be my fault, makes me want to leave immediately.

Talking with other new employees, it seems to be a problem they aren't having. Reaching out to other friends in related STEM companies and laboratories, however, to people who share my demographic background, my experiences are sounding more universal. I have regrettably come to the conclusion that a lot of the talk of the company about inclusion is empty. It's something that sounds good on a corporate headline, looks good in trade magazines and news publications, but even if it's the official position of the company, it's not reflected in the culture. It's a Defense Contractor, this is probably inevitable.

My takeaway is that if you're a typical white male, you'll have no problems here. You will likely find a wonderful career. If you don't fit the model of the majority, your coworkers will be cold towards you.

review_title: Corporate
job_title: Electrical Engineer I in Oklahoma City, OK

review_title: Once a great company to work for, but for how much longer?
pros: I have worked for NG for 15 years and loved it. People were treated like valuable resources. Compensation and benefits have traditionally been top notch. Quality mentoring program, excellent training resources and best of all – quality people to work with. Facilities and other resources were well maintained and plentiful. As with all large companies there are some challenges, but generally a great work environment!
cons:
The significant downturn in government programs over the last couple years have caused NG to do more than simply scale back. Pay raises are trivial, less benefits even though rates escalate. Resources are difficult to come by and staff members always worry if they are the next to fall. 
The challenges that NG is facing are not uncommon to defense contractors, but I fear that a company that has traditionally been an industry leader is fading into just another government contractor. NG has recently released a new series of TV ads that depict NG as continuing to be a cutting edge company, and in many ways they still are. However, in an attempt to continually increase sales the company seems willing to chance any contract that might have funding, regardless of its within NG’s core competencies.  This change has had dramatic impact on traditionally stable knowledge base of the NG staff. NG management is funding capture efforts that often require the company to hire new skill sets at the expense of legacy personnel. The result of this behavior is that individuals are frequently worried about the future and are more aware of external job opportunities. People who would gladly enjoy a lifetime career at NG are now always on the lookout for an exit strategy. If you look long enough you will find something …

review_title: Great Company, Not Perfect

Also, referral bonuses are only for higher level engineers or jobs that are desperate for candidates.

review_title: Few positives, many negatives at BWI campus
pros:
The group I worked with was very nice - I enjoyed working with them all very much. There are many opportunities to work on many different programs. Good educational assistance for those who would use it (although the vest time has recently been extended)
-Flexible work schedule (in my case, anyway) which afforded a good quality of life.
-CEO is a very intelligent person and supremely qualified to lead the company.
cons:
-You can always get more work/responsibility here, but good luck getting them to actually give you the corresponding salary/title. 
-If you stay here more than two years, you are almost certain to be significantly underpaid
-Systemic incompetence throughout all parts of the company. Lots of people just going through the motion for a paycheck
-Many antiquated programs with old hardware/software
-Nonexistent training and mentoring
-Corruption/nepotism everywhere.  Many people in high positions because of who they know
-Ancient, really conservative leadership that don't understand that the younger group don't have any long-term incentives (i.e. pensions, etc.) and can't comprehend why everyone is leaving after 2-3 years.
-BWI facility is ancient and resembles a mental institution in some ways. Never ending hallways, dated carpet, etc.
-BWI is terribly overcrowded and has been for years.  Cubicles will often have 2-4 people smashed into each one. No semblance of privacy anywhere.
-No organization throughout the company. I didn't realize how bad it was until I joined my current job and saw the difference first hand. Be prepared to often be on your own to find answers for travel, training, programs, etc.
-No incentive to stay with the company. They recently unrolled a performance incentive that would pay up to $800 in your 401k if the company met its performance goals for the year. Seeing how Wal-Mart and Starbucks paid their employees more in bonuses this program falls very short
-Similar to above, the only way things will change is when you resign - then they will likely start trying to retain you. After years of the environment described above the efforts were too late.
-Performance reviews do not adequately reward performance. You will really devote yourself to a program, get a great review and nothing but excuses on why your raise was 3.5%. It was never really financially worth putting in the hard work and extra effort to obtain a top-level performance review.

review_title: Not a long term job

review_title: Good pay but make sure you are making the right choice.
pros: Pay was very fair. Benefits and 401k match right away. Interview process was very fair and I was treated very nicely. Completely arranged travel and accomodation.
cons: Alot of disconnect between offices. No one knows anyone and empty promises. It seems like the bosses do not really care about you outside of the office. I was promised flexibility within the company and that i could try difference things if i watned to, that was false.

review_title: Learn to be a King, but dont stay too long.

cons: You are truly more of a number compared to smaller companies. Decisions made at a senior management level dont neccesarily reflect or support the smaller department goals. Getting additional money for R&D, infrastructure, can be very difficult.

review_title: Dilbert Land, OMG!
pros: NGC has a relaxed work environment.  Working from home is not frowned upon, depending on your location.  The pay is as average to good for the Defense Industry, though they seem to use this against you as you advance in seniority.  Recent layoffs were heavily weighted to the senior software staff. (NGC categorizes its SW Engineers. from 1-7. In a 2009 lay off 80% came from the 4-7, 57% from the 5-7 category).  NGC benefits have been been better than average, but this is changing at the end of this year (2009).  Vacation was reduced about 40 hours for senior staff and medical insurance is getting worse, more expensive and more bureaucratic. Its not a bad place to work but everything is dependent on your project and division.
cons: Its not a bad place to work but everything is dependent on your project and division. If you are considering NGC ask your interviewer if they are a matrix organization.  This is the only structure in NGC I would recommend.  Otherwise when your project is over NGC only gives you two weeks to find another job.  That's their policy, regardless of your loyalty to the company.  If you are looking for a career with NGC, then you need to be in Herndon, VA., or on the West Coast.  If you are not in one of their centers there is little opportunity for career growth.  They are a large company that has gobbled up lots of smaller companies and they just haven't learned how to work together, or help each other.   Everything is dependent on your project and regardless of how good a project may be, eventually it will end and you will be looking for work.  I've worked for two other large Defense contractors and moved or left programs previously and still feel fondly towards those companies.  NGC is not a place I am proud to be associated with.

review_title: Company in Decline
job_title: Tech Lead/Senior Software Developer in Huntsville, AL
pros: 9/80 schedule is nice if the project schedule allows.  Depending again on the project, your comings and goings are not watched too closely.  This facility has occasional free employee events.  cubicles but fairly modern.  Employees allowed to take their office laptops home.
cons:
Management can be vindictive to employees.  Employees not given the opportunity to work from home.  Vacations are being reduced.  Used to have a company shutdown at Christmas - no more!
Used to have a company paid medical and pension plan.  Potential transferees are given no more consideration than a non-employee, seeking employment.  This is the first place I worked where working extra hours voluntarily can get you a ding on your performance appraisal.  Some BS about not meeting the velocity of the normal work schedule.  If they want to give you a lousy raise, then they will do there best to make your performance review justify that raise, or lack thereof.  Severans Pay for laid off employees reduced and capped.  Those who do the best at this facility kiss major booty.  High turnover here.  We have what is called the 6 month club.  Most People who hire or transfer in stay at least 6 months and then transfer out, if they choose to stay with NG to a better location or project.  Management has no people skils and care little about their employees.  Good example.  One project, in an effort to give the customer something they did not ask for spent a major part of the budget to give them that extra, not asked for function.  Now half of the staff will probably be layed off because there is no money left in the current budget and additional money for the next phase of development is not yet due to be funded until a few more months.

review_title: The work can be interesting, but sometimes policies or bureaucracy get in the way of things.
job_title: Software Engineer III in Huntsville, AL
pros:
Northrop Grumman is a defense contractor.  If you are on the right project, it's really easy to become a part of a project that really makes a difference to the people who defend our country.
Northrop Grumman is not your standard mom and pop company - the company can really push into markets with their clout and get you into some really cool projects.
Northrop Grumman has big name suppliers, which means when cool new gadgets come out, your project may be able to get a hold of them a little bit before everyone else.
Executives at director level and above seem to be very sharp and good at their jobs, for the most part.
If you can get approved for Extended Work Weeks, it is very easy to get paid well above your pay grade if you're willing to work a lot of extra hours.
cons:
Northrop Grumman is a defense contractor.  This means that if the defense budget is cut, it likely also means that they'll need to cut back somewhere.
Northrop Grumman, like many defense contractors, often needs to hold on to people with subject matter expertise, even if they are not on contract, so you may find your team "padded" with these individuals.
Many managers don't believe in paying you for hours above and beyond your "full-time" status (referred to as Extended Work Week), but will imply that you should do it anyway.  There are managers that will allow this kind of charging, though.
Career paths are very murky - it's very unclear how to climb the ladder.

review_title: The Technical Services Sector give terrible raises

review_title: Ehh..it pays the bills.
pros:
As with other big corporations, on many points, the "Pros" depend on your location. But overall, 

(1) A pension along with your standard company benefits fare (e.g., health, dental, vision, life insurance, etc.) which I'm grateful to have, but the only distinction from other beltway bandits is the pension; 

(2) Good work/life balance in that when you need the time off you pretty much get it (again, dependent on your job and where you work because, realistically, it's essentially your direct manager & contract you're working that will determine that sort of stuff). 

(3) Lots of management I've dealt with have their hearts in the right place but are powerless in many respects. 

(4) Coffee is paid for (again, probably depends on your location); it's not Starbucks but it fills the tank.
cons:
(1) We've become our primary customer, the federal government. It shows in the big bureaucracy of red tape employees are forced to deal with (especially on the finance/business side of the house).

(2) Communication is either drinking out of a fire hose or the sound of cricket chirps.

(3) This for the finance types out there: tools & reporting ability are generally lousy at best with a few exceptions here & there.  Despite the fancy web interfaces and paeans to our multi-million dollar SAP system that's being invested in, we live by Microsoft Excel pivot tables.

(4) More emails of VP's coming & going than I can count with more chefs in the kitchen tripping over one another and making a big mess for those downrange who suffer the repercussions of idiotic data calls to make some big wig happy.

(5) Yearly salary increase range from 1-4%. Start your time here with as much as you can negotiate, because after that, chances are you won't be pulling in much more on a yearly basis. Still, at least there were raises which can't be said everywhere.

(6) Some might think the following good but I differ: employee morale & welfare being ruled by the masses via, literally, Gallup poll instead of clear thinking leaders with the ability to set a positive tone and policies that would distinguish working at Northrop from other defense contractors. Right now, generally speaking, you can probably cross the street and go to Lockheed, Boeing, etc. etc and get the same thing with variations on the sources of the afternoon headache.

To sum it up, working here is pretty typical of big defense companies. For the most part, you have military retirees with the right connections running the show as they collect their retirement on the side and bark orders to the troops with little or no thought other than the immediate task at hand. Don't come to Northrop expecting visionaries, innovation, or inspiring motivation.

review_title: Wasted potential, no vision/focus, highly unqualified leadership and management
pros:
Any decent engineer will have a job for life.
Benefits are good.
Technology has potential and room for growth and innovation.
cons:
This is particularly for the Woodland Hills, CA campus.  NG is a large corporation; experience at other locations will vary vastly.

The leadership and management are highly unqualified, directionless, and do not plan and work for the company's products, future, well-being, and employees in mind.  If you are successful, you will find yourself suddenly surrounded and being led by five or six bosses and "leads", none of which were around before your success and none of which will contribute in any significant and valuable way.  Often the "leaders" wound up creating negative work, slowing down your progress, and draining your budget or siphoning it for unrelated efforts.

As mentioned before, the technology has great room for growth and innovation.  However, behavior of the leadership and management often meant any good idea or opportunity for innovation will be hampered down by excess and ground to a halt by inefficiencies and bad planning.  More often than not the company seemed to be following trends, rather than being a leader or even at the forefront of technology.

A good engineer will have job security. But your professional career, skill set, and experience will stagnate and flat-line.  If you ever find yourself out looking for an opportunity, you will be hit with the hard reality that you are no longer competitive in the job market and, by extension, out of touch with your contemporaries in engineering and technology.

The environment is highly volatile and non-conducive to engineering.  Budgets are constantly being raided, employees are constantly being shifted around, resources are constantly being over and reallocated, and far too much time is spent in meetings and demonstrations.

review_title: Functional Home Room Induced me to Quit
job_title: Staff Systems Test Engineer in Rancho Bernardo, CA
pros: Job Security.  Cheap medical and dental if Single.  Some opportunity to transfer to other locations such as Melbourne, Florid, San Diego, etc.  Their 401 k has an unusual three components: Traditional pre tax, Roth post tax, and then After Tax.  Traditional and Roth total contributions are limited by standard IRS limits of 19 k or 25 K if over 50.  But after that, one can put more into the after tax!  And one can put in up to a total of 55k limit across the 401k total contributions.  So if one wants, one can put a lot of money into the After tax which later when you leave, you can roll over into your own ROTH IRA outside of work.  This was a fantastic thing for me being old and a senior as I make too much money to contribute to a ROTH IRA outside of work, but here I could dump a lot into what will go into my ROTH IRA when I leave, which I have done.  They do a 9/80 work week which gives you every Friday off and that in general is a good thing.
cons: Functional Home Room extra layer of management is horrible.  People you do not work for, and junior people at that who are manager wannabees are the ones that write your evaluations and performance reports.  They have no idea what you do for actual work.  In addition, they can put down anything they want in the evaluation, whether true or not, and you have no way to address or dispute what they put in. cons: Some negatives for Northrop Grumman are mediocre benefits (weak 401K match, no sick time), aging workforce (lots of 50+ employees very set in their ways and some not interested in working with new blood and technology), uninspiring leadership.

review_title: Business Management Intern
pros: Hours are very flexible. Every other Friday off and a lot of opportunities to move within the company. Potential to travel to other locations and great pay.
cons: Defense industry isn't particularly exciting in general. Lulls in between projects can lead to boredom unless you really apply yourself. The opposite may be true as well, once on a project you may find yourself very stressed out and busy.

review_title: College Technical Intern
pros:
Northrop Grumman definitely cares about their employees by caring about what you, as an employee, desire to do within the company.  NGC recommends relocating to gain experience in other projects and they care to hear about your annual goals.
As a College Intern, I was able to meet many experienced engineers and discover the engineer life-cycle for their contracts.
cons: I noticed that many projects leads and project managers are just waiting to retire.  So in small locations, it can be hard for advancement in the company if you stay.

review_title: Good benefits
job_title: Software Engineer I in Omaha, NE
pros: Good environment with a really good benefits package, and the starting pay was more than  I thought I would make right out of college, which was nice.
cons: You need to work for the government and sometimes it feels like NG as a company doesn't care a lot about retention.  My manager did, but our location didn't really fight really hard or stand up for me when my contract let me go (for reasons I later found out to be illegal).

review_title: Redefine your future at NGST but there will be obstacles.
job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Redondo Beach, CA
pros:
This is a place you can really learn given that you are given the opportunity. The environment is good for college graduates or people who just recently received their master's degree. The organization does emphasize college graduates to pursue an advanced education. The company pays for the tuition while you can work on a part time basis. Fellowships are available for employees who want to pursue doctoral degrees. These benefits are for engineering positions. A degree other than engineering is not sponsored. Business analyst have benefits in pursuing other business degrees. 

The health coverage is adequate and usual has a lot of variety for different employee needs. The 401k plan is average but does have the flexibility in terms of giving more diy people who want to invest on their own through a brokerage account. This company was originally called TRW until Northrop Grumman took over. So the pension plan still exist for employees who were hired back then but has already been phased out starting in 2008. NO pension plan for new hires as of July of 2008. Instead the company contributes funds toward the 401k plan. This is general practice throughout the industry and ultimately other companies will follow. So the idea of getting a pension is obsolete.

Communication from management to employee is decent, but really is different among departments. You do have a voice and can relay your opinions towards management. 

Work and life balance is good. I've heard that they have a mandatory 9/90 schedule now, which can be a good or bad thing. You can simply just perform your duties and leave at the end of the day.
cons:
Now for the real deal. The culture hasn't really changed since the 1960's. The engineering process has been magnified ten fold, with countless paperwork and documentation for accountability purposes. Work is mainly focused on documentation and design is still stress, but is now secondary in nature when it comes to closing out a design. Six Sigma is highly emphasized and management has jumped on the bandwagon for acceptance by higher authority and not by efficiency in its process. 

The wide extreme of personality among fellow workers. On average very approachable people but occasionally a couple of bad colleagues who exhibit unprofessional behavior, such degrading others through e-mail and wanting to control how others work and think.

Favoritism does play a significant role. If management believes you have talent, then the assignment is given you. Other than that, you are given a poor one. The good side is that management turnaround is every three or four years. If a manager recognize your ability, you have a chance to work on more interesting assignments. Not fair but this is part of reality. Promotions are handled the same way.

Career growth is in your hands. While management does support ideals, it is really for show and they won't do anything about it. If your future interest doesn't fit their needs, don't bother stating in your professional growth plan. Just apply for another position through their career website. Human resources won't really be on your side when the time comes for to get another job.

review_title: Great company if you don't expect corporate loyalty
job_title: Systems Engineer III in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Decent pay and benefits relative to the rest of the industry. Staff is very technically competent relative to other companies and good performance is rewarded with good pay raises and bonuses.  Management is flexible with vacation time, and the holiday shutdown is basically an extra week of vacation that I would have taken anyway.
cons: The company has little loyalty to its employees when it comes to layoffs - granted, I wasn't laid off because I left before they could, but I saw others who were laid off. As long as you have "coverage" and stay billable on a contract, you're good as gold even if you underperform. When you receive notification you're about to lose coverage on a contract, you'd better find something else fast or hope you have a lot of vacation banked up so you can take vacation and look for new billable work.  Otherwise they lay you off no matter how much seniority you have with the company. Senior management does a poor job of handling the labor budgets, and if they screw up, you're the one to pay the penalty, not them. They'll force people to take vacation if they're overbudget on a contract, then turn around and lay people off later. Plus the senior management doesn't alert you to impending doom, they just spring the news like it's no big deal that you're about to be laid off in a month. What's really maddening is NGMS will lay someone off, then hire someone with an identical resume on another task order. Why couldn't they just transfer you to the other task rather than hiring a new employee?

review_title: Good balance of work and life.
pros: Northrop Grumman offers good benefits and good opportunity to balance work and life.
cons: If you work on a contract you'll periodically go through the rebid process. Finding other work at Northrop if a contract ends is far from guaranteed. But, while the contract is good you know you're good, so it goes both ways. Also when on contract your raise will probably barely keep pace with the cost of living because the company wants to make a certain percentage profit.

review_title: Easy Money but Not Fun Work
job_title: Financial Analyst I in San Diego, CA
pros: After about 7 to 8 months the work becomes easy. You can show up put in your hours and leave(as long as you get your work done). The 9, 80 work schedule is nice, you get every other Friday off. If you get a cool manager they are cool about your schedule as long as you put in your 9hr.  They have tuition reimbursement program that is generous, it pays 15k a year. If you want an easy job while you go to school its not bad for that.
cons: After you learn how to do your job by trial and error because there is no formal training, the work becomes tedious and boring. They call you a financial analyst but it should be "database processor" or "data manipulator". Even if you are super efficient and are looking for more work (they will give it to you if you ask) there is no point because unless you are related or good friends with a high up VP or Manager good luck getting promoted. They believe that you have to have a specific amount of years served with the company before you can be promoted. They even have a chart that says between what years you have to have to promote. The yearly raise is average at best 2 to 4% and the bonus program is a joke its just setup so that the managers can get bigger bonuses. The managers are on a different scale for the bonus program and they are hush hush about it. This job is not bad if you want something easy and don't care about promoting fast. If you have any drive to move up in an organization or you like stock market finance don't take this job.

review_title: It really depends upon which sector you work for.  With SATCOM systems, I enjoyed my time there.
pros: Levels of expectations are fully defined.  You are give the scope and resources to work with and know what is needed to complete the job.
cons: Being that it's a such huge company, the culture can be somewhat sterile at times. Health benefits are in line with the industry, but not fantastic.

review_title: Mysterious "Friends & Family" Promotions, Deep Ruts
pros: I am very proud to work at technology leader like Northrop Grumman, and have been able to work on some exciting, fascinating projects.  Apart from professional development and promotions, benefits are as good or better than any other company I have worked for.  A recent sincere effort has been made to improve Work/Life balance...NG can be a great place to work, but the "quality of life/work" depends a lot on one's "permanent" supervisor (and his chain of command) and the luck of the draw in projects...
cons: Mysterious promotions to close "friends and family" of senior management irk me the most.  Firstly, there is a huge culture and compensation gap between the Westinghouse Old Boys Network (pre-1997 employees) and NG (post-1997) workers.  Pals of big managers can be promoted, even if they do not meet the minimal requirements for a position (e.g., a generic bachelor's degree).  Kids of VPs, Directors and other bigwigs enjoy backdoor entry and accelerated promotions.  A manager recently slipped up and blurted that, after an employee has been at NG 8 years, management figures that he/she will not leave, and tightens up the raises accordingly.  There is a vast disparity in the way supervisors conduct annual reviews, and corporate policy contributes to the byzantine process by implementing raises every 15 months or so, disconnecting the eval & raise events.  Promotion inside one's own rut is rife with Catch-22 pitfalls.  Changing jobs or moving to different business areas requires a miracle or herculean personal campaign, unless one is in the "friends and family" plan...  Despite corporate policy and executive vision, mid-level managers in the OBN will do what they please.

review_title: Being a manager at Northrop Grumman
pros:
1. benefits are decent
2. ability to work from home is nice
3. 4 weeks of  vacation is nice
cons:
1. An environment where it's acceptable for people to speak down to others and even yell.
2. Almost impossible to advance unless you "make friends" with Director/VP.
3. Org changes every year so there is never any cohesiveness to the environment, very difficult to keep staff motivated becauses there are always changes.
4. Micromanagment of Sr Mgmt.  For example, need a VP to approve me taking my staff to lunch, or getting a Blackberry.  
5. It's an environment where others will throw you under the bus to make themselves look better, this does not occur within functional orgs but across functional orgs.
6. They always add top layers of mgmt while reducing lower level managers, staff.  This company is TOP HEAVY.

review_title: Good company with ability to be great but carrer is limited if you do not have friends at higher levels to help you
job_title: IT Support Manager in Richmond, VA
pros:
Good Benifits as far as profit sharing and other items like health care coverage etc...

Personally I have been able to get off as needed for personal  reasons so that has always been a good thing to have when needed. management is good in that area
cons:
Program Managers make unrealistic decisions based on profit and not reality of how the program actually works at ground level or towards customer needs..
They expect unlimited hours as in monitoring emails at 9:30PM for 6:30AM directions the next day and this happens  time and time again. When do you suppossed to be off work? Mostly applies to salary staff. Many workers work 60 a week minimum and some upwards to 80...a week!!

Management places work leads and and other non-management staff in management types of situations where you have no authority over who they ask you to correct lets say in a employee behavior problem scenario or work not getting work done scenario.

Seems like the same top 15 people get promotions and change jobs while the rest can interview 10 times for 10 different positions but you never are qualified to receive an offer. Basically if your manager does not help you advance then you cannot on your own talent alone. I say this not just me but noticed this many times in our peer group. Interviewing for 3-4 times for a job and there are only two from your program and they then hire the 3 candidate  from the outside. you are better off to come from outsie then to be hired from within.

review_title: Manufacturing Engineer
pros:
-Friendly work environment. My co-workers, along with my manger were a pleasure to work with.
-Professional Organization. In regards to the values of the organization, NGC is great. They really do strive to be a top-tier organization. 
-Good medical benefits and 401K plan.
cons:
-Hard to move up. Moving up the corporate ladder if only easy if you work at one of the main campuses.
-Pay raises are minimal.
-Constant concerns of labor shortages and lay-offs. For the last couple of years they have had numerous rounds of lay-offs. This greats, as you can image a high level of anxiety among the work force.

review_title: Insider view
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Northrop talks a good game.  They claim to be a diverse workplace that values women and minorities.  Don't believe it.  Its for show.
cons: Women may be at the upper levels for the public eye, but the reality is that there are exceptionally few women in management.  They will low ball your salary.  They will low ball your promotions.  They lie.  They overwork everyone, promise the world, never deliver.  Their benefits have dropped significantly.

review_title: Diverse Company with Potential
pros: Large company with diverse offerings. Opportunity to get involved in a variety of different projects. Potential for growth if you push the envelope.
cons: Lots of bureaucracy and politics. Extensive networking and use of who you know required to move around. Lots of senior folks just waiting retirement hanging around.

review_title: Good place to start a career
pros: Work-life balance is good. Company does care about employee engagement and feedback, with an increasing focus on making it actionable.
cons: Information is often silo'd between organizations, even those that operate under the same umbrella. Training and learning opportunities aren't as easily gotten as they make it out to be at the beginning. Often is not approved and you have to use your own time, even for industry certifications. Compensation is ok.

review_title: Good Company
pros: Very good flex schedule. They offer the ability to work a 9/80 program where you enjoy every other Friday off. Also offer competitive salaries to their employees.
cons: If you are part of overhead you do not get to see the very cool products that Northrop Grumman makes too often. Sometimes it can also be hard to get answers when people work in different time zones or offices.

review_title: It's been a good place to assist me in building some hard skills
pros: Building hard (technical) skills and the education assistance is fairly good along with ability for telecommuting positions makes for quality work/life balance.
cons: Unless you have multiple advanced degrees or know people, advance,eat is hard to come by. If you are a veteran, don't even think of moving into leadership positions unless you have advanced degrees or know many powerful people in the company

review_title: Systems Engineering Manager
job_title: Systems Engineering Manager in Rancho Bernardo, CA
pros: Northrop Grumman provides great work assignments on great programs with great benefits, work-life balance,  9/80 work schedule and year-end shutdown. The company has great internal educational classes to help develop the employee for career progression.
cons: Ethical behavior of management at the Rancho Bernardo center of excellence. As of 2018 the Rancho Bernardo site is under pressure with respect to work.  The current site programs are all being pushed into sustainment and there is lack of follow-on UAV contracts. NGC also no bid the UAV tanker program.

review_title: Hopes Were High
job_title: Production Operator in Rolling Meadows, IL
pros:
Extremely flexible schedule
Nice benefits
Clean and safe environment to work.
cons:
Unless you’re an engineer or management, there is no focus on you. 
Too many managers putting in there input even for the smallest tasks. 
They gave up on their technicians.

review_title: Overall Great Experience
job_title: Capture Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Huge company working on some of the most challenging problems in the DOD. Good benefits.  Lots of opportunities if you know how to take advantage of them.
cons: TS sector is contracting  - layoffs and uncertainty will be a reality until they figure some things out. Size of company creates possibility of being pigeon holed into a role for extended periods.  Mostly due to security concerns the company uses out dated technology and tools for corporate management making it more difficult to do your job.

review_title: New Town, ND site
pros:
4 day work week
Pretty much hire anyone
Small town environment at this sire anyway.
Lots of chance for overtime after the first year.
cons:
Pretty much hire anyone

High mentee to mentor ratio that has been caused by the New Town, ND  site's very poor management decision to take on more work than it could handle.  Now they are forced to hire way more than the building can handle.  You have employees elbow to elbow in some areas.  There was talk of local expansion to the building there but the company itself seems too reluctant to spend any funds to do the project for the North Dakota site.

They promote whoever they want though it helps to be in the "inner circle", so bring your golf clubs and your chap stick.

They have poor supervisors in place.  Most with no floor experience and some just plain old lazy.  

Company constantly runs out of materials that are needed to do the job but still holds their incompetence over their employees heads, demanding they deliver the product with plenty of threats along the way.  

Raises are horrible.  Average roughly 2% yearly.  

No retirement packages anymore other than the standard 401k.  

This site has trouble getting the employees quality tools to do the jobs.  Parts they use on harnesses are hardly "platinum parts" as they claim.  They are literally the cheapest things they can find.  So much for doing everything we can for our military.

There are a few very hard working individuals working the production floor but there are way more that waste time or are just plain old lazy.  They rely on the few good ones to pull programs along but they do it with absolutely no rewards.  The bad employees seem untouchable.  Some should have been fired a LONG time ago.

review_title: Still here unfortunately
pros: 9/80 week. Most people are pleasant
cons: No opportunities. Its a fast track or no track in Northrop Grumman. Cannot move up in my own organization as they only hire from the outside. Manger quits, you put in an application, they don't even call you back to tell you that you are not getting an interview. Management changes frequent, but they rotate. No way to move up, bottom line. The rare examples are new hires that somehow get on a fast track. kiss up buddy, then you might make it here.

review_title: Good, but could be better
job_title: Manager Inustrial Security II in Monterey, CA
pros:
+ Stable Fortune 500 company
+ Good pay/decent benefits
+ Small sites typically the most freedoms, best perks and less bureaucracy 
+ Internal transfer opportunities abound
cons:
- Big, antiquated, often times complacent company
- Stingy ‘profit sharing’ program (if you can even call it that)
- PLENTY of lip service from the top...
- Hands down thee most hellacious IT Service Desk (not the people per se, but rather the parts and processes ‘as a whole’)

review_title: Glassdor
pros: Good people, have a great culture for diversity. Employee Resource groups are fun. Kathy Warden is such a great CEO tho! I love watching her talk when she talks to employees.
cons: Their management matrix changes a lot. Confused who to go to, a lot of managers who in the end can’t really hell you find something.. you gotta network on your own to find another position you’re interested to. Since there’s a lot of ladder there, i was not compensated well, underpaid. They follow a specific structure for salary even though you do a senior work

review_title: Cutting edge technologies
job_title: Digital Design Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Cutting edge technologies and problems and a good place to train.  There is a good amount of work-life balance here.  Very few people work late or on weekends.  You are rewarded for achievements, not face time.
cons: Layoffs, inability to allow employees to move laterally out of their functional specialty.  A lot of technical management was chosen due to technical smarts, not leadership ability.  Most of them could benefit from leadership training.

review_title: Fine place to work
pros: It is a big company with a small company feel. The name attracts some very talented people, and the corporate culture seemed pretty supportive. They don't stand in the way of successful teams. Frequent acquisitions lead to some disjointed units.
cons: There are huge disconnects between business units. Constant reorganization is the theme of the day. I had to keep my current department name in pencil, because it changed so often. The sharing of information between departments and divisions is nonexistant.

review_title: Great job, great company, tough location for an "outsider".
job_title: Senior Naval Architect/SE in Pascagoula, MS
pros:
Great compensation and opportunities for a dedicated worker.
Pretty good job security in scary economic times.
cons: The "yard environment" is pretty ugly, which can be hard for someone who prefers a professional environment.  Parking is a nightmare.  Union vs non-represented issues can also be pretty ugly.  I would say I'm pretty proud of my company, but feel like a fish out of water at the location I'm in.

review_title: Overall a good place
pros: Overall a good place to work.  Good opportunities due to the industry lacking mid-level employees, due to the downturn in defense in the 90s.
cons: Lower pay than a similar commerical industry opportunity.  Big company.  Easy to get pidgeon holed, feel like  cog in the works, etc...

review_title: Safe, but not a place to grow.
pros:
Stable work.  
Low stress and relaxed environment.  Dress is fairly casual. Schedule is flexible.  Hours are sane.
Free coffee.
Nationally Recognized Name.
cons:
Dinosaur technology:  Company builds to the status quo instead of pushing the use of advanced technology.  Slow to embrace new ideas.

Technically inept management:  Managers of technical projects have little understanding of day-to-day challenges faced by their employees. 

Process Heavy: As a government contractor there is a lot of bureaucracy and busy-work to deal with.

review_title: My experience has been Turbulent
pros:
Tuition Reimbursement
Genuinely Interesting work
Many locations in and around Baltimore area
You work with some seriously smart people, especially in engineering,
cons:
Horrible, unfair, review process
NG uses "Matrix Management".  That means you have a functional ("Homeroom") manager and a separate manager you're working for on a progrom.  The person that controls your review (homeroom mgr) is not the same person that sees you work every day.  It's a terrible, terrible, arrangement.  It's 100% uphill to get a good review.

review_title: Culture Clash
job_title: Internal Process Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great attitude towards employees in need after natural disasters. Great place for engineers to work. Progressive company that works to increase market share.
cons: Sectors too competitive with each other. Couldn't get anyone to work together across sector lines. Product lines so diverse it was tough to get corporate support on specific initiatives. Huge culture shock between "airplane builders" and "shipbuilders". HR function in several sectors was terrible (incompetent and deceitful).No upward mobility in management. No clear leadership or management career path development.
